【質問: Corinna Van der Ghinst (Analysts)】
This is Corinna Van de Ghinst on for Kate. I was wondering if you guys could talk a little bit more about the promotional environment that you saw across the competitive landscape in Q4 and how that might have impacted your business during the quarter. And then just as a follow-up to your comments on the inventory buildup ahead of the port disruption, you mentioned that you're not expecting a material impact on your results, but how do you think the port disruptions might be impacting the selling environment across the industry in the first half?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Yes, from a promotional point of view, this is Dick, from a promotional point of view, our focus is really selling premium footwear and apparel. So we know what our cadence is. As Lauren talked about, our markdowns were lower, so going into the holiday period our promotional cadence was where it needed to be to manage our inventory and to drive sales. So we finished up with our inventory on standards -- better than standards and with the markdowns down. So we worry about what we have to do from a selling point of view. The cadence around the industry, we monitor, we know what goes on. But again, the kids are coming for us for innovation, exciting new products and they're willing to pay for those. As far as the inventory buildup and the port delay, again our team did a tremendous job of getting out in front of it, so that we were well positioned going into Q4. We gave a little bit of relief on our ending inventory numbers, as Lauren talked about, to make sure that we were positioned going into February and we continue to monitor it. Obviously, there's catch-up going on. As we talked about, they'll be awhile while where everything gets reset, but we feel good about where we sit in the industry.

---

【質問: Corinna Van der Ghinst (Analysts)】
Okay, great. And then just as a quick follow-up, do you have any guidance on how many shop-in-shop rollouts you're planning to do this year across the Fly Zone, Kicks Lounge, Jordan 23, et cetera?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Yes, we'll go into a lot more detail on that when we talk on the 16th, but those would be part of remodel programs and new store openings. And our remods will be at a level fairly consistent with what we experienced in -- what we accomplished in 2014.

---

【質問: Michael Binetti (Analysts)】
So can you talk a little bit about -- and I apologize if I missed this, can you talk about what ASP was versus traffic in the fourth quarter? And then maybe just how that dynamic looks directionally as we think about 2015?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
ASPs continued strong as they have been all year. Traffic was up slightly in the quarter. Very strong traffic in international divisions. In the U.S., it was a bit more mixed with some divisions up slightly and some divisions down slightly.

---

【質問: Michael Binetti (Analysts)】
And directionally in 2015, Lauren?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Well, I wouldn't see ASP's direction to change and traffic we continue to drive in excess at the mall, we believe, because very strong product offering, great marketing efforts and that's the reason why we're making sure that we keep those store environments so fresh and exciting because that helps with the traffic.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
And our vendors continue to bring innovative and fresh product and the customers clearly are responding positively to that. So I agree with Lauren, I think ASPs will continue to be where they're at or up slightly.

---

【質問: Michael Binetti (Analysts)】
So I guess the -- where I was going with that is that you guys -- we're thinking ahead on the gross margin for next year here a little bit and I know you guys tested some new allocation software last year and you commented that, that would further help merchandise margins with improved markdown rates, but you also just commented on ongoing item new pressure. You've had a lot of pricing power here that's been helping on ASPs and the products obviously resonating. I'm curious how far we should look ahead to IMU continuing to be a pressure, considering the consumer seems to be accepting these price increases.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Again, the IMU that we saw this year, that pressure was really driven by mix of vendor offering and mix of category, so it wasn't about the price we paid for the product. I would see IMU tempering somewhat, that delta year-over-year, but we still think that's a factor. So we control what we can control. We work very closely with the vendors to improve product flow that help with the margins, and as you pointed out, we're in the midst of the installation of the allocation system, which will help us get that much smarter at getting the right product to the right place, therefore supporting lower markdowns, more full priced selling.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
And using more cross-channel initiatives as well. So our inventory is visible to all of our customers, regardless of where they're shopping, which gives the inventory, at the end, more value and allows us to use fewer markdowns?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
And when we really are at the top of our game in apparel, that should help as well. But we've got, what we described, we think that on a constant currency basis, merchandise margins improved slightly in '15. We levered the fix, but we've got to navigate the FX, which, when you factor that in, it means we're going to be flat to up slightly when it's all finished.

---

【質問: Eric Tracy (Analysts)】
If I could go to DTC, just continued strength particularly in the banners. Maybe just a bit of an update there in terms of where you feel like that channel has evolved, what still needs to be done in terms of sort of infrastructure build-outs to support and any just sort of updated thoughts around the consumer migration that you all see.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, I'll start with the consumer. Eric, we see a multichannel consumer worth more than a single channel, for instance. So while we drive excitement in the stores, we also have great programs online that attract the consumer. We want them to be able to shop our stores and our banners wherever they are, whenever they are. So we've been in the digital or dot-com Internet business for a long, long time, so the infrastructure has been in place. We continue to make improvements. Lauren mentioned an order management system that we'll put in place starting in 2015 just to make it a little bit more effective on the back end and make it a little more streamlined for the customer on the front end. But we continue to make investments both in the stores and the digital space to make it more clear for the customer that wherever they are, whenever they want to shop they have access to our banners and to our product.

---

【質問: Eric Tracy (Analysts)】
And then as you think about it, just a follow-up on that in terms of the vendors, Nike coming out with their sneaker app and again, just that balance of working with the vendors to segment the product across the space, any sort of issues, challenges as this channel evolves?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
No, I think that we have a great relationship with our vendors. The strength that we bring to the table that our consumer can see the best of all the vendors. We're able to create meaningful assortments across vendor brands. And I think that we're going to both coexist in the space, obviously. But our marketing programs drive consumers to our sites, the product attracts them to our sites and our stores and I think that it will continue to drive success in the multichannel environment.

---

【質問: Eric Tracy (Analysts)】
And then just lastly, if I could, as it relates to Europe. Sort of on a constant currency basis, so beyond FX, the assumptions being made for '15, it sounds like traffic is holding up pretty well, but maybe just speak to the underlying demand within Europe that you guys see.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
We continue to see the recovery -- the economic recovery is a little bit bumpy in Europe, different -- north and south, different country-to-country, but we're in 19 different countries and the sneaker culture continues to be strong. The running silhouette is king there, but the team over in Europe is doing a great job of making basketball relevant to that consumer. Our vendor partners are strong in Europe as well. Ken has called out in previous calls that the 2 real emerging markets from a sales perspective are the U.S. and Western Europe. So we're positioned well. We continue to invest there, Lauren talked about the store openings being driven there. And the team over there is also doing a nice job with their digital efforts. So we feel good about where we're at in Europe.

---

【質問: Christopher Svezia (Analysts)】
So I guess, first, just on apparel. I guess fourth quarter better than maybe the trend line we've seen throughout the year, but there's still some work to do. So I guess your thoughts about where the opportunity is, maybe where the issue is, private label versus branded. What can you do really to kind of start to see some improving trend line given the drag it's been across the business. And I'm just curious, in Champs remodeled stores, was there a dramatic difference versus those Champs stores that were not remodeled on apparel?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
We see a difference in the remodeled stores, absolutely. And I think that we talked about it in the comments earlier, Chris, that in Europe, it's a little bit of a case of some branded assortment items that have not resonated as well with the consumer, along with some private label hiccups. At Champs, there are some branded issues with a couple of programs and then the private -- or the license side of the business. And Champs is on a pretty steady decline. So it's a matter of getting those things balanced, working with the brands to make sure that we've got strong assortments. Part of the remodeled program is to do a better job of storytelling from head to toe and across the brands, so the remodels, a small percentage. We're not done with the remodel program by any stretch of the imagination. So I think the work that we've seen done at Foot Locker and the things that they've done at Footaction tell us that there are some upsides and the work that the team at Lady Foot Locker and SIX:02 is doing on the apparel front tell us that we can get there. It's just that the 2 banners that have the highest penetration, Champs and Foot Locker Europe, have struggled a bit.

---

【質問: Christopher Svezia (Analysts)】
Okay. So I don't know if you'll break this out, but just in your assumption of your mid-single-digit comp on the year, you're not really assuming the apparel business turns, I assume? You're still a negative number?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
We don't break out that guidance by product category, but rest assured, we're working very hard on apparel.

---

【質問: Christopher Svezia (Analysts)】
Okay, fair enough. Just last 2 things here. One, just on the remodels for Foot Locker and Champs, any -- I think you're at 30% on Champs, 20% on Foot Locker, any thoughts about what that looks like this year? You continue to remodel those, any percentages? And Lady SIX:02, are you at a point now where you can more aggressively roll that out? Or is that something you'll touch more on, on the 16th?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Yes, well, we'll talk -- we'll have some more about SIX:02 and our women's business in totality on the 16th. But the status of the remods, we ended the year with Foot Locker at about 20% through its remod and Champs about 25 and we're at about the same remod level in '15 and '14, which is what the plan is. They would both end up, Foot Locker and Champs, in the low 30% completion at the end of '15 on remods.

---

【質問: Sam Poser (Analysts)】
I just wanted some clarification. You said that you expect in reported numbers the D&A to be $150 million, is that correct? Or you get -- you should get -- can you just clarify that for me?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Yes. We should be about $150 million to $155 million in reported next year.

---

【質問: Sam Poser (Analysts)】
And then even with that, you're expecting reported -- you're expecting your reported currency-affected earnings to be up double digits as well, correct?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Yes. But as I described, the double digits is, because of FX, more tempered than what we've been achieving in the last few years, which has been double digit, then 20-something increase. We're expecting something more tempered than that because we've got FX pressure of about $0.16 to $0.18. Does that help?

---

【質問: Sam Poser (Analysts)】
Okay. And then as far as the product mix goes and where you are with the allocation, where are you, Dick, with the allocation system and the implementation there? And where are you with the implementation of the allocation system right now? And when do you think -- when do you expect that to be completely in place?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, Phase 1 of the implementation is ongoing across the U.S. divisions. Europe was our leader in that and has most of their divisions up and they'll be 100% onboard with the allocation system later this quarter. The U.S. will trail that a bit, but will also be -- by the midpoint of the year, will have all of their departments on the allocation system and that will be Phase 1. Phase 2 will be piloted in Q4.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
And we really don't -- we don't really ramp up until 2016 before we get to the last division, the last product category.

---

【質問: Sam Poser (Analysts)】
So then, just to understand it. You should steadily get some benefit from this as it rolls in, but arguably, as it gains its own history and does all the stuff, next year will be -- this year will be good, next year will be better and '17 would be full effect is the right way to think about that?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Well, you're absolutely right that we continue to get benefit for multiple periods because, as you described, it is a learning system. The more it learns, the better. There are also humans running it, so the more we learn, the better. But as we have opportunity then to apply those learnings to our purchases, right, we have -- we purchase many months in advance, we'll start to apply those learnings to the purchases and we'll get benefit. So yes, it's a multi-year build.

---

【質問: Sam Poser (Analysts)】
Okay. And then lastly, what is the share count that you're assuming -- the average share count for the full year that you're assuming in the guidance?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
I'm not going to go that far. But as we said, we just with executing the share repurchase program, the new $1 billion program, we expect average share count to decline in the year.

---

【質問: Sam Poser (Analysts)】
Would you expect it to decline more than it did last year on a percentage basis?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
I can't do that for you.

---

【回答: John Maurer (Executives)】
It'll depend on multiple factors.

---

【質問: Robert Ohmes (Analysts)】
Just a couple of quick ones, one is just a follow-up on the Michael Binetti's ASP question. Can you give us color on the -- was the ASPs strength in the fourth quarter, was it across basketball and running? Was it sort of a similar type of average selling price? Or was one way ahead of the other?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
We saw increases across our footwear categories, Robby.

---

【質問: Robert Ohmes (Analysts)】
So were they -- was basketball a lot stronger than running? Or was running ASPs up similarly to basketball?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
They were both up.

---

【質問: Robert Ohmes (Analysts)】
Okay. And then the technical running business, so I think you called out the casual running business, but any commentary on the health of the technical running business? The Free and the Lunar and I think you mentioned ASICS getting into casual running, but how about their technical running business, how is the outlook for that in 2015?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
It varies banner by banner for us, of course, Robby. I mean I think when you look at Brooks and ASICS and some of the platforms that you mentioned from Nike on our women's business, there's still strength. We've got a certain number of doors that have good programs with all of those technical shoes in our Foot Locker banner both in the U.S. and in Europe, so we think that technical -- we think that the running silhouette continues to gain strength. Whether the shoes are technical or lifestyle, most of them don't get running [ph] anyway. So the point is that the vendors continue to bring great looks in the silhouette that has meaning for our consumer.

---

【質問: Robert Ohmes (Analysts)】
Got it. And then last question. I know you guys saw the Walmart and TJX announcements about wages. Can you remind us where Foot Locker is in wages? And if we should expect any changes or pressures given what's going on across retail.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Yes. So our compensation for our store associates is base plus commission. So they have the ability through their sales strength to set their compensation. As a result, the majority of our associates are significantly more than minimum wage. So we watch those developments very closely because we are committed to paying competitive wages. But our associates, certainly compensation dollar-wise is important to them, but there are also other things that they enjoy about working at Foot Locker, not the least of which is being in stores surrounded by sneakers, which they have a personal passion for. So the discount that they get on that product is also important to them. But I would say, we continue to watch that very closely and we'll remain competitive.

---

【質問: Bernard Sosnick (Analysts)】
I'm wondering about eBay (sic) [Eastbay] posting a pretty nice gain. Is there something going on there that's invigorating that business?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, I think that as they manage -- as our team out in Wausau manages our store dot-com banner and the Eastbay banner, there are puts and takes sometimes, Bernie, but they've done a really good job of communicating with that high school athlete, which is really their target. They've got great relationships with our vendor partners. They published a really nice look in adidas catalog and a really nice look in Jordan catalog. They continue to use the catalog, the Eastbay catalog, as marketing tool. I just think that the consumer really responded to some of their marketing efforts in Q4.

---

【質問: Bernard Sosnick (Analysts)】
And could you flesh out a little bit the reasons to success at Footaction?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
I think the footwear sort of speaks for itself. They've got a great assortment of footwear that really attracts the consumer, but the thing that we really called out, Bernie, was their really good work around apparel where they've been able to take key lifestyle silhouettes from our major athletic vendors and blend them in with some of the faster fashion sort of vendors that consumer that really shops Footaction is after: Asphalt Yacht Club, American Stitch, et cetera. They've got the ability to move a little bit quicker in adjusting to some of those styles, so I think that they finally have a nice rhythm as it relates to that mix. And obviously, when you talk about things like Timberland boots becoming a fashion item, Footaction certainly benefits from that sort of mixture.

---

【質問: Bernard Sosnick (Analysts)】
Great. Sounds like you have a lot of good things going on and I'm sure we'll hear more about Lady plans on the 16th.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Absolutely.

---

【質問: Seth Sigman (Analysts)】
I wanted to follow-up on the Lady business and the double-digit comps that you're seeing there. Is there a way to quantify if there's a benefit you're seeing from some of the store closings that you've done there? Or is there a benefit from maybe opening some bigger stores? I'm trying to dig in a little bit more on to that level -- that low double-digit comp that you're seeing and what's driving that improvement.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, it's a combination of a lot of things, right? I think the merchandise assortment is improved. They've done a nice job positioning apparel even in the smaller Lady Foot Locker stores. They've shifted that consumer over a little bit in that base. Clearly, Lauren called out that we closed some underperforming stores, so that will continue to benefit us. The footwear mix is strong and obviously we've got the 15 SIX:02 doors that factor into that mix as well, which are, in fact, a bit bigger stores, Seth.

---

【質問: Seth Sigman (Analysts)】
Is there a way to think about how big of a delta there was between your better-performing Lady Foot Locker stores and then some of the ones that you closed?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
We haven't really gotten into discussing how good the good are and how bad the bad are, so it blended out to a double-digit comp gain for the quarter.

---

【質問: Seth Sigman (Analysts)】
Got you, okay. And then as we think about capital allocation, it's been great to see the increase in buyback. There's been a little bit of an evolution in the thought process, it seems like. How do you think about the right ratio or the right level of repurchase on an annual basis? I know you gave a 3-year view with the authorization, but what's the right way to think about the annual target there?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
It's not a formula. We take into consideration what our capital plans are, we described those as $220 million for next year. We factor in other uses for the cash. And between that and the dividend, we're making sure that we've got really meaningful returns to the shareholders. So I hope that helps you.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
As John said earlier, the amount of repurchases is driven by a lot of factors and Lauren just called out many of them. So we don't have an annual target.

---

【質問: Seth Sigman (Analysts)】
Okay, understood. And then just one more and I'll hop off. But in terms of store growth, it looks like you're going to be a net opener in 2015, first time in a while. I know we'll get a lot more color in a couple of weeks, but I'm just wondering, are you accelerating the openings of some of the banners? Or you're just closing less of others? How should we be thinking about that at this point?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, we called out in the comments, Seth, that the openings are going to be around Kids in Europe and then in SIX:02. So I think that our goal is always to close fewer, quite honestly. We'd prefer to get them more productive and keep them open, but when we have opportunistic chances to close stores, we'll take those opportunities if it makes sense. So I think that, regardless of net opener or not, our square footage continues to increase based on some of the shop-in-shops that we talked about. And the productivity of our square footage continues to increase, which is really what drives the business.

---

【質問: Edward Plank (Analysts)】
I wonder if you guys could dig in to the Runners Point Group a little more. At this point, what have you learned about that consumer? How does it affect your thinking about the growth opportunity there? And then as a second point, how is their online business helping you guys to think about your own dot-com business in Europe?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, from a Runners Point perspective, from a group perspective, we're working on the consumer segmentation work that we've talked about in the past. We've got the Runners Point stores now really defined as all things running, from lifestyle to performance. So they've got men's and women's, the assortments are there, the high-touch selling is there, the treadmills are there to really create that running destination in the mall and the high streets of Germany right now. Once we get that model proven and completed, we'll be ready to test that model outside of Germany. The work's not quite as far along with the Sidestep banner, that's a more lifestyle-driven banner. So as we look to position Sidestep, Foot Locker and Runners Point in the same mall or the same high street in Europe, we've got a little work to do around profiling the Sidestep assortment in the way that the store looks and figuring out exactly who their muse [ph] customer is and making sure that we speak to that consumer. So I think we're making good progress. Clearly, the Runners Point is ahead from a segmentation point of view at this point. From a dot-com perspective, the Tredex business that's part of the Runners Point Group is helping inform the Foot Locker Europe team and we've got our center of dot-com business, our center of excellence in Wausau, so we're trying to share global best practices between the team that's over in Europe and the team that's in Wausau and we continue to see progress being made there as well.

---

【質問: Matthew Boss (Analysts)】
So there's been a lot of debate lately about the athletic cycle, what inning we're in. I'm just curious what you guys are seeing in terms of lead indicators, product pipeline. And you talked about customer demand for the more premium priced shoes, but just in general, how do -- what's the best way to think about not just here, but also abroad, the athletic cycle in the pipeline?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Yes, we continue to see good product in the pipeline. I think, Matthew, the vendors continue to bring innovation whether it be technical innovation, whether it be fabrications, colors, new platforms that they're operating on. So we continue to see a pretty robust pipeline of product across the categories and around the geographies. And I think that it's somewhat of an athletic cycle, but it's also a casualization cycle where people are very comfortable wearing sneakers these days. And I get a lot of stares on the train when I've got my suit on with my sneakers, but it doesn't bother me at all and our core consumers certainly are very comfortable wearing sneakers. So there's ebbs and flows across categories that I expect we'll continue to see, but I feel good about where the athletic trend is and certainly where the pipeline is.

---

【質問: Matthew Boss (Analysts)】
Great. And then on the margin side, can you just talk about where the European margins stand today versus maybe prior peak and more so how to think about the opportunity on a go-forward basis?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
The merchandise margins is your question or finished margins?

---

【質問: Matthew Boss (Analysts)】
As much detail as you're willing to provide.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Okay. Well, let's talk about it in terms of finished margins, which my comment around that would be we have done just so much on productivity, really across the geographies that margins, no matter what part of the globe you're in, are strong. But historically, our international margins, finished, that benefited from the fact it's just less promotional in many of the European markets with legislated promotional periods. So Europe countries, recovering from trough periods, and as Dick described, that's been a little uneven. So as that comes back, opportunity to further increase those finished margins internationally. And the initiative that we're working on, they apply across the geographies, doesn't matter which we're talking about. So the allocation systems and the time and attendance systems, scheduling systems that we put in, all of those are global initiatives.

---

【質問: Paul Trussell (Analysts)】
There's already been a lot of focus on AUR on this call and I'll just try to ask in a bit of a different way. You all are seeing sneaker strength beyond the very highly priced premium Jordan and LeBron product, you mentioned boots and other casual and running silhouettes, some of the younger hoopers like Steph and Kyrie are also seeing success. Are you concerned at all that there will be a share shift towards some of these lower priced, relatively lower-priced products, that could have a negative impact to your overall comp? Or is the unit volume from these assortments enough to make up for it?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
So we know that our kids are going to go to wherever the coolest shoes are, right? I mean, we certainly trade, as you called out, up at the higher end with the Jordan or the LeBron and some of those key sneakers. But a lot of the business is also built on the LeBron Soldier, for example, which is not up at that high price point. That's more on the Kyrie and the Steph Curry sort of price range. So I think we've got strength, Paul, across the range of price points and we see kids buying the Roshes, which are great casual sneakers. They may have 2 or 3 pairs because of the colors that are there and what they want to hook up with. The same with the ZX Flux from Adi, not a high-end basketball sort of price point, but certainly we do volume because the shoe is so flexible for the kid to wear in multiple iterations. So I think we continue to see a good, strong mix of price points.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
And I think we worked very hard to make sure that we have a strong offering across the price points.

---

【質問: Paul Trussell (Analysts)】
That's helpful. Appreciate that. And then just touching on margins, obviously there's a lot of noise regarding FX this year, but just in general taking a step back, how should we think about the comp thresholds to leverage fixed occupancy and expenses on a go-forward basis? Has that changed at all as we look back over the past year or 2?

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
No, we still are able to lever at low single digits. Part of that is making sure that you really plan your expenses tight and in line with sales and you will react to ups and downs. And I think as we demonstrated it last year with where we finished with our margins and our SG&A rate, we have a finely developed muscle there.

---

【質問: Jay Sole (Analysts)】
Questions about the basketball trend. Under Armour has made a lot of improvement in basketball recently, and when that happens, do you see the overall interest level from a consumer standpoint increase? Or do you think one brand's benefit really just comes at the expense of another brand?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
I think that we end up expanding the market in totality, Jay. I think that there's kids that are comfortable with the Under Armour brand, there are kids that will try the Under Armour brand because of some of the things that they're doing. But I think that in the end, we end up expanding the market a bit. It's a new price point, it's a new vendor, there is new excitement around the Curry shoe. Obviously, having him win the 3-point shootout in his new shoe didn't hurt us starting this quarter out around the All-Star game. So I don't necessarily think it's a share shift. I think that we end up growing the market a bit.

---

【質問: Jay Sole (Analysts)】
Got it. And then just on that All-Star game, can you just talk about how you were able to leverage that event and turn into a big sales driver?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, the All-Star game's important for us every year, I mean regardless of where it's played. I mean, obviously with us being in New York and the league being here in New York, there's a lot of excitement around it. So I think that one of the differences this year was the fact that it was held in 2 locations, so we've seen many markets where the All-Star game has brought the town, the city to a virtual halt. Well New York, of course, is so big that it can absorb all of that. But it's a good boost to the start of our year regardless of where the All-Star game is held. It's ultimately driven by great product.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
Great product and we have some exciting things going on in special shop.

---

【質問: Camilo Lyon (Analysts)】
Just one question here. Looking out to '15 and thinking about the mid-single-digit comp there, you've had 5 years of mid- to high single-digit comps, outstanding performance. Can you help us prioritize the building blocks that will drive another mid-single-digit comp this year? Whether it's categories, remodels, e-comm, international, any sort of prioritization and maybe quantification will be greatly appreciated.

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, Camilo, I think that we've got the ability to walk and chew gum with all of those categories, so I think that there's strength across our banners; there's strength across our categories; there's strength across our channels and there's strength across our geographies. So we obviously have internal plans that we work off of, but I think our guys, our teams are all driven to find success. Retail is sort of a perpetual gain. It's not like we can't repeat. It's more difficult than some of the team sports to repeat, but our team certainly believes that they can repeat and I don't think it makes any difference what banner they represent, what channel they represent or what geography they represent. So I think there's a nice strength across our business.

---

【回答: Lauren Peters (Executives)】
All of those levers that you enumerated, all of those levers are what make us excited about the future and give us confidence. And we'll be talking a lot more about that excitement on the 16th.

---

【質問: Camilo Lyon (Analysts)】
No change in demand profile for any other categories nor the opportunities continue to drive sell-through for that?

---

【回答: Richard Johnson (Executives)】
Well, our categories always ebb and flow, Camilo. I mean, our buyers and our merchant teams do a great job of identifying hot categories and shifting ultimate buy dollars to be in the right place, and we work closely with our vendor partners to have a view of the future. But we don't get into where we see categories going up and down dramatically. So I just think that we have strength across all the pillars that you mentioned and that really, to Lauren's point, is what has us excited about '15 and certainly beyond.

---

【回答: John Maurer (Executives)】
All right. So thanks again for participating on today's call. We hope to see many of you here on the 16th. And please join us on our next earnings call, which we anticipate will take place at 9 a.m. on Friday, May 22, following the release of our first quarter results earlier that morning. Thanks again, and good bye.

Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our annual results presentation. I'm going to be very brief this morning because Simon's got quite a fulsome report to make to you all. First of all, I'd just like to say last year was a very good year for us again, remarkably the sixth consecutive year that we've grown our earnings per share by 15% or more, which I think is a very major achievement through a difficult economic time. Sales were up 7%, and we've gone through the GBP 4 billion mark for the first time. More importantly, we've returned GBP 572 million, virtually all our free cash flow, to our shareholders in buybacks or dividends. You'll notice in Simon's report that we've highlighted the total shareholders' return of 19%, which is also pretty good, but we feel that now we're doing special dividends that we ought to look at the total shareholders' return as another measure as well as EPS. So we will continue to track that as we go forward. You are more interested in hearing Simon tell you how we did that and what our prospects are in the year ahead. So I'll pass it onto Simon. Simon?

---

Thank you, Chairman. Very flattering of you to suggest they're going to be interested but I'll do my best. It was a good year for NEXT but a very much, to use an old cliché, a year of two halves. At the beginning of the year, we -- at this point last year, we forecasted our profits to be up 8% at GBP 750 million. We then had 2 amazing quarters. Those 2 quarters were really the second and third quarter of a three-quarter run are very good seasons. Rather rationally, we put our forecast at GBP 795 million. And at that time, there were some accusations and we were being overly cautious. And it turned out, third quarter, we issued what I'm not allowed to call a profit's warning -- Alister gets very annoyed -- it was a minor adjustment to our guidance. And we came in at 5% in third quarter, which was very disappointing. I mean, at that point, we forecast 1% up in the fourth quarter. As it turned out, we did slightly better than that, up 3%. Full year profits came in at GBP 782 million boosted significantly by some group profits. And the underlying profits from the brand were up pretty much in line with sales, around 7.7%. Just looking at those 4 quarters, it's important to see what's actually going on underneath the numbers because the fourth quarter looks like the worst. If you compare it to 2 years, that's the 2-year growth in each of those quarters. What you can see is that the fourth quarter, because it hit the overperformance of the year before, actually in 2-year terms was as good as any other quarter. And it's really the third quarter that was the underperformer and that was when we had the period of very warm weather. And I suppose the important point about this chart is that the experience in quarter 4, you can use as a predictor for the experience that we like to have in quarter 1 and quarter 2. 
Just going back to the accounts, GBP 782 million is what we made. Total sales were up 7.2%. Total operating profit up 12.3%. You should really look at that at the very most of being 11.1% up because there was GBP 9 million currency gain. This is not a real gain. It's basically an accounting adjustment, accounting profit on instruments that we use to hedge out the following year's purchases. So it is purely an accounting measure but is not a real profit, and we'd expect that to reverse out in the year ahead.
Taxation, the same as last year. Last year, our tax reduced a lot by a tax win. This year, it was reduced a little bit by another tax win. In the year ahead, we expect it to be around about the same, around 20.5% as the tax rate -- corporate tax rate continues to come down, subject to any changes that might be made after May. Profit after tax up 12.5%. Earnings per share up 14.7%. That's being boosted by not only last year's buybacks but the buybacks at the end of the previous year.
Moving on to cash flow. Capital expenditure. Capital expenditure on stores slightly down on last year. The drop is down to spending less on cosmetic refix that we did in the previous year, about GBP 5 million less on cosmetics refix than the previous year. 
In terms of other expenditure around the business, GBP 18 million on new IT building, upgrading some of our product buildings and GBP 2 million spent on the beginnings of replacing all of our till systems. Just in terms -- in case you think we're blowing money on fancy head offices, this is just to give you an insight into the beauteous and wonderful head office that we work in that is, in fact, the old Kendall's building that was our systems department and the money we spent on the IT building is to turn into that. So we bought for the front increased space by 60%. So it is a -- and our head office complex is one that needs a little bit of expenditure and it's a bit out of date. But just to give you a feeling for -- when we used to interview people for the systems team, we used to interview them on a different building from the one that end up working in. I'm sure many banks have similar systems department. Warehousing, GBP 12 million in the year. This is all about automating part of our home warehouse for furniture. Looking forward to the year ahead, we expect slightly more expenditure on new stores, partly because we're in -- we anticipate opening slightly more new space and partly because we anticipate spending a little bit more on cosmetic, about GBP 5 million more on new space, about GBP 5 million more on cosmetic. A further GBP 11 million on head office infrastructure. The real issue here is I think far more important issue for the business in a way is the fact that cash customers spend less with us. So the average spend of a cash customer is significantly lower than a credit customer. So the failure to recruit new credit customers is likely to slow growth in top line as well as the road margin. So that there is an issue on margin but potentially a bigger issue on sales. In terms of mitigation, 2 things that we're looking at. The second thing we're doing is we'll begin to market the account unlike other major companies. We've never actually marketed our account. We continue to rebalance the business, drive new revenue streams and invest in future growth. So when we got our renewed license for 10 years, there was a basic set of scales of costs and benefits, and those came out as neutral. And that's as it should be. So I think that part of the conversation has already taken place. I think there is a very interesting debate on sports rights, and you can go from one extreme, like Australia, where all the main sports are protected, to somewhere that's completely open, and then us in the U.K. somewhere in the middle. But if you look at most sports, what's fascinating to me is that cricket is gradually trying to come back free-to-air. Darts has gradually come back free-to-air. Boxing is trying to come back free-to-air. One of the good things about going pure pay is you probably get a lot more money. One of the not-so-good things is your exposure goes down pretty sharply in terms of awareness. And if you look at something like the Champions League, I think we attracted more for our one game than Sky did for their 17. And as a sports right holder -- and I used to be one, that is something, in the long term, you have to think quite long and hard about because it's that interest and exposure that drives participation. It drives sponsorship. It drives merchandising. It drives interest in the game. It drives the people who buy your pay-per-view subscriptions. So you've got to balance the 2.

---

【回答: Archie Norman (Executives)】
All right. Thank you. Those are all good questions. These are very good set of results, and this, I think we'll cut short there. We're happy to stay around -- I know the team is, to answer any questions or [indiscernible] discussions later. Thank you.

---

【回答: Adam Crozier (Executives)】
Thanks, everyone. Thank you very much.

4511809.eventHeadline: Hannover Rück SE, 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 10, 2015
4511809.transcript_text1:
Well, good afternoon to everybody here in London, and good afternoon, depending on your time of day, to all those who are joining us via the Internet. I wasn't going to give you a reminder about turning off the mobile phones, but it's easy to forget. So please do check if they are off. That said, welcome to Hannover Re's Analyst Conference. It's a pleasure to see that so many of you have taken up the invitation and we are very delighted to present to you the numbers for the financial year 2014 in greater detail, the numbers which we have published already this morning.
Today, we have a new feature compared to previous analyst conferences. We are offering additional dialing option for all those who were not able to participate here physically, here at the London Stock Exchange. [Operator Instructions]
First of all, Ulrich Wallin, will kick things off with a brief overview of the 2014 financial year. Roland Vogel, our CFO, will then move on to present the financials in detail. Afterwards, we will be happy to respond at length to all your questions you might have. And I would like to point out that you are kindly asked to wait for the microphone so that everybody can understand your question, even those who are not in the room.
On that note, I'm delighted to hand over to Ulrich Wallin.

---

Yes, good afternoon, and welcome to our presentation of our 2014 results. I will kick it off. I will also finish it off with the outlook for the coming year.
Well, I mean, 2014 for us was quite a good year, I would say. I mean, as you can see, we managed to increase the after-tax earnings of the group by more than 10% and this has been driven by a strong underlying earnings from all segments so that we could continue our rather conservative policy when it comes to reserves, be it on the P&C side or be it on the Life & Health side. So from that point of view, we didn't need to be aggressive on any of the various items of the profit and loss account and the balance sheet in order to generate this increased profitability.
We also decided to increase the dividend via a special dividend of EUR 1.25 together with the ordinary dividend of EUR 3 to EUR 4.25. And this is due to the fact that our capital grew rather remarkably by 28.2%, and then of course, which means that the excess capital also has increased. And of course, the ROE for the current year would be a little bit more stressed so that it was the right time to start with the capital management for Hannover Re, which we already announced at our last Investor Day.
You can see that the business continues to grow, even though at a lower pace, due to the rather challenging market on the P&C side, whereas well publicized the competition has increased quite significantly. But nonetheless, as the business continues to grow both the P&C business, as well as the Life & Health business. As already mentioned, the bottom line grew more pronounced as compared to the top line with almost 20% growth of the EBIT compared to last year and as already mentioned, 10.1% of the after-tax earnings.
Despite the significant growth of the capital, the ROE is still at a quite acceptable level with 14.7%. So we continue to enjoy attractive ROEs. If we then look at individual business groups, overall, as the Property & Casualty business, we are happy. I mean, we think development has been positive. EBIT grew by 12.2%. Admittedly, one might say that the combined ratio, particularly in the fourth quarter, some of you might have expected a slightly lower combined ratio. On the other hand, we are quite happy with the after-tax result of the P&C business group and we were also quite pleased that we could keep with our conservative loss reserving policy, which is the result, of course, of the quality of the underlying business. But also, and that shouldn't be forgotten, of the fact that the large losses came in well within the budget and this, of course, means there was no pressure or deviation of pressure to the combined ratio from the large loss site, which really pretty much offset the pressure on the combined ratio, of course, there from the reduced rates, which we see as a result of the current soft market. So therefore, we could keep the loss reserving policy rather unchanged, a little bit better than we actually had expected.
With the Life & Health business, I'm quite pleased that the earnings have actually increased, the EBIT increased by 75% and also, we had a 25% increase of the post-tax earnings. This is in line which -- what we are trying to tell you since quite some while, certainly, since the third quarter and fourth quarter of 2013. This year, this was still an easy target to have because our 2013 numbers, of course, were depressed due to the additional reserves that we put on the DII business, which we luckily can say now seem to be a conservative. So what really happened in 2014 as the results normalized. I mean they're not terribly exciting, but they are more to the normal level that we expect from our Life & Health business. I would say the technical result, particular in the fourth quarter, a little bit below what we're expecting. Again partly, I mean, conservative reserving on the enhanced annuities, partly negative deviation of the actual to expected on the ING portfolio. So but, overall, I mean, pretty much in line with expectation for 2014, as a whole year. But -- I mean, everything has a positive as well. I mean, if you look forward to 2015, we feel that there is room for -- through the improvement of the results of Life & Health.
We were very happy all together with the investment results, ordinary income app[indiscernible], which is quite remarkable considering the rather low interest rates environment that we are wrestling with. Here again, I mean, the increase in volume helped significantly. Also, it turned out to be a quite favorable for us that we changed the functional currency of Bermuda subsidiaries at the end of 2013 from euros to U.S. dollar because in restructuring the portfolio of around EUR 1.4 billion at the time into U.S. dollars, of course, if you have meant that we had to sell euro securities, which resulted in realized gains. And at the same time, the new investment in U.S. dollars were down at a time when the interest rates in U.S. dollars had a little spike. So even on those investments we already have realized gains. And also the running yields in U.S. dollars was slightly higher than in euros, particular since recently the -- is at the year started some new experiments with the euro currency. So overall, we were very pleased with our investment income.
This is the broad overview of what we see for 2014. The finer details, Roland will explain to you in great detail. Thank you very much.

---

Thank you, Uli. I think you mentioned already some parts of -- or the major parts of our key figures and results. But I think we should start with, before we get into the detailed P&L, we should look at some key metrics or remarkable developments of key metrics, which were not only driven by us, but also by the markets or the ease it be[indiscernible] or whomsoever. First of all, the strong cash flow for 2014, nearly reached the 2 billion mark again. We started a little bit slow into the year. I think we mentioned at previous occasions that there was one U.S. mobility contract. And we might come to that contract, again a little bit later, which was cash negative in the first 2 quarters. This will turn around. It has already. And it will turn around in 2015. So we will get that money back, but the second half year, with very strong cash flow, which I think supports the positive message and the quality of the results even with a little bit of more depressed overall growth, the cash flow stays very positive.
On the right-hand side, the assets under own management up by 14% or EUR 4.5 billion. I can tell you with the development of the U.S. dollar and the yields, especially the yields of the government bonds, this, today, is approaching EUR 39 billion. So the increase is really remarkable. And again, this is not only driven by a very good result, but also the yields and especially the currency exchange rates.
The same goes for the capital position on the next slide. Equity increased by nearly EUR 1.7 billion or 28%, the policyholder surplus by EUR 1.5 billion. Why is that a little bit different? Because we paid back EUR 750 million in February and we issued the subordinated bond, and we issued a new subordinated bond in September with another EUR 500 million, which then again, was the reason why the policyholder surplus decreased order. Subordinated bonds here decreased a little bit. You might remember there is another call date coming up in June for EUR 500 million. Up to now, we indicated that the last EUR 500 million was already an early refinancing. This is not an announcement that we will call that up to now we have called every subordinated bond at its first call date. So one might expect that this green part of the bar might go down in June. On the other side of that slide, you see the increase in the shareholders' equity. And I think that demonstrates very clearly, where this increase is -- strong increase is coming from. First of all, of course, EUR 986 million of result. The dividend we paid last year was the EUR 362 million. And that demonstrates that the increase coming from the valuation reserves on our invested assets, as well as the currency exchange rates. This is more than EUR 1 billion and it's even higher than what we had produced as profits. Now you might want to distinguish these 2 components for the increased or the increased assets from the currency exchange rates. I think this is also reflected on the earnings side by higher U.S. dollar, Aussie dollar, whatever, earnings. So we earn also higher euro values on these amounts. When you look at the valuation reserves, the more than EUR 630 million in the middle that is an increase, which is really an increase in our capital base, which also will have an impact on the future ROIs. The overall number of OCI or capital driven by market -- by the valuation reserves in our asset portfolio is 1.5 -- EUR 1.2 billion, nearly. And with a modified duration of 5 years, one could expect everything equal. We might lose EUR 120 million per year because this will run off. This will be capital components, which will disappear in the future, but it's only EUR 120 million per year.
I think this leads us directly into the capital management actions, which Uli had already mentioned. Here, you see a -- from my point of view, impressive picture. If you look at the last 6 years, 6 years ago, we came here and mentioned that it is our intention to decrease the volatility in our earnings, to decrease the volatility in our dividend payments. And if you look at that picture here, you'll see that we were rather successful, of course, helped by the markets and also the catastrophe components in our business. But even in 2011, which was the second highest natural catastrophe burden in the history of the insurance, we managed to provide a good dividend. The EUR 3-plus, the bonus do represent EUR 150 million. So that is what we kind of give back to our shareholders as a start of -- potential capital management action. The dividend yield today or a few days ago, 5%; if you go back to the beginning of the year, 6%; if you go back 1-year and you had invested into Hannover Re share 1-year ago, the dividend yield would even be above 7%.
One other perspective at the capital development and the ROEs we have provided and do provide. I think the chart demonstrates clearly the achievement. The average capital position has been increasing remarkably from the EUR 4 billion to the EUR 6.7 billion this year. Still we managed to keep the ROE on a very, very high level. On the right-hand side you see the average achievements. On the left-hand side, the last 5 years. The margins over or above the hurdle and we have shown here the old total, the 750 basis points, as well as the new hurdle, the 900 basis points has even increased over the last years, but we have to bear in mind that this has got to be more challenging in the future, with the high capital position and with also the higher volatile capital components. I have tried to explain to you with the OCI positions, which might be volatile in the future. So this is going to be more challenging into the future and this is why we also look at managing the capital position, as well as the income position up there.
I think that -- then leads us directly into the peer comparison, which we always do. I think we are still the #1 on the 4-year horizon. This year, 2 Bermudan companies are in front of us. I think that is not very surprising because of the very low cap burden, which the industry has been seeing. So in that regard, we are still happy and we are still committed to stay one of the most profitable reinsurers in the industry, also, in the future.
So let's then have a brief look at the P&L in more detail. On the group level, I think it's not necessary to repeat the growth of the turnover of the premium. The first component I think which needs some explanation is the other income and expense line here. We have been long in the U.S. dollar and the -- in other non-euro currencies already over the course of the year. And in so far, the majority of that swing from minus 100 to plus 18 and the other expense line is based on the currency result that should be 0 if I manage my portfolio on a very highly matched basis. So on the one hand, this is a little bit of a one-off. On the other hand, I think where we were in doubt, we stayed a little bit longer in the foreign currencies as we saw the euro weakening, especially against the U.S. dollar. This is why this line has improved so remarkably. Moreover, I think other components here is the fee income on those contracts from -- on the Life side, which are deposit accounted, where the risk component is so low that there is no reinsurance treatment justified and the fee income is reflected in that line and that has been increasing as well. Moreover, we have been rather successful in managing our LOC costs down. Also, that is mainly on the Life side where it was possible to decrease the cost of the LOCs, which we, in the majority, need to back up our U.S. business. The tax rate is back to normal. You might remember that last year we had a special effect on the Non-Life -- on the P&C side where the deferred taxes on equalization reserves could be calculated a little bit more realistically based on the decision of German taxman that -- or that have had reduced to 90 million extraordinary effect. That, of course, was not repeated this year. We are still a little bit on the low side based on a very positive result in Bermuda where the tax rate is 0 and where our cat business is written mainly, so the contribution from the low tax environments had been a little bit over proportional, same goes for the Life business, which we write in Bermuda. So this is why the overall tax rate is a little bit lower than what we would expect for a normalized tax ratio, which should be around 25% on a group level.
A brief look at the P&C side. We see a slight growth to 1.2% on a currency-adjusted basis, which is nice and which follows our guidance. Would this number have been negative that would not have been a problem at all. It is positively influenced by some low-risk, low-margin Chinese surplus relief contracts, which we sometimes write. Sometimes the margins are not sufficient. So again, it's nice to see it growing, but if that would have been a negative number, we would not be concerned at all. The burden or the net retention has increased slightly. So we pay a little bit less for our retrocessions, which makes itself felt here that the net premium income is growing a little bit more than the gross. The major losses, I think Uli has already mentioned, the large loss budget was EUR 670 million. EUR 244 million of that budget was unused. And in that regard, it was the third very large, loan large loss number in a row, which, of course, also has its impact on the competition, on the market.
Perhaps and, also, that was mentioned by Uli. Let's discuss a little bit our reserving policy. If you look at the annual result and the runoff triangles, you will see a positive runoff of EUR 270 million. I think that is really fully in line with what I was trying to explain at the occasion of the Investors Day, and approximately EUR 50 million positive runoff would be expected per quarter, a little bit more than that for the year. So there are no extraordinary unusual effects on the runoff result. I would refer to my presentation at the same place, a few months ago, where I was trying to explain the impacts which could be there on the confidence level, as well as the runoff result. Nothing extraordinary here. In that regard, the combined ratio for the fourth quarter, when we read your first comments, seems to be a little bit disappointing. We, as Uli already mentioned, stuck to our reserving policy. We have most likely added and we're waiting on the final results of the reserve studies, but we will most likely have added to the reserve redundancies, which our COO always presented to you at the occasion of the Investors Day. We have to bear in mind that, also, the volume of the reserves has increased based on the currency exchange rates. So percentage-wise, we might have keep or kept the overall confidence level flat, but in absolute terms, we will have increased redundant reserves numbers, which you might remember was EUR 1.5 billion based on the last study. And that also explains a little bit, why the fourth quarter effect, which you had expected in the combined ratio has not taken place to such an extent. I think that's it.
Let's look at the MtCR and the achievements of the year per market on the P&C side. The margins are getting a little bit narrower. Still, even if you back out  the very positive cat result, we would still have made it and the overall result of the business would have been still profitable. We shouldn't fool ourselves  a combined ratio of 39.3% is nothing, which we could really see also in the future. And so far, a large cat year might make the overall P&C result getting nearer to the breakeven point. And it's good to have buffers if that happens.
Apart from that, again, we can briefly look at the North America business, still profitable below the hurdle or above the hurdle. The Continental Europe positive, with Germany also better than it used to be. The Marine business, after the big losses Sandy, Costa Concordia, very profitable. Aviation, we know what happened there. The triple E airport, as well as the Malaysian Airline disasters, of course, hit that. Credit, surety, profitable.  U.K. London Market and Direct, we still had a little bit of problem on some casualty accounts where we were looked at conservatively. We expect that to be far better in the future. The Worldwide treaty on the edge. Cat, of course, I mentioned that very profitable and, of course, the basis for the overachievement. Structured Reinsurance, very positive and making the margin, by far. The major losses I mentioned you can see that here very clearly, 3 years in a row. And if you add all the -- under -- or those amounts for the last 3 years where we were under the budgeted large loss number, that accounts for EUR 400 million. So the EUR 426 million, what you see here as compared to the EUR 670 million, the EUR 578 million as compared to EUR 625 million. But if you then go back to the year 2011, you'll see that all this, what we have saved within -- over the last 3 years, can be gone within 1-year. And in that regard, we should always bear that in mind and not fool ourselves that the very positive results in this segment might go on forever. You see, the large losses, the single ones, not a real single one was a very major loss. On the cat side, clearly, below the budget with the Triple E -- with the storm Ela in Germany, Belgium and The Netherlands, with the highest loss burden of around EUR 50 million for our account. The Aviation claims with Triple E and the Malaysian Airline losses as I already mentioned. Overall as I mentioned, EUR 244 million below our budget.
So another friendly cat picture, although not a glamorous picture. If we look at the Life and Health reinsurance, we did various longevity deals. We took benefit from the improved and the hardening rates in Australia and these were the major profit drivers. We did recede some of, especially the longevity deals, and this is why the net retention goes down. On the technical side, Uli mentioned that the Australian DII business did really well, fully in line with our expectations, even slightly better. So that explains the improvement here. The U.S. mortality still slightly below our expectations, but no better prices here as well. And this is then the basis for the remarkable improvement. The other income here, also, is usually better than in the -- on the P&C side. It did benefit, also, from currency exchange rates, but here even, also, from the fee income of our deposited accounting, especially the financial reinsurance contracts, which have improved as I mentioned before. Margin-wise, I think we are rather happy, Financial Solutions, impressive margins that is the business we especially write in the U.S. where our colleagues do provide coverage for the balance sheet or for the local balance sheet, especially and that is improving and growing nicely. The longevity also over and above the target. The mortality and morbidity business, as I mentioned, the U.S. mortality business, some of that business is still not fully in line with our expectations. And here we can come back to that one U.S. house contract, morbidity project, which we no longer write when we looked at reserves and increased the reserves or incurred some losses, especially in the fourth quarter. We, again, we no longer write that business. So this will not recur. And this is also the reason as to why we look very positive into the future. Even better news if we turn the page and have a very, very brief look at the MCEV. That is hot off the press. For the first time we managed to present the Market Consistent Embedded Value numbers together with our year-end results. And we have demonstrated or in our presentation only the major numbers you will find the details. If you're interested, if you believe in MCEVs, then you will find the numbers in the Appendix and on the website, especially the very brand-new website of Hannover Re, which I think is worth visiting anyway. The MCEV has increased by 16% and is now nearly EUR 4.3 billion. I think even more importantly, the value of new business is for 3 or even 4 years in a row, now on a very high level over and above our threshold of the target markets with EUR 448 million. Again, another new record. Again, this is profit which we will earn, also, long-term up until 20 years, 30 years. Still, with more than EUR 1 billion of new business value over the last 3 years, we are very confident that also the IFRS result will improve remarkably in the next years to come. Perhaps not mentioned on this page but still important is the MCEV or Market Consistent Embedded Value not recognized on the balance sheet. That increased from 1,10,000,000 to 1.12 billion, which is also an increase of more than EUR 100 million. And again, if you believe in MCEV numbers, that is another off-balance sheet value, which Hannover Re carries.
So to come to the investment side, the ROE target, from my point of view, as I'm responsible for that segment, of course, I look at that even a little bit closer. It is a little bit underrepresented or underestimated when we show it here. It includes the technical derivatives, which you see as the changing for value of financial instruments, that is the ModCo derivatives, as well as the inflation swaps. If we back that out, what we do on our target matrix always, the positives and the negatives, we end up at 3.3 ROI and which is a little bit over and above our target. If I come back very briefly to the impact of our subordinated bond redemption and reinvestment, so here we do calculate with the assets beginning of the year, assets end of the year, divide that by 2. Of course, the 7 months where I didn't have that money are not included in that, so also, that is a little bit the reason why the numbers here are a little bit underrepresented. The realized gains and losses, again, Uli mentioned that already, we had some turnover in the portfolio, which created these losses. Apart from that, there were no real surprises. Impairments and appreciations, driven by regular depreciations on the real estate portfolio. So again, nothing extraordinary to write-off. And with nearly EUR 1.1 billion net investment income, we are happy, and again, it is a little bit more than we had expected. 
It is interesting to look at the bottom of that page, what happened to our valuation reserves. I had addressed that already various times. We have now here, the on balance sheet valuation reserves. These are -- those of the investments we have, we account for at available for sale. The off-balance sheet values that is what we have as hold to maturity or what -- which [indiscernible] or others, which we do account at amortized cost. Altogether, that number has doubled from EUR 1.1 billion to EUR 2.2 billion -- more than EUR 2.2 billion -- or nearly EUR 2.3 billion. And we have not taken advantage of that by realizing more. That is a buffer for the potential yield increases in the future.
A brief look and final look before I ask Uli to present to you the outlook. The asset allocation, that is rather stable. The corporate portfolio has increased to 35%, a little bit more, there's nothing more to be expected. The front -- covered bonds have gone down a little bit here. A competitive investor, especially by the end of last year was there with ease at beak[indiscernible] also, competing to buy these issues. So that has come down a little bit, as also the prices went down remarkably. The real estate is developing as well as the private equity. So we keep these portions stable and it's -- and we will hear in a second that with the reinvestment yields we do invest today, our amounts of around 1.7, 1.8. The expectations for the next year is around 3.1% ROI with increased assets under own management. We estimate the return from the net or the net investment income, again in the range of the previous year.
I think with that, I conclude my details. And, Uli, the floor is yours with the target matrix.

---

Thank you, Roland. Okay, target matrix. This year, I'm happy to show it to you because it looks nicer than most years. You can see that we have achieved all group targets, including the earnings per share target with 10.1%, that's quite reinsuring. Then I maybe mention the EBIT margin on the P&C side, the 17%, shows that this business continues to be rather profitable. And you can also see that the economic targets, which are the xRoCA targets, we have achieved comfortably on both of our business groups. 
With that, enough about 2014. Let's look into 2015. First of all, P&C business, we have come off a pretty good start into 2015. The 1/1/2015 renewal was a little bit more favorable than we expected. I mean, we could keep the rates pretty well in many cases, and we also managed to slightly increase the volume. I can also say that the business opportunities for new business are actually quite good. So we have a good deal flow of new business coming in. I would, however, say that this is almost exclusively from existing clients where we have a good position as the go-to reinsurer. 
If I then look at the 3 segments: target markets, specialty lines and worldwide reinsurance. On the target markets, we see good growth in North America at a good margin, particularly in the U.S., where we have more than 600 clients. So writing larger shares with these clients and being involved in their new reinsurance purchasing, which we occasionally do. We see good prospects here. Continental Europe is a little bit a mixed picture. Parts like France and some other Continental European countries like Spain, for example, rather competitive. And of course, volume trending downwards due to selective underwriting. On the other hand, if you look at Germany, for example, still -- I mean, the underlying profitability trend is very positive. And being one of the larger markets in Germany, we benefit from that, particular when it comes to the bottom line.
On the specialty lines, all the business at this point in time is very competitive. So for us, the emphasis is entirely and only on the bottom line. We feel that we have significant businesses there, we're particular on the non-proportionate side, still offers us good opportunity for profit. But discipline is extremely important here. On the marine side, I mean, rates have come down a bit. But overall, they're still a profitable business. And same is true for credit and surety, where we achieved the #2 position in the market in 2010. And this, of course, helps us now that the business have become a lot more profitable -- sorry, a lot more competitive after good profitability in previous years.
Of course, business closes to my heart is aviation. Unfortunately, I can't see a lot of good things about it, because despite the losses, the market continues to be actually quite competitive. On the U.K. and Ireland business, as well as on the facultative business, we see some growth again after having retrenched on the U.K. business last year, and we also see improved profitability there. Worldwide treaty is, I mean, we see reduced premium on the cat site, which is not fully showing here. However, the exposure is still unchanged, even slightly up, but the rates are coming down. So again, a conservative underwriting is important.
On the worldwide treaty, we see plenty of opportunities in the emerging markets, particular Asia, India and China to be mentioned, but also on the agricultural business, which, with what we have written recently, we can clearly see that we will have further double-digit growth on the agricultural business. Also on the structured reinsurance and the ILS business, I mean, we see good growth opportunities, partly already materialized in the first 2.5 months of the year. So all in all, we are relatively, cautiously optimistic on our P&C business for the current year, even a little bit more positive than I would have been standing here, say, 3 months ago.
On the Life & Health side, again, the emphasis is clearly on profitability, which we expect that we could further improve. Particular positive is financial lines business where we have already quite positive trend, and you would see that when we report our first quarter results. We already have said early on, longevity, while this is -- we haven't got a new transaction so far this year -- well, maybe one, a slightly larger one. But we are working on a few others. Market has become a little bit more competitive because -- I mean, most of the reinsurers are competing for that business now. So, again, we take a rather conservative stance, looking for the right deals and not for the volume.
On the mortality, I mean, we have actually seen good profitability also in 2014, and that is also including the ING portfolio that put the whole thing together. We expect continued rise of profitability in that market. I think we will be able to further improve, which means not make it profitable but make it less negative, our ING book. And of course, the new business that we produced in the U.S. still shows positive volumes, actual to expected. So overall, that should be fine. On the morbidity where we have seen negative results, we believe that we also should see an improvement in Australia. Where on the group business, we have very, very significant increases on the TBD [ph] exposure from that business. So all in all, we are quite positive on the prospects for our Life & Health business in 2015. 
That brings me to the guidance, which we left unchanged. We believe that our volume will be at stable interest rates. I hastened to add stable to low-single-digit growth, a little bit like we have seen in 2014. Of course, if you look at that in euro terms, you see current interest rates prevail. You will see some more meaningful growth in euro terms on that business. Return on investment, 3%. Roland already mentioned that. However, on a higher volume of investments and EUR 875 million group net income guidance, we left that unchanged compared to what we told you when we reported our third quarter numbers of 2014. We believe that on stable interest rates, that's pretty much the underlying profitability that our business currently shows, projected with a degree of caution. And therefore, we left it unchanged.
