Honey, thanks. Hi and hello, everyone. A warm welcome to all of you to our Full Year Results Analyst and Investor Conference Call. We hope all of you have somehow digested the massive news flow on the sector over the last couple of weeks.
As always, before we start I have to mention first that you should have received by mail the link to our press release, to our preliminary consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year 2014, as well as the analyst and investor presentation. If you did not receive any of the aforementioned, please visit our IR website.
If you're already using a tablet-only, you can have a look at the Conti IR and you will find all the material available already there.
In the course of this afternoon, the tale of 2014 will also be available on our website for download.
I should also make you aware of Page 34 in the presentation, which contains our disclaimer. And last but not least, you can also follow this conference call via webcast.
As in the last 5 years, we start with the presentation, which is given by our CFO, Wolfgang Schafer, who is next to me sitting here in the room in Hanover together with my colleagues from Media Relations and from Treasury and Finance. We will host a Q&A after the presentation. And after the call, the IR team will be available and ready to clarify any open questions you might have.
So my name is Rolf Woller, and I hand over to Wolfgang that he can start with the interesting part of this call. Wolfgang, please go ahead.

---

Welcome to all of you. And before I guide you through the presentation, let me remind you of the Q4 market environment last year. Global car production was flat in the last quarter of 2014. Europe was down 2%. This includes Russia with minus 32% in the fourth quarter and France was minus 5%. And this was compensated outside of Europe with China and the U.S. market, which were each growing by 5%. Replacement tire markets were even weaker. Mild winter in Europe made the market plunged to minus 8% and the stronger North American market could go only partly compensate that.
Now how does this continue into 2015? We see the production in Q1 slightly up from the fourth quarter levels in Europe, but not as strong as hoped. New car sales trend in Europe, though, is making us confident that this should change in the next coming weeks or months and have a positive impact then on the production.
The tire markets in Europe remained weak at the start of 2015. Nevertheless, we can say that against this backdrop, we had a favorable start into the year confirming our close to double-digits sales growth expectation for the full year of 2015.
For other corporation highlights, I'm moving to Page 3 of the presentation. Our sales were up by 4% to EUR 34.5 billion, including a negative FX impact of EUR 470 million. The adjusted EBIT was up by 4% to EUR 3.9 billion with a margin at 11.3% compared to the 11.2% of 2013. The net income was up by 24% to EUR 2.4 billion, mainly due to massive reduction of our interest of more than EUR 500 million to minus EUR 265 million. Main reason for this is the early redemption and the partly replacements of our bonds in 2013, which positively influenced 2014, and which will have a lasting effect in 2015 following.
Free cash flow amounted to EUR 2 billion, up 11%, all-time record for Continental. And the net indebtedness, consequently, goes down to EUR 2.8 billion, achieving a gearing ratio of 26%, equity ratio at the company at around 37%.
We managed to create sustainably value and the trailing ROCE was up by another 60 basis points to now our target rate of 20%.
And 3 other topics I would like to mention under the most important KPIs of the full year. The acquisition volume in our Automotive Group achieved a new record with EUR 30 billion lifetime sales, which we managed to acquire last year. We finally closed the Veyance acquisition on January 30, 2015. And the third point to mention, our boards will recommend to the annual shareholder meeting to pay a dividend of EUR 3.25, an increase of 30% from last year.
A closer look on the sales and the adjusted EBIT of the group is presented on Page 5. First, you -- if you have a look at the last 4 columns of the slide, you can see the nice increase quarter-over-quarter, which we have shown in our sales development. The fourth quarter was EUR 8.9 billion, EUR 500 million up to the previous year, organically flat 3%, and the adjusted EBIT margin in the last quarter at 10.8%.
The development of the Auto and the Rubber Group in the fourth quarter was quite different though. And to get more view on that, I move to Page 6. And the left graph is showing the development of the Automotive Group. There, the organic growth was 5% or EUR 5.4 billion, which is a nominal increase of 9%, and the adjusted EBIT was up to EUR 455 million, plus 11%, increasing the margin, again compared to the quarter of the previous year, from 8.2% to 8.4%.
And different to Automotive, the Rubber Group growth was quite modest, only plus 2%, mainly 2 reasons for that. Weak replacement tire markets, Europe -- European replacement tire markets, minus 8% in the fourth quarter. I've mentioned this already, and on the quantity side, still, it's a weak mining business, which is affecting the sale of conveyor belts and of hoses. And this is reflected in the profitability, it was down from EUR 563 million to EUR 527 million.
For ContiTech, this is including EUR 15 million costs for the acquisition of Veyance and it is including the reduction of the mining business, which is a very profitable part of the ContiTech business. For the tire business, it is obviously including the lower volumes which we have seen in the fourth quarter, and it is as well including those tailwinds from raw materials of EUR 40 million, which were basically compensated -- even a little bit overcompensated through the inventory valuation, which we had around EUR 50 million, like in the previous years.
Nevertheless, the margin in the Rubber Group in the fourth quarter was again higher than 15%.
The growth profile, again, in more detail, is shown on Page 7. The organic growth of our Automotive Group, and these are now full year numbers for 2014, achieved 6% compared to the passenger car and light truck production growth worldwide of 3%. ContiTech sales only up 1%. I mentioned already the highlights on Page 10 shown in more detail, sustainable value creation. The ROCE achieved in 2014, 20%, 60 basis points up compared to already strong 2013. And more than one time, I've pointed out already on the efforts at Continental on working capital management and overall on our concentration on good management of the operating assets.
Page 11 is showing our maturities for the syndicated loans and the bonds and maturities. Obviously are no longer the biggest concern for us. The next maturity is in 2016. The term loan of EUR 1.5 billion from then on the next 4 years, each one was around EUR 750 million bond. The U.S. dollar bond here shown with EUR 782 million, $950 million, due in 2019, can be called first time in the third quarter of 2015. And in time, we will make up our mind if it makes sense to probably replace a new bond, prebuy it or leave it as it is.
The upper right is showing a table with liquidity numbers. Our total liquidity achieved EUR 7.3 billion in 2014 year-end, including a cash position of EUR 3.2 billion. This cash position is higher than our target rate of EUR 1.22 billion. Based on these numbers, Page 12, it is not surprising that the ratings which we get from the rating agencies are now matching our targets. The targets comparing H1 2009, so when our ratings were at the lowest point, to now, the ratings and the important ratios -- 2014 leverage ratio 4.55 and beginning of 2009; now we're at 0.39. Please don't take into account, though, that in the first quarter, we now will include Veyance with EUR 1.4 billion purchase price, so another EUR 1.4 billion to be added to our indebtedness. And equity ratio, up from 22% to 37%, as well above our target of at least 35%.

I'm moving on to more details of the Automotive Group on Page 13. The left graph is showing the growth rates of the 3 Automotive divisions. Chassis & Safety growing with close to 5%. And this is the organic growth rate, and this is driven by strong growth in our advanced driver assistance system business on the one hand side. Interior business has constantly shown a strong growth throughout the full year in many of the business fields where Interior is working. So overall, Automotive Group was growing with 5.6% organically. 
And on the profitability side, Chassis & Safety, stable margin, 9.4% compared to the previous year 9.5%, including though 100 basis points more R&D than we had it in 2013, reflecting the buildup -- a strong buildup of the business in our advanced driver assistance system business, which is doubling within 2 years from EUR 500 million to EUR 1 billion. Nevertheless, in Powertrain, in 2014, this was not the strongest year, obviously, and below our expectation. Yes.

The comparable figure...

And what's your third question?

Well, order intake, normally 3 to 4 years until it materializes in our books; in some divisions, even longer. Perfect. And another 2, please. On Chassis & Safety, can you please comment what is the contribution from Honda on revenues and the -- on profits, please? Well, Honda was EUR 500 million in 2014, expected to double until 2016 and breakeven, which was won in 2014. Philippe Barrier, Societe Generale. Two questions. Just the first question on the active safety. It could be a drag in term of profitability. Actually, does this distribution network could -- can negatively affect the operating margin in 2015? ---

Our Chassis & Safety midterm target is 10%, and -- but I think what you are indirectly assuming, and your question is right, that the -- this is depending on the growth of the advanced driver assistance system businesses and orders which are in there and the future growth will help as it is a fixed cost business to get the margin up towards the 10%. The additional distribution channels are not in such a magnitude that they are having a big drag on the profitability margin of our tire division. And your assumption that we should go above 20% in 2015, and this is not possible because of additional distribution channels, is not correct.

---

Okay. And just for a question on tires regarding LatAm operation. So you have a plant which was would it be recent [ph]. Today, what is your level of utilization of the plant in Brazil? And what should be the impact of declining market for Continental, specifically in Brazil?

---

Thank you very much. With this, then, we thank you for the very interesting Q&A session. If there are any follow-ups, as mentioned, please don't hesitate to contact the IR team; I am Rolf Woller. And talk to you next time, which will be on May 7, on the occasion of the release of the first quarter results. Thanks a lot.

It's Philip here from Citi. I was most interested in the 2020 revenue guidance. I was just wondering if you could, perhaps, elaborate on the assumptions there. I think -- I've read the press release, so it talks about a certain number of light vehicles. But are there any material acquisitions included in that beyond Veyance? And secondly, if I may, on FX. I think I've heard you say you're pretty much hedged in relation to year dollar moves at the EBIT line. Is that -- are you very confident that's going to be the case in 2015? And finally, actually just on pricing for each tire, I don't know if you've got a good feel for where replacement pricing might be in 2015.

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
And the EUR 50 billion which we talked about this morning in the annual press conference is based on a car production of about 100 -- a little bit above 100 million cars. And it does not include -- I think there was some, probably, misunderstanding this morning, this does not include major M&A deals. Of course, it includes -- and this was the message we were giving, of course, this includes already Veyance because we know that we do have Veyance for these numbers. But it does not include -- it's not external growth. It is internal growth, which we expect based on our orders on book and our expected development. The euro-dollar profit hedge, not only euro-dollar, all our currency hedge which we have proven in the last 2 years, we do expect to hold as well for 2015. And again here, we have the first 2 months, and I reconfirm that. And then your third question, which was on...

---

【質問: Philip Watkins (Analysts)】
Yes, it was on replacement, and if you were feeling good on replacement.

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Yes, pricing on tires. While we do see price pressure in Europe on tires, which is a little bit stronger than we had expected before, we do see quite low price pressure though in the U.S., which in the end leaves our expectation of a price down of about 4% in 2015.

---

【質問: Philip Watkins (Analysts)】
Is the Chinese situation having an impact in Europe? The fact that Chinese tires have been less attractive in the U.S.

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
The Chinese import, it's too early to tell. We did not see the numbers for -- the final numbers for January, February, and the indications we have are not sufficient to answer that question.

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
It's Horst here from HSBC. A follow-up question on this translation effect that you calculate. I just want to ask if I got it right, so that you calculate the EUR 1 billion translation effect that you potentially see for '15 on the basis of the average U.S. dollar rate of the last 6 months, is that right?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, it is our -- this is not only U.S. dollar. We have about more than 20 currencies, and there is the effect of Eastern European currencies is important as well, as we have production sites there, and you know that sales are more in Euro from there or even in other currency. Overall, our expectation for this year is the EUR 1 billion and to remind you, last year, at the same time, we had said the expectation is EUR 700 million for 2014. We came out with EUR 460 million. I think -- so this was the forecast, which was quite okay. At the moment, I think the EUR 1 billion is a realistic number, of course, more of it to be seen in the first 3 quarters, and then the fourth quarter is where the currencies, the euro was already getting weaker and the currencies were already changing. That will be less than we expected then in Q4.

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
But I mean, if I you take alone, for example, for the U.S. dollars, the average change over the last 6 months, you should assume a U.S. dollar-euro rate of USD 1.20. So we are now at USD 1.10. So that means -- what I want to know, if the currency rate stays where it is today at USD 1.10, USD 1.11, the translation effect potentially could be much bigger. I know it's not in your forecast. But if the currency -- if the euro remained as weak as it is, is that calculation right?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
But if you take again one single currency out of the set of our currencies...

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
But it's the most important for you, right, the dollar?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
No, no, it's not the -- the euro-dollar is not necessarily the most important. There is, as I've mentioned before, as well other Eastern European currencies, specifically on the hedge for the cost and sales side. So if the dollar would stay on this number, the number, the EUR 1 billion, might be a little bit higher. But, I mean, we do foresee and expect at the moment, the EUR 1 billion.

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
Okay. So in the last question -- or another question that I have is on European production. You only give this guidance including Russia, which drags down the European number in total. I want to know what you assume for the EU-28 countries in terms of production. Market gross?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Schneider, I do have the Russia number which we assumed for 2015. I'm just looking in the table [ph], another minus 20% is included for the Russian production in these numbers. I don't have now Europe without Russia here in the numbers, but...

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
So -- but would you agree that the start to the year, especially in Europe, has been stronger than you would have expected at end of last year?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, this is -- Schneider, this new car sales. There you're right. We do not see this in the production numbers. But, I mean, new car sales are a good indication that the car production should increase as well.

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
All right. And then the very last question that I have is, it was an interesting statement that you made on the order intake and that a big part of that came from Asia, and you also mentioned Toyota, and I also heard that from some smaller suppliers that, basically, I mean, it is said for some time now that Toyota is getting more open towards Western suppliers. Do you see significant upside from that perspective, especially with Japanese carmakers? Or is that a little bit too optimistic to state?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
No, no, no, this is completely right. We do see quite some increase in our sales with Japanese OEs, so not our sales in Japan, but with Japanese OEs worldwide have a good chance to double over the next 4 to 5 years. And this is really an achievement which finally comes through; as you were rightly saying, they are more open to the Westerners.

---

【質問: Horst Schneider (Analysts)】
Where does the share stand right now? Just on an aggregate; you don't have to mention it for a specific carmaker.

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
And the share of our automotive sales, yes, it's below 10% -- I mean, to all Japanese OEs, it's about 7% or so, 7% or 8%.

---

【質問: Christian Ludwig (Analysts)】
Again, one follow-up question on the FX. Did I get it right that you're -- on the EBIT level you're hedged that you, basically, will see no absolute impact of potential FX gains? And that would be question one. Second question, talking to some of the German dealers on the tire side, it looks like that they currently have a huge inventory glut of winter tires. You -- how do you see that developing, basically, into Q4 this year? What kind of potential risk is there that we'll have a very, very bad winter tire business for Conti in Q4?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Yes. First the FX understanding is not correct. We have said that the impact of FX on cost and sales is the same. So the -- relatively, margin will say the same, but the EBIT will change as well, influenced by the FX rate. The margin, not affected, but cost and sales are basically influenced the same, in the same relative way. And I'll confirm the winter tires at the dealers are high, quite high stocks. And I've mentioned already that, to our knowledge, the stocks -- and this is what we get as feedback from the dealers, the stocks of Continental are on a normal level, basically, not surprising, if you remember our reports of Q3, where we were reporting quite high winter tire sales into the organization, and now, I reported that the winter -- which were clearly above previous years' levels and now we reported that we've just managed to get full year numbers of 2013 matched in 2014, 22 million tires, meaning, we have reduced the selling into the tire organization quite significantly in Q4, which, in the end, leads to a reasonable stock situation at the dealers now, which, in the end, should not create a bigger problem for us than that for the 2015 sales, winter tire season starting in September or August, September in this year.

---

【質問: Kristina Church (Analysts)】
It's Kristina Church here. Just coming back to Philip's question on your guidance for 2020. I was just wondering whether you're now giving such a medium-term guidance because you see any sort of change in the way that penetration rates will go towards 2020. Is it linked in any way to sort of European targets and whether you think there will be -- you'll be able to make this division, for instance, more acceleration and penetration rates as you get closer to 2020 targets? Or is it -- am I reading too much into that? And then another question on the Powertrain division and your targets to get to the 8%, x HEV. Could you just give a little bit of an update on the -- your growth progression that you're expecting to see in sales as well for the Powertrain division?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
On the 2020 medium-term sales target of more than EUR 50 billion, basically organic growth, which we were giving, I think, it should not be a surprise to any of those which are following closely our target outperformance of the market, 4% to 5%. Fair enough, for 2014 due to Powertrain was, a little below that number. But if you take that, you get to a number which is clearly above the EUR 50 billion in the next 5 years. So I think this should not be a surprise. And there is no change in any environmental factors or market factors, which made us -- make this statement. And the penetration rate -- additional penetration which we achieved in the cars is already there with advanced driver systems with more connectivity of the car, with connecting the cars with each other. So there is a lot to be expected and specific strong growth in '18, '19, '20. And I think this is a continuous process, as we have shown, fair enough, a little bit less in '14, but even in '14, which we have shown in the last year. Powertrain, the 8%, excluding the HEV business, is our target for 2015. Medium-term target is to achieve the 10%. But this will take then the next years until 2019 until we will achieve it.

---

【質問: Thomas Besson (Analysts)】
Two questions, as well. Coming back first to this midterm target that I find fascinating. Can I ask if you're assuming any down year between 2015 and 2020? Or whether you assume that it's going to be the first entire decade of economic increase since the beginning of the car industry between 1899 and 1912.

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
No, we -- I mean, this is based on an expectation. We don't plan for a recession in these numbers. So this is planned for continuous growth of our -- of the car market, too, and it is above 100 million cars produced in 2020. This is the assumption on that.

---

【質問: Thomas Besson (Analysts)】
Okay, so growth every year. Second one, coming back to winter tires and to the European replacement market overall. Can you say, if you start seeing any impact of lower oil price on miles driven, and we've seen that in the U.S, are you anticipating that we should see that in Europe as well? And can you, as well, talk about any effect you anticipate from the increased offer of either all-season tires and like what Jelly [ph], or what you offer, or these new type of tires that Michelin seems to want to introduce that would be a bit of a mixture between summer and winter, potentially accepted in the regulated markets?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, miles driven -- and what we do see -- as you rightly say, we do see this effect already in the U.S. Miles driven goes up. They, of course, do have less taxes in their gasoline price, I think below $2 now hardly being the price for a gallon, this has helped the Americans to drive more. In Europe, these numbers are not available. But we do by -- from past years, we do see some effect with such a drastic reduction of oil, which as well in Europe makes the gasoline price to go down to see some increase in miles driven. The connection of those 2 factors is not as strong as we see it in the U.S. We don't see at the moment, though there were some announcements, we don't see a bigger change in the structure in Europe between summer tires, winter tires and all-year-round tires.

---

【質問: Thomas Besson (Analysts)】
Okay. Can I ask a question on the impact of raw material at a group level and you've discussed already what you anticipate for the Rubber Group. Can you explain us the equivalent effect on the Automotive Group on your primary raw material and the share of these raw materials, either indexed or not indexed? And what we should assume in terms of positive impact from raw materials in Automotive, please?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, first and second quarter, there was some tariffs for raw material, probably third quarter, probably something around the impact which we have seen in the fourth quarter. And our guidance then included some increase in the raw materials in the second half of the year, but I fully admit that our guidance for raw material in the last years were not always -- we were always guiding for some increase and up to now, it didn't come. We still believe that there should be some increase. To our knowledge, the natural rubber farmers are below all their production costs. And I mean we can, of course, lengthily discuss how the oil price will develop over the next half year. But I have mentioned the $10 down in the oil price, the effect on our cost reduction. The question there is so -- and I think this is the more important one, how much of this will finally stay with the tire producer and how much of this will be passed on to the consumers? Our assumption at the moment is no profit impact of raw materials in 2015 for Continental.

---

【質問: Thomas Besson (Analysts)】
Okay. But did you reckon it might be conservative?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【質問: Thomas Besson (Analysts)】
Can I move to the ATV losses? I mean, if I'm correct, they've expanded -- increased in '14. I think you've said very openly that they would continue to be high in the coming years. Are they going to stay between EUR 100 million and EUR 150 million in '15, '16? Or can we expect that they should decline to be at double-digit million euros?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, they will clearly be above EUR 100 million in 2015. There will be some improvement then starting in '16, as we had shown in our third quarter conference, but it will take until 2019 before we get to a breakeven. And, basically, the 48-volt business which really is nicely getting into our books now, which will help to get the growth of this business unit.

---

【質問: Thomas Besson (Analysts)】
Okay. The last one on the mining business and the impact it had on ContiTech and it had on Veyance. Can you tell us what you're assuming in terms of end market for '15, '16? And whether we should see already a recovery in the conveyor belt business and the construction business in '15, '16? Or whether you think it's still going to be a -- kind of flat in '15 before a potential recovery in '16?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
To a different degree we still expect the mining markets to be weak and potentially further decrease. Now for ContiTech. As conveyor belts are wear parts, you have to replace them because they're loose; these stones are running over them over time, they are worn out and they have to be replaced. So we do expect that this year, the replacement cycle is stronger kicking in for ContiTech, and by this that there should be some tailwind for the conveyor belt business. So it's not the mining market, it's more the intrinsic logic of the conveyor belt business.

---

【質問: Frank Biller (Analysts)】
Frank Biller, LBBW. A question on the order intake in the Automotive Group. So you've mentioned EUR 30 billion order intake lifetime volumes. Maybe you can give us more insight about what orders or which products are running best here in your new order intakes and, maybe, the comparable figure last year? The other question is on electric vehicle development. So we heard some news about electric vehicles not coming in so strong as expected. So what can you see right now? And what you expect in the quarters and years to come? And the other thing is in net debt, so gearing target is 20% here in your presentation here. So when do you want to reach this gearing of 20%? And what dividend policy should we expect until then?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
The order intake of Automotive -- I mean, I could -- I can give you some examples. We had a big order in Chassis & Safety of those numbers, which are stated there for the MK100 with Ford, which is the braking ESC system, the newest ESC system, with lifetime sales of more than half a billion. We had diverse advanced driver assistance systems with Toyota; I mentioned this as well. If you go to Powertrain diesel business with Koreans, exhaust business, the big exhaust business with BENTELER, transmission control with Ford and Audi as well, big orders, and I'm only mentioning orders which are on a very high level and an interior instrument cluster on the MQB platform, a hands-free module with some novel telematics with Toyota. So these are big orders which we have in our books.

---

【質問: Frank Biller (Analysts)】
The comparable figure...

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
I'm sorry, next question on electric vehicles. Well, if you say not as strong as expected, this is always where you put your expectation on ours. Now I think we had already reduced our expectation quite significantly. And I would not confirm this now for us. We did not expect more on electric vehicle orders to be than we do see them at the moment. Nevertheless, as I've mentioned, we do see now the increase -- strong increase in the 48-volt hybrid solutions, which is for many carmakers, a very attractive solution they can use the -- without any reparation of these old motors and just add on the 48-volt solution. They don't have to construct a new motor, which already helps to get a significant reduction in the emissions. Net debt. Well, if you take our free cash flow guidance this year, deduct Veyance from it, it's basically a slight positive leftover and then take off the EUR 650 million dividend which we announced, we most probably end up this year with a somewhat higher indebtedness than we had seen it and a somewhat higher gearing ratio than we had seen it at the end of 2014. Nevertheless, with no further acquisitions assumed, if I take this assumption, I think we are in a good position to achieve the target of below 20% in 2016. Now this is not in any way confirming that we are not looking at potential M&A. This is just assuming theoretical pro forma calculation should be achieved in 2016, if we don't do any additional acquisition. Dividend policy unchanged, 15% to 30% payout ratio, with our actual performance, cash performance more in the upper end of this range, as we show the 27% payout ratio again in 2015 for '14.

---

【質問: Paul Hartley (Analysts)】
My first one is just on the Powertrain division. So at the Capital Markets Day there, you talked about diesel products being one of the weaknesses of that division. And I was just wondering if you could give us a percentage in terms of the Powertrain revenues that come from diesel products firstly?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
And what's your third question?

---

【質問: Paul Hartley (Analysts)】
I was just wondering in terms of the Powertrain division...

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
No, this I understood. Okay, I thought there was another question to come. It's 1/3 basically of the engine system business which we have.

---

【質問: Paul Hartley (Analysts)】
Okay. And my follow-up question to that was just in terms of some of the headlines we've seen in Europe about -- particularly in France, about this decentralization of diesel, would you consider a move away from that fuel within the European market a positive for the mix of Powertrain then?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, the diesel -- the injection pumps and the injection systems in diesel are the ones which have a higher value for us. I mean, you're talking about much higher pressure and more sophisticated technology. So a diesel system is clearly for us more attractive to sell in terms of sales volume than an injection system for gasoline cars. But the question is always asked, if there are less diesel cars or motors and more gasoline engines, what is the net effect on Continental? And then this is not so easy to say because the question is, what is the diesel engine going to be replaced with? If this is a gasoline engine, including turbo charges, including direct gasoline injection, potentially even including some hybrid systems, this might be the more attractive order of motor for us compared to diesel engine.

---

【質問: Paul Hartley (Analysts)】
Okay. And then my second question was just on the Rubber Group. So I think for 2014, from the numbers you've given, your adjusted price mix was neutral in the tires division. Price was negative within that, and the raw material tailwind was about EUR 190 million. So taking that together, does that mean that the net of price mix and raw material was a positive in 2014 for the Rubber Group and for tires, in particular?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Yes, this is right. And you saw the increase in the margin of tires, which is confirming that. And just keep in mind, I mean, -- so yes, confirmed, but keep in mind that the price is 1:1 P&L relevant while mix is about only 30% P&L relevant.

---

【質問: Paul Hartley (Analysts)】
Okay. And for 2015, you've given a suggestion of the pricing headwind as well. I'm assuming mix is, perhaps, positive on the opposite side of that, again, so potentially the net of price mix from raw material is, again, to be positive in '15? Is that a fair assumption?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
No, this I will not confirm. The price mix, again, price minus raw mix, we do see an increase of around 4 -- improvement of 4% in mix, so this I would confirm. But then again, back to what I said before, price 100% P&L relevant, mix only 30%. So there is a negative effect on the P&L. And as our expectation for the year is, basically, balance out, no effect, neither positive nor negative, from raw materials; the net balance of those 3 factors is negative.

---

【質問: Jose Asumendi (Analysts)】
Jose, JPMorgan. On order intake, could you talk a bit about the timeline between orders and sales? And does it differ by division? And can we expect those sales to hit the order level the latest by '18? And second element, is it fair to assume the profitability of your Asian contracts is at least 2% higher than the average of the division? And could you share the share of the -- your Asian revenues across Chassis, Powertrain and Interiors? And I've got 2 follow-ups as well.

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, order intake, normally 3 to 4 years until it materializes in our books; in some divisions, even longer. There are some orders which materialize already in the next year, but this is very few percentage of the order intake which we see. The profitability in Asia is basically in line with our profitability in the rest of the world. And the reason behind that is quite straightforward. Many of our customers in Asia, specifically in China, are those customers which we know from Europe and from the U.S. and from Japan. It is the international OEs and they, I mean, have their own purchasing department which makes sure they know our cost base in Europe, they know our cost base in the U.S. and in China, that we don't earn higher margins, which they would feel is unfair in those countries, than we do have them in Europe and the U.S. The Asia sales share is mentioned actually, I didn't comment on that. It's mentioned actually on the Page 17 of our presentation, for each division as well. Within the circle, you can see Chassis & Safety at 30%, sales share in Asia Powertrain 25%, Interior 22%. And in addition, our new Fact Book is available online at least now -- or in the afternoon. And there, you'll get the numbers, the newest numbers, not only for Asia, but for the sales pick-up of the divisions all over the world.

---

【質問: Jose Asumendi (Analysts)】
Perfect. And another 2, please. On Chassis & Safety, can you please comment what is the contribution from Honda on revenues and the -- on profits, please? And then on Interiors, how can you accelerate the order intake to make it sort of match the level of Chassis & Safety and Powertrain? Is it a question of product, of account management, I don't know, of competitors? Can you give us some insight there, please?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, Honda was EUR 500 million in 2014, expected to double until 2016 and breakeven, which was won in 2014. So I think we are on this path as expected, as this is a very, very high fixed cost business. And the second question, if I understood that right, could we accelerate the order intake in the Interior division? Well, 2 answers to that. On the one hand side, Interior includes all the aftermarket business of our Automotive divisions. And as you know, the aftermarket doesn't have this lifetime order intake. This is always, you sell to dealers. So this, on average, lowers the growth rate and the order intake shown in Interior relative to the sales of Interior. And secondly, I mean, this is depending as well on the orders -- big orders which might be on the market or are not on the market, and so this is why orders on the market might differ from one year to another, though it is already a big market. And by that, there are some natural changes from year-over-year just due to the fact what is available on the market and what is not available on the market.

---

【質問: Philippe Barrier (Analysts)】
Philippe Barrier, Societe Generale. Two questions. Just the first question on the active safety. I would like to know when the Chassis & Safety division can go over the 10% operating margin, assuming that the active safety systems could really become profitable in the coming years? How many years to go about 10% for this division? And when should the active safety system get a decent level of margin? This is the first question. And second question is regarding the tire business. With integration of distribution network, it seems that the company is coming back to the -- its own distribution network. It could be a drag in term of profitability. Actually, does this distribution network could -- can negatively affect the operating margin in 2015? And what should be impact -- what should be the impact in terms of profitability for the tire business, assuming the margin now is 19%, actually hit a drag, which may prevent the division to go over the 20% operating margin again?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Our Chassis & Safety midterm target is 10%, and -- but I think what you are indirectly assuming, and your question is right, that the -- this is depending on the growth of the advanced driver assistance system businesses and orders which are in there and the future growth will help as it is a fixed cost business to get the margin up towards the 10%. The additional distribution channels are not in such a magnitude that they are having a big drag on the profitability margin of our tire division. And your assumption that we should go above 20% in 2015, and this is not possible because of additional distribution channels, is not correct.

---

【質問: Philippe Barrier (Analysts)】
Okay. And just for a question on tires regarding LatAm operation. So you have a plant which was would it be recent [ph]. Today, what is your level of utilization of the plant in Brazil? And what should be the impact of declining market for Continental, specifically in Brazil?

---

【回答: Wolfgang Schafer (Executives)】
Well, the utilization of our factories in Brazil is low. We are in a restructuring process. We've already had layoffs significantly in our white- and blue-collar people. We closed down by other reasons, so we closed down a factory in Manaus last year, and this process is not coming to an end at the moment, as we see as well and notice additional competition moving into the market. Sales, our sales share to Latin America is about 3% to 4% of our total sales. In that area, we are no longer profitable at the moment. This is why the restructuring is on its way. So it has some drag on the profitability of the overall of the Automotive business. But thanks to the fact that it is not such a big part, the effect is limited.

---

【回答: Rolf Woller (Executives)】
Thank you very much. With this, then, we thank you for the very interesting Q&A session. If there are any follow-ups, as mentioned, please don't hesitate to contact the IR team; I am Rolf Woller. And talk to you next time, which will be on May 7, on the occasion of the release of the first quarter results. Thanks a lot.

4617859.eventHeadline: Deutsche Post AG, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 11, 2015
4617859.transcript_text1:
Thank you, and good afternoon or good morning, wherever you are to the investor conference call on the full year 2014 results of Deutsche Post DHL group. I take it you have got the material that you could download or find on the app in front of you. And we have, as announced, the group's CEO, Frank Appel, with us as well as the group's CFO, Larry Rosen. I will hand over to them for the presentations. Afterwards, as usual, sufficient time for Q&A. And with that, I'd like to hand over to you, Frank.

---

Hello from our side as well, and thank you for joining us today on our 2014 numbers. Let me go straight away into the summary, which is on Page 3 of the document. I think that summarized quite well where we ended up in 2014. We -- I think 2014 was a preparation year and a good step in the right direction. Express actually has performed pretty well with them EBIT -- 10% EBIT margins, which we had for years, achieved 1 year early than originally planned. I think that's great. You see also strong growth in the PeP division for parcels and a very moderate decline, which is actually less than what we originally guided years ago with 2% to 3% decline and it was again -- it was better in mail. We have our challenges with our cost position, particularly with the salary level. You might have followed that we have done something. I'll come to that later on as well but that has, of course, had impact on our EBIT numbers here as well. The transformation in DGF with the NFE program is a key priority and will remain a key priority. In summary, here, it appears to be more challenging when we expect it, but I believe we are taking the right actions to get it back on track. 
Supply Chain. We are pretty pleased with the new strategy where we guided you that we will make mid-term 4% to 5% margins. We improved it. John Gilbert and his team have taken first actions. Okay. So that -- in terms of the group net interest I think for this year was around EUR 390 million on the P&L. Can we assume, all else equal, that, that can come down a little bit in reported terms in '15?

I think that would be a pretty good estimate of what the likely direction is.

Two for me, actually. One on the free cash flow guidance. I can see that you're guiding for free cash flow covering the dividend payout, that would be EUR 1 billion. Yes. So we'll maybe take the second question first. Okay, and maybe just one follow-up, I mean, given that your earnings are still increasing this year into your free cash flow guidance, as for a decline in free cash flow, that indicates that EBIT cash conversion is deteriorating and I think that cannot just be because of the slightly higher CapEx?

Well, we have not forecast declining free cash flow. We've only neglected to make it more precise other than to say we think it'll be more free cash flow generation that we need to cover the dividend. So we've had -- we haven't said that it will be less than last year.

Okay. Well, thank you again. Now listen, to keeping in mind that busy schedule that we all have on a day like today, we have to come to an end with the Q&A session here. As always and with great pleasure, the IR team is looking forward to further talks and discussions with you out there. And with that, I'd like to hand over for closing remarks to Frank please.

Yes, thank you for all your questions. We are convinced that we had a good year last year, and we kept our promises another year and delivered good results, which are a good base for the transition from what we call the first S curve of our strategy 2015 to the next S curve for 2020. 2015 will be a year where we change quite a lot, I think, in many parts. 【回答: Frank Appel (Executives)】
Yes. Let me take that question. So I think we are not ready yet to give you a more detailed outlook. 【質問: Damian Brewer (Analysts)】
2 questions for me. First of all, on the Express business. 【回答: Frank Appel (Executives)】
Yes, so let me answer with regard to the -- where we are with Express. I think we made great progress and the majority of all these things are done. The story never ends, to be honest. And I'm now on the IT board for all 3 years, I'm sharing that. And if you talk about IT, that story never ends. We -- Ken and his team is looking already to upgrading our functionality with many dimensions, be it billing or functionalities for digital features and so on and so forth. So I think, as we originally outlined, that is almost completed, and we are already -- and they are working already to upgrade our capabilities further, which is, of course, related to -- there is more international B2C and we have to find new answers. If I understand TNT's strategy, they want more focus on road anyway, which is not our core in Express. In Supply Chain, as I said, we have won almost half the business of the next competitors, while going through that, I think our key target has to be, we win on a standardized scalable operation, and we see that in some markets. 【回答: Lawrence Rosen (Executives)】

I have 2 questions. One on the guidance regarding FX effects. So the guidance for 2015 is based on what kind of U.S. dollar-euro relation, on the backdrop of the currently very depressed euro?
