In terms of -- if we see the entire March, and I know that's a really detailed one, but March has one less weekend this year, if I'm not wrong, versus the previous year. Don't you think that this will have a calendar impact because I heard you saying that you want to see on a 3-quarter -- on a 3-month basis sales, but you haven't mentioned any calendar impact and you haven't quantified, which you usually do. So I wonder whether do you think that there is a calendar impact for March.

---

【回答: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)】
Yes, for the full March, as you say, there is a negative calendar effect estimated to 2% or to 3%. So that's a negative calendar effect.

---

【質問: Chris Chaviaras (Analysts)】
I see, but there isn't one from the 1st until the 21st, right.

---

【回答: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)】
No, there is no calendar effect. There is 3 Saturdays, 3 comparable days for each weekday. So there is no calendar effect in that figure.

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
We can hear you very poorly, by the way. Gentlemen, I'd like to ask you a question on the online rollout. Obviously, we noticed quite a substantial increase in local currency sales in markets like the U.S. but also in Italy and a few other prominent markets where you've just recently rolled out new channel sales. Could you educate us a bit on the impact on those markets from new channel sales, please.

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Yes. We are very happy, again, with the online development but also with the store development. It's a combination of both online and offline.

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
Yes. And I also understand you've been rolling out various software systems and changed the -- made a few changes to the product offering versus customers enabling in some markets a more seamless customer experience with returns possible in physical stores, et cetera. How has that rolled out? And is there any early indications of the impact on bottom line, please.

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Again, this is the reason why we invest so much in online and IT. It's not just expansion of the online store to more markets. It's also, as we'd elaborated many times now, the improvement of the existing stores and to take it to even further level, so to speak, and in terms of greater offering, wider offering, better navigation and seamless features as we discussed before. So developing very well, but we take it step-by-step and very promising.

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
And final question, if I may. Can I just say, I guess, there are 3 main sort of possibilities to counteract the increasing sourcing costs ahead: changes to price points; changes to mix and categories; and buying cheaper goods. Do you think -- is there anything of this that you've been discussing in particular or -- and/or are there any other options available for you at your discretion, please.

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
As we discussed before, the number of things we work on, of course, we work very hard, but we don't compromise with the quality, of course. But having said that, it's of course very difficult to offset the magnitude of the sharp U.S. dollar increase.

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
And finally, in terms of price position in the market, you said you're monitoring closely your competitors. Are you referring to your absolute position or your relative position in the marketplace?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
It's both, of course, and this is done on a continuous basis, not just right now when the dollar is changing rapidly.

---

【質問: Unknown Analyst (Analysts)】
I just wanted to, Nils, to elaborate on this -- looking at the 3 months together, the March, April, May numbers, you said it's a recurring thing every year. Is it because of the change of season or because the weather is so dodgy worldwide? What's the reason why we need to take those 3 months all together?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
It's very simple. As I said, the timing of when the spring arrives in each market varies a lot and also the timing of the different Easter and holidays makes a big, huge impact on the monthly sales numbers. Just look at our historical monthly sales numbers. You will see very volatile numbers.

---

【質問: Unknown Analyst (Analysts)】
Okay. And that's every year, that's recurring every year?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【質問: Richard Jaffe (Analysts)】
Just a question on what's happening in Asia and Europe and the apparent margin erosion there. If you could address what that -- what might be -- that might be based in the specific causes for the operating margin erosion?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Are you referring to the segment report? Again, this is as a result of our transfer pricing policy timings. You can't draw too many conclusions on a quarterly basis, I'm sorry.

---

【質問: Simon Bowler (Analysts)】
Apologies in advance. I think, I might have just missed a comment early. Just wanted to clarify. Did you or ostensibly could you if not quantify the impact on your inventory balance from the U.S. dollar appreciation, which -- implied earlier was a significant reason for the increase that we're seeing now?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Of course, there's a significant dollar impact, but we choose not to quantify it, no.

---

【質問: Andrew Hughes (Analysts)】
Just a question, going back to the big move in FX, so we're seeing as a sort of 20% or so move in the dollar versus the euro. How does that compare with the situation a few years ago when the cotton price had trebled? Is it the same sort of magnitude in terms of what it does to your effective -- to your bought-in prices?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
It's difficult to say because, of course, there are similarities, but there are also big differences. And I think the company is different and the world looks different.

---

【質問: Andrew Hughes (Analysts)】
Yes. So your response on, say, external factors may be different. But in terms of the quantum, is it possible to sort of compare the 2 together?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
No, not really, I think. I see where you're heading, but I think it's important to look at history and learn from that. But again, there are always some other tweaks and again different environment today than it was 4 or 5 years ago.

---

【質問: Andrew Hughes (Analysts)】
Yes. I mean, by different environment, do you mean that obviously we're in the middle of a financial crisis at that point and we're not now. Or is there anything else that's changed?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
A lot of -- most things have changed, I would say. We have a different exposure to different markets. We are larger, et cetera. But what I could say is the same is, of course, our long-term commitment and always to have the best offering in each market.

---

【質問: Andrew Hughes (Analysts)】
Do you think with the change in your geographical exposure, your markets are more competitive now than they were 4 or 5 years ago?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
In a way, you could say by definition. The competition is always getting worse because everyone tries to improve things. But at the same time, in some markets, there might be softer competition because a lot of competitors have left the market, et cetera. But of course, for us, it's always about improving things and strengthening our offering and being long term.

---

【質問: Rebecca McClellan (Analysts)】
I've just got one follow-up question, please, on the sourcing model. I know that you've got significant volumes out and sourced up the Far East. If the dollar sort of stays where it is over the medium term, is there any sort of prospect of you bringing some of your sourcing back close to home back into the European basin or anything?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
I mean, there is always a lot of development going on in sourcing, meaning also shifting from different markets. But again, with the balance we have, you can't just jump back and forth. But this is something we continuously look at. And we -- since we grow so much, we also continuously have to add new markets and new suppliers. So that's why we're looking at sourcing in Africa, for example, in Burma, et cetera. But of course, we still source almost 20% of the volumes in Europe, which of course is very interesting for proximity and speed.

---

【質問: Rebecca McClellan (Analysts)】
And are you seeing any sort of pressure on European sourcing costs or opportunity costs because of perhaps a geographical shift away from the dollar-denominated sourcing?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Sorry, say again the question, please.

---

【質問: Rebecca McClellan (Analysts)】
Is there any sort of shift away -- is there any pressure on European-based opportunic costs because of the competitors might be shifting away from the -- from Asia, for example?

---

【回答: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)】
Yes, it might be for a lot of the players are moving and sourcing to Europe, of course, then it's of course maybe causing capacity limitations, et cetera, which could affect the price. But we haven't seen that at the moment, but of course, it might be in the future, the situation if more and more sourcing are moved to Europe.

---

【質問: Paul Rossington (Analysts)】
Can you just remind us of the actual mechanism by which you hedge out your U.S. dollar exposure on sourcing?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Right. It's very simple, and we do it continuously, meaning that each order or every day when we place new orders, we hedge the exposures until we pay the suppliers, to say in a simple way, meaning that the -- as I said before, the lag between time of the -- when you place the order until you see the effect coming through in the figures, and the P&L, et cetera, is roughly 2 quarters. And this is done continuously no matter if the dollar is weak or strong.

---

【質問: Paul Rossington (Analysts)】
I think of one more -- one last question. You've opened fewer stores in Q1 this year versus Q1 last year. Was that by design or just more a question of availability of new space?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
It's more a timing issue. But again, our target for the year of approximately 400 new stores remain.

---

【質問: Paul Steegers (Analysts)】
Just to follow up, given the interest rates in Sweden are in negative territory, Central Bank. I mean, does that make you think any differently about your balance sheet and your cash balances going forward? I'm aware, obviously, of cash across your different geographies. But generally, anything we should be thinking about in terms of the cash on the balance sheet and the payout ratios or dividend? Or I think will it broadly remain as it was before?

---

【回答: Jyrki Tervonen (Executives)】
Yes, when it comes to the cash situation and the interest rates, we often have got the question, do you have too much money laying in the bank accounts? Of course, it's a relevant question, but we are happy with our cash position and the balance we have at the current time. So what's happening in the future, that we will see. But for now, we think we are in a good balance.

---

【質問: Paul Steegers (Analysts)】
Okay. And maybe just one follow-up question on sourcing. Is there any discussions around Chinese suppliers that you could potentially buy in euros going forward, as we've seen in a few other sort of industries? Or is this generally always been U.S. dollar price sourcing and that's the way it'll stay?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Well, of course, we're always open to new ideas. This is something that we've been looking at. But now -- I mean, I think the U.S. dollar is the predominant sourcing currency in Asia.

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
Now we've gone a quarter into the year 2015. I was just wondering, would you actually care to give us a little bit more detailed breakdown of the investment-related extra costs that you actually expect for the full year on a quarterly basis?

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
You mean these incremental long-term investments?

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
Yes, please.

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
I think the message is the same. For the year, we approximately guide SEK 400 million to SEK 600 million, but they could be spread unevenly between the quarter. So sorry, we can't give you any more flavor.

---

【質問: Nicklas Fhärm (Analysts)】
Okay. And then just a nitty-gritty question. You state the number of stores in China at 278 at the end of your fiscal Q1. And according to the most recent set of results for Q4, you had 291 stores in China. So that implies actually 13 stores, 13 fewer stores, which is not in tandem with the report and the tables on Page 12 today. I was just wondering if I'm missing something here.

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
That's because we have broken out Hong Kong.

---

【回答: Nils Vinge (Executives)】
Thank you, all, very much for participating in this conference call and welcome back for the second quarter results on the 25th of June. Goodbye.

6192150.transcript_text1:
Dear, audience, and for those who are present, welcome you all to come to the 2014 result announcement. In the management team, we have our Chairman, Mr. Hao Jian Min; and the CEO of the Group; Vice Chairman, Mr. Xiao Xiao of the Group; CEO, Mr. Chen Yi; Vice Chairman and our Chief Construction Expert, Mr. Luo Liang; and our CFO, Mr. Nip Yun. And first of all, please welcome Mr. Hao to go over the 2014 business review for all of us.

---

Dear, friends, and those audience who are watching this on video, good afternoon. I am very happy that we have this opportunity. After the annual result announcement, we have this opportunity to communicate with our investors. First of all, I would like to thank you, all, for your support to China Overseas, and my report today is mainly -- has mainly the 5 sections and you have that PPT on hand. And I'm going to go over it briefly so that we have more time for Q&A session. First part is our annual results. In 2014, the key profit index continued to grow rapidly on a high basis and our performance has again historic record. And over the year, we have realized a total revenue of HKD 120 billion, a year-on-year rise of 45.5% compared to last year. Net profit attributable to shareholders is HKD 27.68 billion and 20.1% rise. And our core profit has increased by 25.6%, reaching HKD 23.83 billion; basic EPS, HKD 3.39, a rise of 20.1%. And the board recommended a year-end dividend of HKD 0.35, an annual dividend of HKD 0.55, an increase year-on-year of 17%. So the dividend accounts for 18.9% of core profit. I am reading this slowly on purpose so that our audience online could hear it carefully. In 2014, we have maintained the ability of great value creation, and gross profit has increased by 0.2% to 32.7%; net profit, 23.1%; core net profit, 19.9%. If excluding the buyback of social housing and funding -- and funds, the adjusted gross margin is 34.3%. Compared to mid-2014, using the same way, same calculation methods, the method is roughly the same. In the chart below it, it shows the dividend. Here, you can see it shows the revenue and profit of the group, and during this period, the property development revenue is HKD 116.25 billion, which accounts for 96.7% of the total revenue, an increase of 47.9%. And rental income has increased by 38.2% to HKD 1.18 billion. Property investment has realized a profit of HKD 6.03 billion, an increase year-on-year, 43.5%.
On this page, you can see our shareholders equity has risen by 21.2% to HKD 133.33 billion. Net asset book value per share, HKD 16.3, and year-on-year increase of 20.7%. Annual average shareholder return is 22.8%, and we continue to maximize the profit for -- and value creation for the shareholders. By the end of last year, cash on hand is HKD 51.28 billion; long-term liability, HKD 71.99 billion; net gearing ratio, 32.4%. We have continuously realized our target of gearing ratio no higher than 40%, and maintained the healthy level of the financials of the company. 
And during the year, the group has again received good results from S&P, Moody's and Fitch. And during this volatility of Chinese property market, the healthy financials have really helped us to maintain the high recognition from those professional rating agencies. 
In May and in June, we have issued many -- lots of guaranteed notes and totaling USD 2 billion. We have also complete -- acquired the largest club loan in November, totaling HKD 14 billion. And thanks to the confidence and support of the capital market, we were able to maintain the interest rate at a relatively low level. In terms of our financial resources: cash on hand, RMB 85%; Hong Kong dollars, 2.6%; and U.S. dollars, 12.4%, including unused credit facilities, totaling HKD 11.7 billion. We have financial resources available, HKD 62.98 billion. We have enough reserves for our future development. In terms of bonds, we have corporate bond, HKD 48.18 billion, and bank loans, HKD 46.36 billion. Long-term liabilities with more than 1 year, 76.2 years, and debt structure and repayment cycle are all very healthy. 
And now let's go over the business for last year. In 2014, we have realized contracted property sales, HKD 140.8 billion. GFA sold, 9.398 million square meters. By end of December, we still have subscribed property sales, HKD 7.77 billion, and waiting to sign the contracts. I should think that they have been signed by today. You look at it by region, South China has -- Southern China has realized HKD 32.96 billion, which has contributed the greatest portion to the profit of the company. For Hong Kong and Macau, contracted sales, HKD 5.06 billion, and our sales collection rate is 88%, totaling HKD 102.09 billion, and maintaining the leader in the market. 
And now let's look at the completed areas, completed GFA. And in terms of completion, we have -- for the group and our JV projects, we have 51 projects. These are our own projects, and 4 JV products (sic) [projects] and the completed GFA is 10.77 million square meters. By end of December, we have already sold 79.4% of our own project and 90% of the JV projects. 
And this chart shows you pre-sales and bookings. In terms of bookings, including JV projects, we have 7.78 million property bookings, totaling HKD 131.4 billion. By end of December, including JV projects, we still have 4.12 million square meters project for pre-sale waiting to be completed, and totaling HKD 65.3 billion. 
On this chart, you can see the land acquisition for 2014. The whole year, we have entered Jiangdong, Taiyuan. I don't need to explain this, right? You know where they are located, which province. And in Jinan, Qingdao, Guangzhou, Wuxi, Kunming, Xi'an, we have also acquired another 17 plots of land, and total area for development, 9.04 million square meters and totaling RMB 38.28 billion, and the average land cost is around RMB 4,234 per square meters; it's roughly in line with the average land cost for the past 2 years, which has ensured the profitability going forward.
On this chart is our land acquisition by end of 2014. Currently, if you add the 14 cities from China Overseas, Hongyang, and we have business in China across 47 cities, including Hong Kong and Macau. In beginning of 2015, we have purchased 2 plots of land. Area for development, 1.625 million, and the land price is RMB 3.56 billion. On this chart, it shows our property investment. Property investment completed, 1.14 million square meters, and the rentals of mature properties are doing well. Office buildings in the Hong Kong, Beijing and Chengdu, and the Unipark shopping malls in Jinan, rental rate have exceeded 90%, and the rental income have increased to HKD 1.18 billion and year-on-year increase of 38.2%. Last year, we have opened the Unipark shopping malls in Shenyang, and rental rate has also climbed up to 90%. And Unipark shopping malls in Nanjing will open its door this year, and other shopping malls in the developed second-tier cities will gradually start business. With our chain operation, we believe that's the brand and influence of China Overseas will continue to improve. So I believe that, for the first part, it is very similar to your expectation. You would have expected this. 
And this part is something that you always ask me, but I have never really quite responded to your questions recently with regard to asset injection. Today, when we are issuing our result announcement, we have also published the announcement between us and our parent company on asset injection and share subscription, including some acquisition of several real estate projects. And now I'm going to talk to you through this, and there are many -- a few parts. One is the strategic meanings of this transaction for China Overseas. Here, we have listed a few points, some of which might be something that you've already thought about. If there are any things that you feel like we've left out, please tell me. I would like to talk to you about the few points here.
Here, this time after the consolidation, in terms of our resources, we are better distributed between the first, second and third tier cities in China, especially in the first tier cities. And we know that in the past few years, especially in the first tier cities, regardless of how the sales go, the land price is always very high. So for the first tier cities and second tier cities, to continue to acquire land, that will play a very important role in maintaining our leading position in the market. 
Second, in terms of coverage of the regions. With the asset injection, we have 9 cities which are already included so -- which are not included. And it really helps with our countrywide plan and to cover the major economic bouts in the fast developing regions. Well, of course, because, thanks to our brand consolidation, going forward, we could maximize the advantage of our brand, and you could think and imagine how that's going to help us using the same brand. Fourthly, in terms of core competence, because in the past, we've always had very good quality when it comes to cost control and product quality et cetera. Going forward, in those projects, all of these qualities will be exempted again, so it is worth expecting, it is worth waiting for. And finally, this is something that I'm eager to share with you. In the past, I feel that when I was talking to you, perhaps, people didn't really quite understand it, but today, I want to share with you what support really means.
In terms of the group support, you can see in the announcement, our parent company will no longer participate in direct sales of property business. And this has avoided the possibility of cannibalization. And again, you can see from these arrangements, COLI as one of the important business arms of our parent company. You can really see how important we are to the parent. So based on these reasons mentioned above, I believe that this is a great strategy. Just now, I said if you feel like there's anything that I missed out, please feel free and do tell me about it.
And now let's look at the structure of the deal and consideration, and the deal is -- includes 2 parts, asset injection and shares subscription. And asset injection, the total consideration is RMB 1.82 billion, and in terms of the CSCL loans, it amounts to RMB 31.99 billion, and COHL, the parent company, will subscribe to 1.687 billion new shares and at the price of RMB 28.38 price per share. Compared to the market closing price of yesterday, there is -- and this is 10.8% higher than the market closing price of yesterday, and compared to the average market closing price, 10 trading days prior to the announcement of this deal, this is 15.2% higher. This time, the asset injection includes 30 projects, and the total consideration in the CSCL loan is RMB 33.82 billion, and because I worry about some of the differences when it comes to exchange rate, so everything is calculate -- denominated in RMB. And the total GFA is 10.92 million square meters located in Beijing, Shanghai, Tianjin, Chongqing, Suzhou, Chengdu, Xi'an, Urumqi, Changsha, Weifang, Zibo and London. Compared to our cities disclosed in the past, the 24 cities, some of them are different, and the total consideration in the CSCL loan is RMB 33.82 billion, and there's one figure I could tell you here. I didn't tell this to the media. For all these asset, our original investment is RMB 31.11 billion. You should understand what I mean here, right? 
Moving on to the transactions timeline. Today, we have made the announcement. We predict no later than 17th April, we will dispatch the circular. Well, these are all expected time schedule, so this is just for your reference. And roughly in line with this, I hold myself responsible for everything I say, but I must tell you that this is an estimated timeline. May 5, we will have a General Meeting, and we expect by end of May, this acquisition would be completed.
Next page. These are reasons for completing the deal and benefits that brings us. Perhaps, I should not talk about benefits myself. Perhaps, it is up to you to talk about it, and a few points I would like to share with you here. First, our parent company have completed their consolidation of direct sale -- of their direct sales property industry, and they have confirmed that COLI has the most important real estate business platform, and has eliminated the potential competition between China Overseas, COLI and the parent company. On the other hand, the parent company, as a SOE with great reputation when it comes to property and construction, they have always been giving us great support. After the deal, the parent will continue to give support to us in terms of human resources, financials, financing, business resources and business network, et cetera. When I'm saying this, you should have seen that our parent company have said that they will exit the direct sales of real estate business, and today's A-shares market is completely different from 2 years -- from a few years ago. For a company with a potential of -- a value of RMB 200 billion, where is it going to go? It is worth waiting to see. Second, the deal will complement the land acquisition for COLI. After the deal, our land acquisition have increased by 29.1%, reaching 48.3 million square meters. The land acquisition here does not include our own land development for 2015. 
And thirdly, the asset injection will bring new impetus for growth for COLI, and in the asset package, there are different -- there are sales property -- property for sales in different phases waiting to be built during construction and small -- and a small portion of investment property. Upon completion of the deal, we believe that this will contribute positively to our contract sales, cash flow, profit growth and income, and these words are said by the lawyers. I am not allowed to say this. I would be able to put it in a more lively fashion, but I'm not allowed to say that, so please just go by the lawyers words. 
And finally, I would like to tell you that the asset being injected is net cash. And after the deal's completion, the equity foundation will be more solid, and our capital structure will be further improved. Our financials are so healthy that they cannot be further improved. I cannot release specific figures to you. I estimate that even including the Hong Kong, Macau companies, you will not be able to find the companies with better financials than us. On this chart, you can see that the distribution of the asset across China and London, and total GFA is 10.92 million square meters.
Moving on, I don't know if you are interested in this market analysis. If you're not, I can jump this. Should we vote, those who think we should jump the market analysis? Not half of the audience here. So maybe I'll just read it out. So apologies to those who have put up their hand. Just a very simple analysis, a very simple report. I believe, as you have all studied this closely yourselves, and I'm just going to share with you some of the informations that we have. And here, we have outlook on the Chinese macroeconomic situation, and there's one point that I believe that I should share with you. Despite for 2015, the GDP growth target is only 7%, same as when Premier Li were answering the questions. For our country, our GDP growth, even if we have slowed down to 7%, this is already the total aggregate of many other countries. So under this fast speed and the high basis, high benchmark of the current Chinese economy, and we're still able to maintain a relatively high growth, and we are very confident about the future of China's economy, and especially for the new employment being created, which is over 10 million positions, and so that would make sure that -- I'm sure that, that will bring more stable structural demand for the property industry. 
And here is our market liquidity, and I'm not going to go into details, and here, we have some property outlook. I'm not going to read out it word by word, but I believe that it is still worth reading when you have time. And when it comes to the policy level, what I'm about to say, it is not included on the PPT. I just want to share with you. We believe that the market will become more market-driven in the next few years. And in the past, we normally say that the government will control the government and the market will control the market, and you know that in the past and the Chinese economy and the property market have always been affected by policies, et cetera. Going forward, as one of the most important growth sector, which is the -- which belongs to the consumption as an important index for growth for the Chinese economy, I believe that there is still hope in this market. Second, on the market's demand, it is changing structurally. The property market has also entered into a new normal. In the past, we talk about different demands. For example, structural demand, investment demand, et cetera, and upgrading demand, but actually, the concepts, they are very blurred. 
What is the project that has really met the structural demand of the consumers? Not many people have studied this. And once that comes out, this will change the market dramatically. And I would like also to say that, going forward, we will be doing very well in terms of getting rid of the inventory. I remember that, in February, across the nation, we still have 600-million-something square meters to be sold, waiting to be sold. And this figure is the figure that we have achieved in 2014, which is a relatively low year for property transactions. So I believe that in the next 1 year to 15 months during this period, these areas will be digested by the market. But I need to tell you in which areas we will be able to get rid of more inventories, and which areas it won't be so successful. So I would like to say that there will be a more clear division between the urban areas and the rural areas in China. This is really affected by many different factors, not only just about the growth of the economy and the population. If you do not study these relevant indexes carefully, there is still a lot of risk when it comes to investing in the Chinese property market.

6267359.transcript_text1:
Okay. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for joining us. We will do this as we normally do. For those who are familiar with us, we'll have a presentation first and then we'll have a question-and-answer time later. 
Let me just quickly say, for the Q&A, we will ask you all to wait for the microphones because we'll have a simultaneous interpretation. You may ask questions in English, Cantonese or Mandarin. Again, please do wait for the mic to come so the translator can hear what you're asking. And we also ask you just to help us keep track and know who's interested, who's coming, to give your name and organization when you put your question. 
I think without further ado, let me ask and invite Charles to come forward with the presentation.

---

Thank you very much for attending our earnings announcement today. I will very quickly make a broad introduction, and then Paul will walk you through our financials, and then I'll come back and touch on some of the strategic issues, but at the end mostly is really Q&As for all of you.
Okay, this -- something is wrong here. Can you figure that out? Okay, great. I think -- this one doesn't work either. Okay. You got it? Perfect, yes. 
Very quickly, on the overall key achievement of 2014, both financial and otherwise. Our revenue and other income up 13%, mainly driven by increasing ADT and also related revenue increases. A record fund-raising year. This is really -- we're second globally in IPOs. I think this is even in the absence of some of the real big, large transactions. And we raised over HKD 900 million. This is a truly a record. 
Successfully launched the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect. Enhancement are now being implemented as we speak. 
LME commercialization in very, very solid and good progress. LME Clear launched, and with about 1/4 of operations this year. And overall ADT and LME hit a record high as well. 
Introduced a 3 London Metal Exchange mini contracts in Asia. And this is really the first step for us to build out the commodity -- overall, the commodity win of LME.
This is really just a very quick breakdown on cash equity, derivative market and commodities. As you can see, volume has been growing quite solidly, both in the cash market and derivative market. I think if you look at the LME commodity product, the red, looks like this is the 700,000 vis-a-vis 676,000 is a very solid increase. The first quarter and actually the first couple of months still continued to saw very strong growth. You see the red, it seems to be dipping a little bit. That's actually is a little bit misleading. The number 2014 is the whole year number and the 696,000 is year-to-date, including a very big Chinese New Year holiday. Usually that's a slow time for LME. If you compare same period against the last period, LME is actually up more than close to 70%, 80% in terms of volume. 
So very strong cash market ADT increase last year. Derivatives increased -- ADT increased 8%, commodity 4%, very solid year. And also, Paul will also walk you through on the financials, clearly indicating not only revenue is up, our revenue is up, outpacing ADT. And also partially, obviously as a result of a decrease in the trend of increase of the trend -- the growth of cost is smaller than -- significantly smaller than the growth of revenue. So as a result, we see very strong overall financial performance for 2014.
And I will ask Paul to give you highlights of the year on financials first. Paul?

---

Thank you, Charles. 
Well, the first thing is that I'm extremely pleased to stand here with such a great set of results. We nearly hit $10 billion, which would have been the first time. This is the highest income we've ever earned. Going back to 2007, we came close. But $9.8 billion, heading to $10 billion, and I'm sure we're going to beat that next year. 
Across the whole slide here, I think it's a set of positive results. Trading volumes and revenue have obviously increased, but we had a particularly strong fourth quarter, really following the more positive sentiment in the Mainland. And also following the positive sentiment generated by the announcement of Stock Connect in November, we had a significant increase in ADT and activity generally. We had the 11 trading days where we hit over 100 billion a day, which we haven't seen for quite some time.
So revenue significantly up 13%. It's 28% higher than the fourth quarter of 2013. A number of factors have really driven growth this year. And our results whilst I believe they're good, I don't think they're controversial. They pretty much follow what we have seen in terms of activities of the group. 
We launched LME Clear in 22nd of September, a really significant turning point for us. We've been building that system for a couple of years, and we've now had 1 quarter's revenue contribute to our earnings, and that's seen a clear jump. That added close to $200 million, $187 million of clearing income, trading income.
We also had a record capital raising year, an absolute record, $943 billion. We were second in the IPO market, but the secondary capital raising took us to a new record. And that's flowed through into our listing-related income and the income that's related to that, the IPO income and the brokerage income that's related to those new issues. That in total contributed around $100 million. 
We've also seen an improvement in the interest rate environment this year. We've seen an average increase in the margin fees we've earned. And overall, looking at the Hong Kong investment of those funds, we've made about $180 million more. 
In LME, there's been some investment income, but that tends to relate to gains on the holding of LCH, which is separately reported throughout our results. 
The increase in ADT was felt across the piece. It's felt in the trading income, in the clearing income. And it has a spin off effect in other income like depository fees, especially in the fourth quarter. So our ADT was up by 11%, but overall, our trading and clearing fees were up by a higher percentage. 
Depository fees gone up by around $100 million and platform and infrastructure sales also by $100 million. And I think the importance of some of these numbers and the reason for giving you some of this breakdown is that the increase in our income this year, 45% of that increase came from nontrading activities, which I think is a particularly good result.
As we look at costs, operating expenses, these are under control. They've gone up by 7%. The number is slightly flatted by the fact that we had a recovery of amounts due from Lehman of $77 million this year. But net-net, considering that we were still building out LME Clear, LME is still going through a retooling process, and we're continuing to make investments. A 7% growth in operating costs in this year, I think, is a solid result. And as a consequence of revenue exceeding that, we see, flowing across the page significant increases in EBITDA and profit attributable to shareholders. And I think it's also important to note this year that the value given back to shareholders comes not just through the earnings per share, but by the fact that our share price has also gone up by 33%.
This is just a breakdown of the revenue and income as shown in our financial statements. I don't want to dwell on this too much. The trading fees obviously come primarily off the ADT. Just to note that the cash equity business was stronger than the 7%. The derivative business was rather flat. That's due to the mix. Even though we had record volumes in the derivative business in terms of the number of trades, the mix was on the lower fee side. Basically, the options grew faster than the futures. 
Listing fees, I think it's obvious from the volumes. Clearing and settlement fees off the ADT, the higher volumes were also with that contribution of $187 million from LME Clear.

6777450.eventHeadline: Sasol Ltd., H1 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 09, 2015
6777450.transcript_text1:
Thanks very much, operator, and good day, everyone. Thank you for joining us for our interim results conference call today. Joining me here in Johannesburg from Sasol are Bongani Nqwababa, our new Chief Financial Officer, who started at Sasol on March 1. A warm welcome to Bongani. Also on the call is Paul Victor, who has been an outstanding and extremely dedicated acting Chief Financial Officer, who will support me on today's call. We also have with us other members of the Sasol group executive committee, who will support us and respond to any questions you may have.
As you would have seen, today, we announced a resilient group-wide performance, notwithstanding an extremely tough macroeconomic environment, despite the implementation of a major corporate restructuring, our colleagues throughout the world have maintained their focus on safety, volume growth, increased sales in key strategic projects.
Turning to Slide 4 in the pack. We'll cover the following key messages today: I'll begin by providing you with a high-level overview of how our optimized operating model is providing Sasol a solid platform to weather even the most severe of storms; next, we'll spend some time reviewing our key performance achievements during the first half of the 2015 financial year; I'll then provide you with an update on one of our most important initiatives, our Business Performance Enhancement Program. 
Of course, it's clear that the current crude oil price presents challenging times for us. Instrumental to our ability to ride out the storm and maintain our momentum is our response to the low oil price environment.
In December, the management team launched our oil price Response Plan. Today, we'll update you on the cash conservation levers we are actioning as part of this plan. Paul will then go into more detail on our financial and operational performance.
Before wrapping up, I'll talk you through the advancements we've been making on our dual regional strategic, primarily focusing on our Lake Charles Chemicals Project in the U.S. And we'll conclude this morning's session by recapping how Sasol continues to create value by proactively prioritizing our business activities.
Moving on to slide 5. On July 1, we implemented a completely revamped operating model. 8 months down the track, we definitely see us gaining traction and delivering results. Our new operating model aligns operating business units, regional operating hubs, strategic business units and group functions into an integrated value chain, producing liquid fuels, high-value chemicals and low carbon electricity.
Having implemented our new model at the start of this financial year, we also updated our financial reporting according to the new reportable segments. This slide summarizes the key operating model benefits, which you will be familiar with so I will not go into any further detail here. 
However, one important takeaway is that through our internal consolidation and rightsizing, we've radically streamlined our management layers. In fact, since 2013, we have reduced our top management layer by 61%. This reduction was brought about by more efficient reporting lines and by maximizing economies of scale.
Next is Slide 6. And looking at our interim results, we have solid contributions across the value chain. In addition, our group safety recordable case rate, excluding illnesses, improved to 0.32, down appreciably from 0.36 at the start of the financial year. 
Turning to our sales volumes. Performance chemicals were up 5%, base chemicals normalized sales volumes were up 1%, and liquid fuels sales in our energy business in Southern Africa were up 3%. Through determined management action, our normalized cash fixed costs have continued trend below inflation at 6.1% versus the South African PPI of 6.8% for the half year. 
Over the period, headline earnings per share were up 6% to ZAR 32 per share and earnings per share increased by 53% to ZAR 32.04. The half year had a number once-off items which, for the most part, impacted our performance positively and Paul will explain the items further in just a few minutes. 
With significantly lower oil prices, the management team and the board revisited our group's dividend policy. Last month, we moved away from a progressive dividend to a dividend cover range based on headline earnings per share. As a result, the company has declared an interim dividend of ZAR 7 per share for the first half of FY '15, not dissimilar to last year's record interim dividend of ZAR 8 per share.
Turning to Slide 7. In the context of our large-scale change program, which commenced in 2011, we refined our corporate strategy, streamlined our management structures, we adapted our systems and processes and drove a comprehensive Business Performance Enhancement Program. Today, as we navigate our way through a challenging global reality, it's reassuring to know that at Sasol we have been fixing the roof while the sun was shining. As a result and with our company redesign fully implemented, we are much better equipped to deal with any challenge.
Looking at some of the specific details of our enhancement program. By December 31, we'd signed off on approximately 1,500 employment separations, either through voluntary retrenchments or early retirements; we implemented a group-wide vacancy freeze and a hiring moratorium, which today are both delivering additional benefits to our cost optimization endeavors.
As a result of our intensified efforts, we have increased our program target from at least ZAR 4 billion in annual savings to ZAR 4.3 billion at the end of FY '16. If we look at our sustainable savings to date, we are sitting at ZAR 1 billion annually with restructuring charges of approximately ZAR 1.5 billion. However, in the context of a lower-for-longer oil scenario, our change program efforts, although significant, are not sufficient. If we consider the views of external experts and the prevailing market sentiment, far more has to be done. 
Turning next to the graph on Slide 8. Over the past several months, we've seen a sharp decline in the average Brent crude oil price. This has had a severe knock-on effect on everyone in or affiliated with the oil industry. Forecasting the oil price trajectory remains challenging as the market is still in the process of determining a new short-term equilibrium price. Equally difficult is predicting when supply and demand will become more balanced, in parallel, storage constraints and geopolitical tensions must also be considered.
What we know for certain is that current oil prices are too low to sustain drilling programs or to provide incentives for new upstream investments. Companies within this sector is substantially reducing their capital requirements and cutting exploration budgets.
As is the case with our industry peers, we too are hampered by what many external experts expect to be a lower-for-longer oil scenario, until at least mid-2016. In the longer term, the rebalancing of the supply-demand market will require additional volumes to replace global oil production declines coupled with demand growth. This is evident from the oval shading in the graph, which indicates the recovery to $80 dollars per barrel in FY '17. So today's outlook is quite different to how we viewed the world only a few months ago. As a result, in December 2014, we proactively formulated a comprehensive plan to protect cash in response to these oil-price uncertainties. 
Moving on to slide 9 come, having done considerable legwork, our Response Plan caters for a cash conservation target range of between ZAR 30 billion to ZAR 50 billion over the next 30 months. In all the activities we are working on to protect cash, safe, reliable and efficient operations remain non-negotiable for us. Response Plan has flexible levers so that we can respond to the volatile macroeconomic environment, while optimizing our ultimate profitability over the long term.
The cash conservation levers we have formulated under the Response Plan are over and above the Business Performance Enhancement Program savings targets. And while our Response Plan protects cash over a relatively short period, the next 2.5 years, several initiatives we are actioning will also result in longer-term cost savings. Here based on our current analysis, we're looking at an additional ZAR 1 billion in annual sustainable savings from FY '18.
Next to Slide 10. Several core levers underpin our 30-month Response Plan. These levers are summarized on the screen, on your slide, reflecting the individual ranges which equate to the ZAR 30 billion to ZAR 50 billion cumulative target. 
Looking at each of the levers in more detail. Turning first to cash cost savings. Here we've identified an extensive list of activities which will deliver ZAR 4 billion to ZAR 7 billion. These activities include corporate policies relating to remuneration, travel, entertainment, professional services and a broad category of discretionary spend items. And further optimizing our top and senior management layers of the company, we are looking at reducing our headcount by another 200 senior management personnel. 
Next, with a target of ZAR 5 billion to ZAR 9 billion through our gross margin and working capital lever, we are driving margin and efficiency improvements, we're also optimizing our account receivable balances and inventory on hand. Turning to the capital structuring, as mentioned earlier, our board confirmed a change in our dividend policy based on our cover range. We're also considering other opportunities in this area, which has allowed us to set a target range of ZAR 8 billion to ZAR 12 billion. 
To our final lever, in January, we announced that we are rightsizing our capital portfolio, given uncertain external factors. As a result of this exercise, we decided to delay the final investment decision on our gas-to-liquids plant in the U.S.A. We're also reprioritizing our other growth and sustenance capital projects, here our target range is ZAR 13 billion to ZAR 22 billion in the next 30 months.
I'll now hand it over to Paul, who will unpack our results in a little more detail for you. Paul?

---

Thanks, David. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. I'm pleased to present you 2015 half year-end results to you today which are, obviously, in our guided earnings range provided for in our trading [ph] statement. We continued to deliver an overall strong operational and cost performance, despite a highly volatile macroeconomic environment as signaled by the 19% decrease in crude oil prices for the period under review. 
Before moving to the details of the results, I would like to emphasize the following. First, management's continued focus on factors within our control has resulted in a strong operational performance, with overall increased volumes, cost-containment and margin improvement despite a very challenging operating environment. 
Second, we have made significant progress on reducing our cost base through our Business Performance Enhancement Program and have increased the target to deliver at least ZAR 4.3 billion in sustainable cost savings by the end of the 2016 financial year. And finally, mitigating the challenges of the low oil price and continuing to deliver maximum sustainable value to our shareholders remains one of our top priorities. 
Moving to Slide 12. The macroeconomic environment driven by the significant decline in crude oil prices remains subdued and uncertain, with tough trading conditions expected to continue in the following 2 years. We are expecting a lower-for-longer oil price environment and as David has indicated, we have taken decisive actions to minimize the impact on our business. The average rand/U.S. dollar exchange rate was 9% weaker, with a 19% lower being crude oil price. Chemical prices and margins, on the other hand, have been much more resilient during the period under review.
The solvents [ph]  business, however, remained sensitive to significant movement in the rand/dollar exchange rate and oil prices and we do remind you about sensitivities to each of these variables. We estimate that the ZAR 0.10 in the annual average rand/U.S. dollar exchange rate and a $1 change in the crude oil price will affect our profits from global operations by approximately ZAR 605 million and ZAR 800 million, respectively.
Moving to Slide 13. As mentioned previously, our new operating model as well as the simplified legal structure came into effect on the 1st of July, 2014. The results presented today reflect a performance of our 6 reportable business segments organized along an integrated value chain. For further details on the new segmental reporting, I refer you to the detailed [indiscernible] announcement as well as the supplementary information, that we publish on our website since November of last year. 
Overall, the group delivered a strong operational performance as result of increased sales volumes and improved margins in our performance chemicals and base chemicals' strategic business units, and increased sales volumes in our energy business unit. Headline earnings per share increased by 6% to ZAR 32 per share. Profit from operations of ZAR 30 billion was up 39%. This increase was positively impacted by once-off items of ZAR 6.8 billion, driven by macroeconomic factors, changes to the share price and our decision to operationalize our 2050 strategy. 
Focusing on our value chain. Our operating business unit delivered an overall strong performance, driven largely by stellar production performance from mining. In our strategic business unit, the energy business unit was impacted by the lower oil price, however, through focused management interventions the business increased liquid sales volumes by 3%, and reported high refining margins on the back of strong product differentials. 
Turning to our international energy portfolio. ORYX GTL delivered a solid operational performance, with an average utilization rate of 91% for the period despite a earlier-than-planned shutdown during December 2014. In our chemicals businesses both improved volumes as well as resilient margins boosted profitability, contributing 44% to the group's profit. 
Moving to Slide 14. The weaker rand/dollar exchange rate increased profitability by 12% and that benefit was however, overshadowed by the lower oil price which adversely affected profit by 20%. Profit from operations increased by 54% as a result of the following once-off items and period-end adjustments: a ZAR 3.7 billion lower share-based payment charge, following a 32% decrease in our share price over the last 6 months; lower depreciation and rehabilitation charges of ZAR 2.5 billion, due to the change in the useful life of our African assets in accordance with our 2050 strategy; and lastly, lower remeasurement items of ZAR 171 million complete through the ZAR 5.7 billion in the prior period, mainly due to the ZAR 5.3 billion Canadian impairment booked during the first half of financial year '14. High depreciation charges in respect of new plants as well as inflation of costs adversely affected profitability by 13%. 
We are pleased to report a 6% increase in the sales volumes across the group. This is on the back of a 7% increase in sales volumes reported for the comparative period. The total increases in sales volumes of 13% over the last 2 years amounts to ZAR 7 billion in real terms.
Moving to slide 15. We are extremely pleased with our continued cost performance. The increase in normalized cash fixed cost have been contained to 0.7%, below the South African producer price inflation of 6.8% for the first half of the 2015 financial year. Our cost savings mindset of driving sustainable cost reduction, in the group, delivered this strong performance, this, despite the cost pressures arriving from the South African cost environment in respect of labor, maintenance and electricity costs. 
In addition, sustainable savings from our Business Performance Enhancement Program for the first 6 months amounted to ZAR 991 million, while cash implementation costs of the Business Performance Enhancement Program as well as growth costs added a further 6.9% savings to the total cash fixed cost.
Overall, we benefited from a weaker rand/dollar exchange rate but the impact of the weaker rand added a further 1.5% to the total cash fixed cost price. Lower maintenance and energy remains the main drivers of cost base, with labor comprising, now approximately, 55% of our total cash fixed cost base.
Our strategy to control energy costs has seen us maintain our electricity generating capacity in South Africa to around 70% of our own requirement. We expect electricity cost inflation to be in the double-digits, again, in the forthcoming financial year.
Finally, cost reduction continues to be one of the critical focus areas for management. And through our Business Performance Enhancement Program and our recently launched Response Plan, we aim to be deriving cost streams in a safe and sustainable manner. 
Moving on to Slide 16. Focusing on our operating business units, minings profit from operations increased by 66%, mainly on the back of a 5% increase in production volumes. The benefits of our Business Performance Enhancement Program coupled with further operations flexibility created by the mine-replacement program, resulted in unit costs from our operations being contained to well below inflation, the first time since 2010. 
Exploration and production in international reported a loss from operations of ZAR 1.7 billion. Our Mozambican operations were positively impacted by favorable gas prices, while volumes remained at similar levels compared to the prior period. We are progressing well with our current programs in Mozambique and further updates will be provided to the markets once confirmed. In Gabon, our assets were under pressure due to the decline in oil prices and the unfortunate selling of wells, which resulted in a partial impairment of ZAR 1.3 billion. In Nigeria, we relinquished our exploration licenses and incurred a loss of ZAR 565 million. 
Our Canadian upstream assets generated a loss from operations of ZAR 584 million, mainly due to the lower gas prices as well as reduced drilling activities. The 91% improvement in a loss from operations was mainly due to the lower depreciation and operational costs as well as a ZAR 5.3 billion impairment recognized in the period, in the prior period. We continue to execute on improved development plan in conjunction with our joint venture partner Progress Energy, and are derisking the assets with specific emphasis on the Cypress A acreage.
Moving to Slide 17. Underpinned by an overall strong production volumes, our energy business delivered a pleasing set of results with Secunda Synfuels and Natref increasing production by 2% and 6%, respectively. Our Southern African energy portfolio was adversely impacted by the increased cost of production as well as reduction in basic fuel prices, which resulted in an 18% lower gross margin. 
Our Business Performance Enhancement Program however, continues to deliver results in all facets of our business, and we expect normalized cash cost per unit for the full year to be below SA PPI. Our ORYX GTL joint venture delivered a solid performance despite the earlier-than-planned shutdown. Our share of the profit from the joint venture decreased ZAR to 1.3 billion, mainly due to the shutdown and the oil prices. The plant achieved 91% utilization rate, which is ahead of the previous guidance provided. 
Moving to Slide 18. We have continued to see an increase in sales volumes and margin resilience in our chemicals business. The base chemicals' SBU delivered a pleasing performance of increasing profit from operations by 42%. Our chemicals basket dollar prices have declined by 5% in comparison with a 19% decline in average Brent crude oil prices. 
However, sales volumes normalized for sale of the Solvents Germany and Middle East polymer marketing operations increased by 1%. This business also benefited from the impact of the extension of the useful life of assets in South Africa, amounting to ZAR 899 million. 
The performance chemicals SBU recorded another exceptional performance, underpinned by consistent and reliable operation delivery and a weaker rand. Profits from operations increased by 60% to ZAR 7.4 billion whilst operating margins expanded by 6% to 19%. Sales volumes increased by 5% due to improved production output on the back of high demand. 
Our U.S. business is still realizing healthy margins despite the decrease in sales prices. Our European operations continued to report improved volumes coupled with resilient margins. In our South African operations, we recognized a partial impairment reversal of ZAR 1.3 billion of the Wax Expansion Project, as a result of the impact of weaker rand exchange rate as well as the decision to extend the useful life of the plant beyond 2029. 
Moving to Slide 19. I would like to extend on what David touched on earlier, in respect of our Business Performance Enhancement Program. We have increased our savings target and now expect to generate sustainable annual savings of at least ZAR 4.3 billion at the end of the 2016 financial year. We have achieved actual year-to-date savings of ZAR 991 million and expect to save ZAR 1.5 billion in savings for the 2015 financial year. This represents an annualized run rate of about ZAR 2.2 billion. 
Project implementation cost of ZAR 1.5 billion were incurred for the 6 months to date and I expect it to peak at approximately ZAR 2.1 billion at the end of our 2015 financial year, before tapering off in the 2016 financial year as the project reaches its final phases of implementation. We then expect cash fixed costs to follow inflation from the 2017 financial year. 
As David mentioned earlier, through our various Response Plan activities, we plan to deliver further sustainable cost savings of ZAR 1 billion as from financial year 2018. This is in addition to the business performance enhancement savings of at least ZAR 4.3 billion by financial year 2016. 
Moving on to Slide 20. Taking various factors into account, including overall market conditions, the group's financial position, capital investment plans as well as earnings growth an interim dividend of ZAR 7 per share has been declared. As part of the capital structuring lever in Response Plan, the management team and the Sasol Board of Directors have evaluated and changed the company's progressive dividend policy.
The revised policy is based on a dividend cover range of a corridor of between 2.2x and 2.8x of headline earnings per share. Our objective, considering the factors mentioned earlier, is to maintain a 40:60 interim to final dividend split. This policy, together with other components of the Response Plan, will provide sufficient flexibility for the company to manage its balance sheet, execute on its growth program, while continue to return maximum sustainable value to our shareholders through dividend payouts.
Moving to Slide 21. Another critical lever of Response Plan is the reprioritization of our capital portfolio. We have revised our 2015 capital expenditure down from ZAR 50 billion to ZAR 45 billion. Our 2016 capital estimate will remain at ZAR 65 billion. This estimate, however, negates a ZAR 4 billion impact of the weakening rand on our capital portfolio. A further ZAR 8 billion to ZAR 13 billion in capital reduction is planned for the 2017 financial year. 
Even though we are reducing capital and other costs, I would like to emphasize that safe, reliable and sustainable operations are non-negotiable, and that management will continue to drive world-class safety practices across all operations. It's also important to note that critical and strategic growth projects in North America and Southern Africa will continue, as we evaluate new opportunity for further growth.
Turning to Slide 22. We continued to focus on the factors within our control, that being volume growth, margin enhancement and cost reduction. We expect an overall strong production performance for the remainder of the 2015 financial year. 
Total South African liquid fuel sales volumes are expected to be around 59 million barrels for the year. We expect ORYX GTL's average utilization rate to continue to be above 90%. Our chemicals business will keep on driving improved volumes and margin enhancement. Base chemicals normal sales volumes are expected to be slightly higher than the financial year '14, with margins coming under some pressure during the second half of the financial area compared to the first half of the financial year. 
And performance chemicals sales volumes are expected to outperform financial year '14 with increased market demand coupled with resilient margins. We expect normalized cash fixed costs to follow inflation; the Response Plan's cash contribution to range between ZAR 6 billion and ZAR 10 billion for financial year '15; and the average of Brent crude oil prices to be at least 30% lower in the second half of this financial year compared to the first half of the financial year.
And on that note, I hand back to David.

---

Thank you, Paul. And to reach our overarching goal of delivering shareholder value sustainably, it's important that we maintain focus on our dual regional strategy here in Southern Africa and North America. This approach complements our other important business activities in Eurasia, the Middle East and the rest of Africa. 
Looking at the U.S. specifically and turning to Slide 24. We're proceeding with the construction of our ZAR 8.9 billion ethane cracker and derivatives complex in Louisiana and as all of you know, in December 2014, we established a $4 billion credit facility which will be used to finance the project. We've already secured 80% of the funds required through a combination of project finance and our own equity contributions.
The robust project economics benefited from an advantaged site location, which expands on our existing operations, economies of scale, and improved our cost structure and upgraded infrastructure and utilities which drive further efficiencies. 
The new cracker complex would roughly triple the capacity of the Lake Charles site. Furthermore, our product slate distinguishes our investment for most of the other crackers that have been announced. Our project combines commodity and specialty products which will leverage low-cost U.S. ethane feedstocks, and note that specialty chemicals produce will deliver high-value returns even if chemical markets fluctuate. 
To oversee the execution phases of projects, we have an extremely experienced owners team in place and have progressed several key milestones. Site work is proceeding safely and efficiently and we expect that the plan will achieve mechanical completion at the end of calendar year 2017, beneficial operations is on track for the first half of calendar year 2018. 
Slide 25 summarizes our broader contributions in Southern Africa. This slide is self-explanatory, so let me just make a few general comments here on air quality and carbon emissions. Now responsible operations is at the heart of our corporate commitments and to ensure our ongoing compliance with new air quality regulations in South Africa, we applied for certain postponements to manage our short-term challenges relating to the compliance time frames. 
We have now received decisions on our postponement applications from the National Air Quality Officer which, while aligned with our requests, imposed some stretched targets. Our focus is now in the alignment of our licenses to reflect these postponement decisions and on implementing our air quality emission reduction road maps, including community-based offsets to substantially improved ambient air quality where we operate.
As an important aside, it is a given that increasing South Africa's investment attractiveness and alleviating the current electricity crisis are top priorities for the government. It therefore remains our position that the implementation of a carbon tax, any time in the foreseeable future, would be ill advised and instead add a further cost burden to the economy. 
At the same time, we are concerned that the proposed carbon tax will diminish South Africa's international competitiveness and result in a range of other unintended consequences. In our view, the country needs appropriate incentives to invest in new, more energy-efficient processes and projects that improve our energy security and lower our greenhouse gas emissions. 
Looking at the final slide, Slide 26. In order to build on our successes, whatever the global circumstances, we are focusing on enhancing our existing assets and on driving selective growth opportunities. 
In 2011, we undertook to get operational basics right. Today, our ZAR 14 billion Secunda growth program is nearing completion with volume and electricity benefits now fully realized. Group-wide, we continue to generate improved volumes from our global operations. Our Business Performance Enhancement Program is also delivering results with simplified company-wide structures, reduced management layers and costs contained within inflation. 
In South Africa, specifically, we've embarked on an extensive 2050 strategy to ensure the efficiency and reliability of our in-country operations to the middle of the century. Looking at our selective growth opportunities, our dual-regional strategy remains compelling. In America, our Lake Charles Chemicals Project is advancing, while in Southern Africa, we submitted our full field development plan for the Production Sharing Agreement to the Mozambican authorities on February 25. 
Also in Mozambique, our 175-megawatt gas-fired power plant is ramping up nicely. Once fully operational, the plant will supply electricity to more than 2 million Mozambicans, which equates to 8% of the country's current demand. Here in South Africa, the expansion of our Wax facility in Sasolburg is progressing well, with phase 1 commissioning of the new slurry bed reactor scheduled for the first half of this calendar year. Phase 2 beneficial operation's on track for the first half of calendar year 2017. 
As you can see from this slide, both our existing asset and selective growth pillars are now underpinned by our Response Plan, thereby serving to create more value. Here, our prioritized plan, supported by a solid balance sheet, underpin our flexible dividend policy based on a cover range. 
In the half year, we continued to deliver an overall, strong operational and cost performance. With oil prices moving dramatically lower over the last 6 months, the management team has formulated a comprehensive Response Plan to conserve cash and further refine our organizational structures and near-term strategies. The benefits of the detailed work we're doing now will ensure that Sasol emerges from the current challenging macroeconomic environment as an even leaner and more-focused business. With that, we'd now be happy to open it up for any questions you may have. Operator?

Okay. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for joining us. Today, we will walk you through 2014 results and the strategy update over the next 4 years. We are pleased once again to report a solid set of result for 2014, achieved despite a tough and challenging environment. Snam's sound operating performance over the period is reflected by the EUR 3.6 billion of revenues and the EUR 2.8 billion of EBITDA, both at similar level to 2013. This is a remarkable result considering that 2014 is the first year of the full regulatory period for transmission, regasification and distribution businesses. The acquisition of TAG strengthens Snam's leading role amongst infrastructure operators in Europe. Thank you, Carlo, and good afternoon, everyone. 2014 Snam's results were characterized by some relevant events: first year of a new regulatory period for transport, regasification and distribution activities; low gas demand; the consolidation starting from July 1, 2014, AES Torino, the gas distribution company operating in Turin; the Robin Tax that in 2014 decreased from 10.5% to 6.5%, and in 2015 has been considered generating a one-off positive adjustment of EUR 120 million to deferred  tax fund. Given the significant and growing contribution granted by our nonconsolidated associates, it's worth underlining their results in terms of both impact on income and our cash flow.
