Thank you, Antonio. Let me now walk you through 2015-2018 strategy and target. Our goal of achieving sustainable returns and profitable growth will be attained through a focus on 4 strategic priorities that preserve our low risk profile.  First, disciplined management of investment opportunities will allow us to exploit the optionality of our asset portfolio through capitalizing on high-quality growth opportunities in Italy, focusing on 2 main European gas corridor, the East-West and the North-South corridors to integrate and complement our asset portfolio as well as to diversify our country and regulatory risk. Second, we will continuously improve our operational management. This will be accomplished by progressing towards obtaining the role of market facilitator, providing integrated services to shippers and final customers. We will also continue to control costs. Third, pursue sound financial discipline through investing in value-additive CapEx as well as consolidating our solid and efficient capital structure. M&A activity will be selective and aimed at returns' accretion. Drive value for all of our stakeholders through profitable and steady growth even in a low-inflation environment. We will continue to pay a sustainable dividend, thereby delivering attractive shareholder returns. 
Starting with the business environment. I would like to draw your attention to the following main trends in the European gas market. Gas demand in Europe is expected to remain almost flat over the coming decades. However, this would not imply a static marketplace as a decline in the regions' gas reserves and production, particularly in North Sea, will increase Europe's net gas imports from around 65% of total demand in 2013 to a remarkable 75% in 2030. And this import deficit will be geographically imbalanced, the highest import needs being contracted -- concentrated in North Europe. Overall, Europe will become more dependent on non-EU sources, Russia, Middle East, North Africa with an important new contribution by the Caspian region where most gas reserves are concentrated. This market development will generate a significant shift in EU  internal gas flows with Southern EU becoming a crucial entry point for additional import flows.  Furthermore, there is a growing need to balance peaks in gas demand due to its increasing volatility as intermittent renewable energy sources need to be backed up by production in gas fuel combined cycle. These peaks, which require intensive availability of transport and storage capacity, are increasingly uncorrelated to the overall trend in gas demand. This trend imply the need to build out gas infrastructure to facilitate the matching between imported gas and gas demand as well as to integrate gas market to efficiently balance supply and demand. 
The European natural gas industry is being challenged by several factors beyond the global economic downturn and competition in the energy production market. The market is still looking for the right equilibrium between new market needs and security of supply. This is the big challenge for years to come. Along the gas chain, we can observe a re-definition of long-term established roles. Upstream players are willing to get closer to the consumer market, thus, bypassing the traditional gas importers. The latter will also face increasing competition brought by traders and by final consumers. All this translate into a higher degree of volatility in the market. This will become even more evident with more gas supply contracts being renegotiated and linked to the gas spot market rather than to long-term contracts. 
On the other hand, it's important to stress that the complete cancellation of the take-or-pay contracts may become an issue as it affected the security of supply that remain a priority at European level, particularly considering high dependence of single-supply sources and political instability of certain exporters. Infrastructure availability will need to change accordingly and be much more flexible than in the past. Its development will no longer be driven only by the growth of gas demand, but will be required to improve the security of supply, enable the integration of domestic market into a single European marketplace, connected to the highest number of supply sources and provide efficient services encouraging energy price competition versus cheaper but more polluting fuel like oil. 
Additional transmission system and storage facility will have to be developed to cope with highly volatile demand providing the required peak capacity to ensure a secure, reliable and sustainable response to the needs of consumers. Storage is the main resource to tackle potential gas flow shortages. Institution and the regulators should work together to design appropriate measure to pool parts of existing and new gas security stock at European level, ensuring the full utilization and further development of a strategic storage for the continent. This would be possible under several conditions: a common set of rule to establish transit condition of gas from the countries where storage is physically located to consumption site; and an international body able to coordinate specific rule and condition for the use of strategic storage; the debottlenecking of national gas grid; and the availability of reserve flow capacity at cross-border interconnection points. 
The European gas market is characterized by a number of challenges, which can only be addressed by the creation of an interconnected pan-European gas network to diversify gas sourcing and increase the security of supply as well as to foster the flexibility. The integration of European gas network will be supported by the development of efficient and bidirectional cross-border gas corridors. This is the key to guaranteeing security of supply, enhancing competition of the gas market and promoting a smooth transition for an efficient and sustainable low-carbon economy. 
Infrastructure operators needed to design sustainable investment strategy to capture the opportunities generated by the rapidly changing business environment. Their role is evolving from being a mere asset owner, simply managing infrastructure to market facilitator providing innovative integrated services to shippers and final customers. At the same time, the availability of market-responsive services to meet the evolving needs of shippers and final customers, in particular, in terms of flexibility and service integration, is becoming increasingly crucial. A more flexible and shipper-friendly commercial offer and the implementation of common rules are necessary to promote the efficient functioning of the market to foster its liquidity and to preserve the security of supply. Specifically, more advanced commercial offer will aim at an integrated offer for -- of transport, storage and LNG services, with the latter more focused on short-term requirements; a higher degree of consistency between capacity and volume transported, supporting shippers in the optimization of their logistic portfolio. The development of new activities would allow an optimal access and utilization of the gas system by traders and shippers, thus, improving their performance. This will translate into revenue and investment sustainable for infrastructure operator. 
Let me now briefly focus your attention on Italy and specifically, on the distribution industry. From the chart, you can see that the Italian distribution market is still very fragmented between many small operators. The result is that the whole system works at a suboptimal level of efficiency. The recently completed legislative framework is expected to further enhance the consolidation process and increase the efficiency of the distribution through the substantial enlargement of concession areas to seek economy of scale, implying their significant reduction in number; a set of standard rules for the tender process based on economic conditions and parameters on security and quality of the services. The new business environment represents an important opportunity for Italgas as a leading, highly competitive and nationwide position player in the Italian market to unlock additional value. 
Let's now focus on how Snam can develop its strategy in this evolving environment. Let's start with our investment priorities. Snam's CapEx plan has to be analyzed in the context of the changing market environment we just described, which provides us with the optionality to pursue growth opportunity with a long-term vision. In order to support the development of the Italian/European gas market, gas network will have to guarantee high level of security, flexibility and liquidity. This will be achieved through the creation of substantial transport and storage capacity in Italy, including additional capacity to allow for the physical reverse flow of gas from Italy to other European countries, paving the way towards connecting North African countries, the new Caspian area and Eastern Mediterranean gas sources to Continental Europe. In particular, in the transport business, capital expenditure is devoted to meeting capacity requirements and to providing supply source diversification to the shippers. This development should facilitate not only a higher level of security and flexibility of the gas system, but also gas transit to European market via the reverse flow of gas from Italy to other countries. 
Moving on to storage. Our substantial investment program has been designed to guarantee greater storage capacity in the gas system both in terms of modulation and peak capacity, optimizing the balance of the overall system. At the same time, by increasing capacity, we can create a favorable condition for the development of higher liquidity in the gas system. This will set the path for  facilitating the use of our storage system for gas swap opportunities as well as to pull it for security purpose at the EU level in coming years. 
With regards to the distribution business, investment will be focused on the development of new distribution networks, mainly in South of Italy and on the smart metering project, which will allow Italgas to guarantee a high level of service quality. More importantly, the new legislative framework, Italgas will both exploit consolidation opportunities and will begin optimizing its portfolio and concession, which we will discuss in further detail later on. 
The plan for CapEx in Italy is EUR 5.1 billion over the next 4 years, which will support an estimated 1% annual growth in our consolidated regulatory asset base by 2018, starting from the 2014 estimated base just below EUR 25 million. We plan to manage the pace and timing of our investment to maintain our track record of profitable growth, improving capital efficiency and returns. The change versus the previous 4-year CapEx plan is mainly due to the shifting of spending related to the certain investment in the south of Italy in order to match the capacity need related to the TAP project as well as to the completion of some development project for the new storage capacity. 
In 2015, we expect to invest EUR 1.3 billion, with the remaining EUR 3.8 billion to be spread over the remainder of the plan period. Furthermore, we will consolidate the profitability of our asset base, leveraging the incentive scheme set by the authority. With around 70% of total investment incentivized, with higher remuneration, the share of the overall RAB benefiting from incentivized remuneration will account for an average 1/3 of the total for the plan period. 
Over the 4-year business plan, 60% of the total CapEx, or approximately EUR 3.1 billion, will be spent on the transport business, 30% on distribution and the remaining 10% on the storage business. As you know, we traditionally provide a 4 years CapEx plan as a solid estimation of our future spending. This is underpinned by the fact that around 75% of the overall spending is already authorized. 
Let's now focus on the project in the transport business. The project we are developing in Italy around EUR 3.1 billion over the plan period and will strengthen both import and export infrastructure, facilitating the establishment of future physical gas transit. With regards to export, the project will involve new pipeline developments in the Po Valley, 450 kilometers, two new compressor stations, 100 megawatt of installed power capacity as well as the empowerment of an existing station to allow for physical reverse flow in the pipelines. The overall investment dedicated to the north gas market and the creation of reverse flow capacity is around EUR 0.6 billion over the plan period. 
With regard to imports, the key project in our plan is the South-North development. We plan to build pipelines of over 420 kilometers, which will increase the capacity at the southern entry points by around 8 bcm. This new project will be on stream by 2021, and will require the investment of around EUR 1.5 billion, of which EUR 0.1 billion in the plan period 2015-2018, mainly related to the engineering and permission activities. This project represents the bulk of the CapEx to be put in place after 2018, in order to complete the main development projects of the plan period. 
Our forecast for gas consumption in Italy shows an increase of around 1% per years for the period 2014-2025, largely driven by growth from the power generation sector of around 2.7%, while the industrial and residential and commercial sector are expected to be flat. 
Combined with the declining domestic production and growing export flows to Northern Europe, we expect import and transit volumes to significantly increase beyond 2020. The projects I have outlined in the previous slide ending but [ph] primarily devoted to consolidating the security of supply in each Italian region, taking into account the expected improvement in gas supply diversification, and therefore, change in our entry point are utilized.  
Furthermore, this project pave the way for the development of greater export capacity. Specifically, our import project will increase the import capacity from 347 million standard cubic meter per day of gas in 2014 to around 370 million standard cubic meter per day beyond 2020. 
Regarding export to Northern Europe, the program is to boost export capacity from the current 24 million standard cubic meter per day to 46 million in 2018, mainly at Passo Gries, where we plan to create the capacity to export over 5 million standard cubic meter by 2015 to reach 40 million standard cubic meter by 2018. 
These projects are well supported by the expected development of the Italian and European gas market dynamics, with Snam's gas transmission network increasingly playing a gas transit role. 
Looking at the storage business, the approximately -- the approximate EUR 0.5 billion of projects include in our investment plan should lead to an 11% increase in modulation capacity. This is expected to reach approximately 12.6 bcm in 2018 from the current 11.4 bcm, excluding strategic storage, which is currently the level of 4.5 bcm. The expected capacity development represents the completion of the project started in order to meet the requirements of the ministerial decree issued in 2010. 
In addition, there will be an 80% increase in peak capacity, which is expected to reach more than 30 million cubic meter per day in 2018 compared to the 281 million cubic meter per day in 2014. These advances will increase the level of security and liquidity in the gas system. We are committed to providing new modulation services to all the shippers, which give them a growing level of short-cycle flexibility. 
Furthermore, we will support development of new services that allow for the integrated management of transport and storage capacities. 
Last but not least, this capacity development will also provide a sound base for the Italian storage system to participate as a central player in the potential pooling of existing and new gas security stock at European level.
In terms of the CapEx plan for the distribution business, our EUR 1.5 billion program is focused mainly on the network expansion and smart metering and will consolidate our revenues growth. We will invest in the replacement of some existing pipes, around 800 kilometers, in development of the distribution network by adding new line and by increasing the number of new connection on the existing distribution network, around 1,000 kilometers. We will also provide higher service quality and security across the network. The overall spending will reach approximately EUR 0.9 billion. 
Regarding smart metering, the investment program will also require the development of the relevant ICT hardware and software. The total CapEx for this project in the plan period is approximately EUR 450 million, representing around 30% of the total CapEx, and it will receive a higher remuneration under the current remuneration scheme. 
Investment in the 4-year plan, together with the optimization of the concession portfolio, will bring the number of consolidated redelivery point to approximately EUR 6.6 million compared to the EUR 6.4 million redelivery point in 2014. 
Let me now briefly focus your attention on our strategy in the distribution business. Italian gas distribution underwent a market consolidation, as seen a few slides ago, and is now on the eve of a massive concessionary renewal. The newly adopted legislative framework should enable streamlined execution, thus, reducing administrative litigation and improve clarity. 
As you know, this new scheme is now based on concession at area level, there are 177 gas areas, with standardized condition service, quality being one of the main granting criteria. The latest mille product [ph] decree imposes an extremely strict calendar, hence, most of the auctions will take place within the next 4 years.
Italgas is today the market leader in Italy with 1/3 of the total market share. In addition, more than 75% of its current business is carried out in gas areas where it holds a relevant market share. The gas benefit from a competitive cost structure and strong cash flow generation, which grant us a significant return on investment. Leveraging its remarkable financial and operational competitive advantages, Italgas aims to unlock further value through the tender process of gas distribution concessions. The tender process will provide the opportunity to optimize the concession portfolio by moving from a fragmented geographic presence to concentrating on more uniform areas of operation, leveraging on synergies, economies of scale and applying its best practice in the newly acquired gas areas. 
Value creation will also be pursued through providing operational services to third-party network, granting us an additional stream of revenue in coming years. In a process characterized by transparency and efficiency [ph] rewards, Italgas aims to increase its current market share, gaining in terms of size and triggering further economies of scale. In the current plan, we are not considering significant additional financial commitment related to the consolidation process. We are monitoring the evolution of the tender process in order to capitalize all the opportunity that could arise to create further value.
As in 2014, over the next few years, we will work to develop new services to boost the liquidity of the gas market across 3 main work areas: capacity services, balancing regime and cooperation with gas exchanges. Let me give you some example of what we have already launched and of where we will focus on our work in the near future. 
With reference to the new capacity services, we have implemented the new products envisaged by the European network code one year ahead of the enter into force of the provision, which is set on November 2015. Gas demand in Europe is expected to remain almost flat over the coming decades. However, this would not imply a static marketplace as a decline in the regions' gas reserves and production, particularly in North Sea, will increase Europe's net gas imports from around 65% of total demand in 2013 to a remarkable 75% in 2030. Let's now focus on how Snam can develop its strategy in this evolving environment. Let's start with our investment priorities. Snam's CapEx plan has to be analyzed in the context of the changing market environment we just described, which provides us with the optionality to pursue growth opportunity with a long-term vision. In order to support the development of the Italian/European gas market, gas network will have to guarantee high level of security, flexibility and liquidity. This will be achieved through the creation of substantial transport and storage capacity in Italy, including additional capacity to allow for the physical reverse flow of gas from Italy to other European countries, paving the way towards connecting North African countries, the new Caspian area and Eastern Mediterranean gas sources to Continental Europe. In particular, in the transport business, capital expenditure is devoted to meeting capacity requirements and to providing supply source diversification to the shippers. This development should facilitate not only a higher level of security and flexibility of the gas system, but also gas transit to European market via the reverse flow of gas from Italy to other countries. 
Moving on to storage. Our substantial investment program has been designed to guarantee greater storage capacity in the gas system both in terms of modulation and peak capacity, optimizing the balance of the overall system. At the same time, by increasing capacity, we can create a favorable condition for the development of higher liquidity in the gas system. This will set the path for  facilitating the use of our storage system for gas swap opportunities as well as to pull it for security purpose at the EU level in coming years. 
With regards to the distribution business, investment will be focused on the development of new distribution networks, mainly in South of Italy and on the smart metering project, which will allow Italgas to guarantee a high level of service quality. More importantly, the new legislative framework, Italgas will both exploit consolidation opportunities and will begin optimizing its portfolio and concession, which we will discuss in further detail later on. 
The plan for CapEx in Italy is EUR 5.1 billion over the next 4 years, which will support an estimated 1% annual growth in our consolidated regulatory asset base by 2018, starting from the 2014 estimated base just below EUR 25 million. We plan to manage the pace and timing of our investment to maintain our track record of profitable growth, improving capital efficiency and returns. The change versus the previous 4-year CapEx plan is mainly due to the shifting of spending related to the certain investment in the south of Italy in order to match the capacity need related to the TAP project as well as to the completion of some development project for the new storage capacity. 
In 2015, we expect to invest EUR 1.3 billion, with the remaining EUR 3.8 billion to be spread over the remainder of the plan period. Furthermore, we will consolidate the profitability of our asset base, leveraging the incentive scheme set by the authority. With around 70% of total investment incentivized, with higher remuneration, the share of the overall RAB benefiting from incentivized remuneration will account for an average 1/3 of the total for the plan period. 
Over the 4-year business plan, 60% of the total CapEx, or approximately EUR 3.1 billion, will be spent on the transport business, 30% on distribution and the remaining 10% on the storage business. As you know, we traditionally provide a 4 years CapEx plan as a solid estimation of our future spending. This is underpinned by the fact that around 75% of the overall spending is already authorized. 
Let's now focus on the project in the transport business. The project we are developing in Italy around EUR 3.1 billion over the plan period and will strengthen both import and export infrastructure, facilitating the establishment of future physical gas transit. With regards to export, the project will involve new pipeline developments in the Po Valley, 450 kilometers, two new compressor stations, 100 megawatt of installed power capacity as well as the empowerment of an existing station to allow for physical reverse flow in the pipelines. The overall investment dedicated to the north gas market and the creation of reverse flow capacity is around EUR 0.6 billion over the plan period. 
With regard to imports, the key project in our plan is the South-North development. We plan to build pipelines of over 420 kilometers, which will increase the capacity at the southern entry points by around 8 bcm. This new project will be on stream by 2021, and will require the investment of around EUR 1.5 billion, of which EUR 0.1 billion in the plan period 2015-2018, mainly related to the engineering and permission activities. This project represents the bulk of the CapEx to be put in place after 2018, in order to complete the main development projects of the plan period. 
Our forecast for gas consumption in Italy shows an increase of around 1% per years for the period 2014-2025, largely driven by growth from the power generation sector of around 2.7%, while the industrial and residential and commercial sector are expected to be flat. 
Combined with the declining domestic production and growing export flows to Northern Europe, we expect import and transit volumes to significantly increase beyond 2020. The projects I have outlined in the previous slide ending but [ph] primarily devoted to consolidating the security of supply in each Italian region, taking into account the expected improvement in gas supply diversification, and therefore, change in our entry point are utilized.  
Furthermore, this project pave the way for the development of greater export capacity. Specifically, our import project will increase the import capacity from 347 million standard cubic meter per day of gas in 2014 to around 370 million standard cubic meter per day beyond 2020. 
Regarding export to Northern Europe, the program is to boost export capacity from the current 24 million standard cubic meter per day to 46 million in 2018, mainly at Passo Gries, where we plan to create the capacity to export over 5 million standard cubic meter by 2015 to reach 40 million standard cubic meter by 2018. 
These projects are well supported by the expected development of the Italian and European gas market dynamics, with Snam's gas transmission network increasingly playing a gas transit role. 
Looking at the storage business, the approximately -- the approximate EUR 0.5 billion of projects include in our investment plan should lead to an 11% increase in modulation capacity. In terms of the CapEx plan for the distribution business, our EUR 1.5 billion program is focused mainly on the network expansion and smart metering and will consolidate our revenues growth. Let me now briefly focus your attention on our strategy in the distribution business. Italian gas distribution underwent a market consolidation, as seen a few slides ago, and is now on the eve of a massive concessionary renewal. The newly adopted legislative framework should enable streamlined execution, thus, reducing administrative litigation and improve clarity. 
As you know, this new scheme is now based on concession at area level, there are 177 gas areas, with standardized condition service, quality being one of the main granting criteria. The latest mille product [ph] decree imposes an extremely strict calendar, hence, most of the auctions will take place within the next 4 years.
Italgas is today the market leader in Italy with 1/3 of the total market share. In addition, more than 75% of its current business is carried out in gas areas where it holds a relevant market share. The gas benefit from a competitive cost structure and strong cash flow generation, which grant us a significant return on investment. Leveraging its remarkable financial and operational competitive advantages, Italgas aims to unlock further value through the tender process of gas distribution concessions. The tender process will provide the opportunity to optimize the concession portfolio by moving from a fragmented geographic presence to concentrating on more uniform areas of operation, leveraging on synergies, economies of scale and applying its best practice in the newly acquired gas areas. 
Value creation will also be pursued through providing operational services to third-party network, granting us an additional stream of revenue in coming years. In a process characterized by transparency and efficiency [ph] rewards, Italgas aims to increase its current market share, gaining in terms of size and triggering further economies of scale. In the current plan, we are not considering significant additional financial commitment related to the consolidation process. We are monitoring the evolution of the tender process in order to capitalize all the opportunity that could arise to create further value.
As in 2014, over the next few years, we will work to develop new services to boost the liquidity of the gas market across 3 main work areas: capacity services, balancing regime and cooperation with gas exchanges. Let me give you some example of what we have already launched and of where we will focus on our work in the near future. 
With reference to the new capacity services, we have implemented the new products envisaged by the European network code one year ahead of the enter into force of the provision, which is set on November 2015. The offer of the so-called bundled transmission capacity services allow for the transportation of gas between hubs via a single-capacity booking process, facilitating trading and arbitrage activities. 
We are also working on the possibility to introduce short-cycle storage services in addition to the basic modulation services to address the increasing flexibility needs of users. 
Finally, we have proposed an incentive-based oversubscription and buyback scheme to offer additional capacity on a firm [ph] basis, in line with the EU regulation, which is now under evaluation by the regulator. 
Concerning the balancing regime, we have extended the balancing market to new flexibility sources, namely import and LNG, in addition to storage, and the new day-ahead balancing session has been introduced. We are in the process of implementing the EU balancing code, which will come into force in October 2015. In this framework, it is possible to envisage incentive scheme for the TSO in providing services aimed to support a better market functioning and to provide timely and accurate information to shippers regarding their daily commercial portfolio consumption. We are working to introduce incentive schemes in these areas. 
Finally, we are working intensively toward the evolution of the Italian gas system, and we have several cooperation activities ongoing with gas exchange operators for the development of future and spot gas market with physically delivery of the gas commodity. 
As you already know, Snam is also shareholder in the new European platform, which was created to offer transmission capacity, in line with the future European rules, and which allows the commercial connection of the PSO to the main North European gas hubs. 
Considering the key role that all the services and activities plays in the creation of the internal gas market, we are working with the relevant institution to introduce incentive scheme to exploit value not only for the gas system but also for Snam. We estimate that the services already identified and under discussion with the regulatory body could activate a potential new annual revenue stream up to EUR 40 million with meaningless related cost and capital employed within the current regulatory period. 
Alongside our investment priority and our international development, delivering operational efficiency is a key focus. Our track record in driving operational efficiency has been achieved across different regulatory periods by leveraging the proven experience that this company has in the cost of personnel, supply and services. This has resulted in a reduction of our controllable fixed cost by 5% in nominal terms, still allowing us to create value through operational efficiency. Such value creation is even more significant, if you consider that our operating activities showed a significant growth in transport infrastructure, storage capacity and in the number of distribution customers. 
Over the last few years, we are approaching a satisfactory level in terms of controllable cost. However, we will continue with our efficiency plan across the businesses. The target for our plan period aims to keeping the unit controllable fixed cost flat in real terms at constant parameters. This is a sound approach considering that we are currently running the fourth regulatory period across all our businesses. We have achieved a satisfactory cost base, and the current regulatory framework partially allows the recognition of the incremental cost related to the growing asset base. 
To give you more evidence on how we would like to manage our cost base, we set some KPIs for our different businesses. In all of them, we plan to achieve unit controllable fixed cost flat in real terms in the next 4 years. The significant effort will well sustain our operating profitability line. 
Now let's move to Snam international development. Moving abroad, as you know, our international expansion strategy is very straightforward. Snam intends to play a significant role in the integration of the European gas infrastructure, focusing on the European gas corridor connected to the Italian infrastructure to best leverage on the strategic positioning of the Italian gas grid with respect to the future European gas flows. With this in mind, we commenced the journey to building a European platform by entering into strategic alliance with Fluxys, which resulted into reverse flow project from Italy to Germany and in the joint acquisition of a stake in Interconnector U.K.; acquiring a co-controlling stake of TIGF, currently is 40.5%, which is strategically positioned along the western leg of the European east-west gas corridor, and providing us further value-creation opportunities through the development of both a higher degree of market flexibility and integration in France and the interconnection of the French and Iberian markets with those of North Central Europe; and more recently in TAG, around 84.5%, which further strengthened the company's leading role amongst infrastructure operators in Europe, also thanks to its potential use in reverse flow towards Southern German and Central Europe markets. 
All these transactions leave us very well-positioned to drive international growth. Our key objective are: to optimize return from the existing asset base; to coordinate CapEx and commercial activities within our cooperation with Fluxys in the North-South corridor; to focus on completing our exposure to our 2 target corridors, the North-South and the East-West corridors. 
I will now hand over to Antonio to further discussion on international development and financial efficiency.

The second step that we are discussing today and we are confident to close the agreement in 2015 is that the condition is clear, but we are confident is to have the possibility to manage directly the commercial contract. That means to enter in the share participation directly in the company in Germany and in Switzerland. It's clear that today, we have the due diligence process. But the intention is, frankly speaking, it's not a financial investment because that will not impact in the economic and financial figures, is having the possibility to manage directly the strategy at European level and to, let me say, to bring inside the institution European commitment regulator in Germany; and in Switzerland, the value-added for a connection with south of Italy and with North Africa. Okay, for distribution, frankly speaking, I'm not so confident that the time there was a lot of -- there has been a strong delay, I'm not so confident. This is the reason I said before there is a problem of financial exposure by the municipality by some small company. That is the reason why could be some delays in the auction, but it's quite difficult to wait 4, 5 years without an evolution of the market. The evolution could be the selling process, joint venture, acquisition. But anyway, today, it's quite difficult to say if the auctions will start in 2017 or '18. I don't think that the distribution market could remain in this condition. That is the reason why we are very clear where we are competitive, but we are monitoring the evolution of the market to exploit the best advantages in this way. For the smart metering, at the beginning, 2 years ago, Italgas, we were warm in speeding the investment because the technology was not so strong to guarantee the cost of -- the operation cost of the new smart metering. The different -- a lot of operators worked a lot to set new technology. And today, I think we are ready to start with the investment. And we will -- let me say, we will proceed with the investment in line with the time set by the regulator in the decree. So there is no intention to increase the investment, but we respect the time because we are quite sure that today, the technology is ready for the investment. The second aspect is that for us, the metering system, the smart metering system is an advantage for all the business, not only for the quality in the distribution business. I said before, I called you about some services having the hourly balancing in Italy means strong advantage in terms of dispatching the gas in Italy and information. That is the reason why we have to consider the positive impact in the transmission business and storage business of the metering system.

---

Monica Girardi, Barclays. I have few questions, if I may. The first one is associated with the comment you made on the focused approach to support the dividend policy. I was wondering if you can -- I know that we are in a particular period of time when you have the ongoing renegotiation of your real pretax return, but maybe you can share with us if you believe that your current dividend policy is sustainable, under which regulatory distressed scenario you don't see it sustainable anymore? And if you can share with us what is your assumption in terms of real pretax return into the business plan? And assuming the authorities not getting the number you want, if you have flexibility into managing your CapEx to protect the return to shareholders? The second question is on the cost of debt. Antonio, you guided for the 2015 cost of debt, but clearly, the major benefits would be accumulated towards the business plan period, so due to refinancing. Last one, I promise, on Italgas, if you can just give us an update on the ongoing litigation there?

I answer the first question. To be very frank with you, my -- I'm confident, my perception is that as usually, the regulator will take a fair approach in defining the tariff reset to allow the company to sustain the business model and the investment infrastructure, which I remind you are completely in-line with the energy strategy, European and Italian energy strategy. And I don't expect it to completely change. First of all, I think that the intention is to maintain a regulatory asset base on real pretax return based on the Italian government bond. The exogenous parameter, as I mentioned, that could be in the risk-free and inflation. But frankly speaking, I'm confident that the approach will be fair. Secondly, if you consider our -- the Snam cash flow generations, the solid balance sheet and I remind restore of financial flexibility we have today, all these item should provide us with a good room, let me say, to manage the potential impact of the tariff reset. I cannot say today we could be all the surprises, but considering cash flow production, balance sheet and restore flexibility, I think we can face the tariff reset without jeopardize our business model. Italgas, after the debt, I give Antonio.

---

Cost of debt -- Monica, you know the rules of our company is to give guidance in relation to the current year, so it is 2.9% for 2015. Let me say when we prepared the presentation, it was clear that the -- also for us that it is clear that the benefit of the current situation will be exploited in the following years, and so we try to give the market, to give the analyst some elements for their math. I would say that, first of all, it is useful to have a look at the refinancing exercise, so the bonds that are going to expire -- are going to terminate within the 4 years' plan, so the EUR 4.5 billion of bonds that according to the market condition of today could give us some advantages in the range of above 200 basis points, so this is very easy for you to calculate the impact. I can add one other element which is the cost of our [indiscernible] requisition, which is the average of the banking facilities, our bonds at floating rates, the cost of the significant part of the European bank funding, which is today at floating rates, as an average, you can assume, something below 50 basis point of spread.

---

An update of the Italgas, I think it's no appropriate litigation. Without summarize all the process, we informed you in July of the situation. Anyway, it's important to highlight that the court decided to invoke a specific Italian law, which is a preventive measure anyway for Italgas. The duration of this arrangement was a set 6 months with the possibility of extension of a further 6 months and maximum 12 months. The last decision in January was to expand the period, expand these 6 months because it's the time set. The reason is that the administrator appointed have to complete the assessment. There's no completely the assessment. We are today, we are working with the court about this point, and is positive that the court ordered to the administrator to set a technical roundtable with Snam and Italgas to, let me say, to agreeing of the measure we can put in place to resolve the problem. So that means that the intention is to speed deposition. I remind you that it's not a crime investigation. It's only an assessment if the procedures and the measure which Italgas has inside are adequate to, let me say, to stop the possibility of infiltration of crime. That is the reason. I have to say that in the last, starting from the summer, it's clear that we are commission and third-party independent, with a third-party independent adviser, it's in particular, Deloitte, I mean to say. We are committed an assessment to understand if the procedure of the company are adequate for this type of procedure. And the result is Autonomous independent adviser. The result is that the procedure of Italgas currently in place are capable at preventing infiltration or facilitation of organized crime, only to say that we are confident that we can speed with the time set by the court, frankly speaking, but we don't have a reason to identify or to expect some impact in the company. It is the reason why there was no discussion with the consolidation. We check with -- not only with the court, which said we have to consolidate. But frankly speaking, we have to work together to try to resolve in the best way, the problem. The same time, it's clear that we -- it's a decision by the court for the consolidation, the appointed administrator have to follow for the managing of the company, the guideline technical, commercial, the guideline of the control company of Snam. So there is no -- there is, let me say, a formal control that the manager in the company will be in line without the risk of some lack in the managing system.

Antonella Bianchessi from Citi. Just 2 very quick questions. The first one if you can give us a little bit of insight on what is the ongoing debate with the regulator? Which are your targets? Which are the most important things that you would like to achieve during this regulatory reset? The second question is on the debt. You mentioned that you have EUR 1 billion of headroom. ---

Thank you, Antonella, after the last November, the last -- the [indiscernible] -- end of the year -- the [indiscernible] of the regulators, today, we are waiting the consultation document. Usually, our approach is not to discuss a figure or element about is to understand the total revenue we can have. That is the reason why only with the consultation document, which we expect the issue of the consultation document by May, roughly. We are ready to start all the discussion for all the figures inside the document not only, let me say, that it's free. Today, we are not, is technical, let me say, discussion, but it's general. There is no, let me say, specific point for the new consultation document. I think the consultation document in terms of the regulator is to align all the businesses, power and gas. So it will be very -- it's very clear that is important consultation document. It's not only for Snam. That is the reason why it's quite difficult today to discuss before the regulator what could be the feeling or the intention of the regulators.

---

For the second point, the flexibility, the EUR 1 billion flexibility, Antonella, it's just a matter of fact. If you consider at least 2 elements, the first one is the rating metrics is just a matter of numbers. If you apply the credit metrics on our numbers, you can easily understand that the EUR 1 billion is a fact. It is also confirmed by the assessment of one of the 2 rating agencies that follows Snam, which in addition to the rating level also disclosed the so-called standalone rating, which in our case is single A-, which is downgraded by some steps to the current one because of the rating of the Republic, the sovereign rate. So it's just a matter of metrics. If you can -- if you want, we can share with you the calculation. In [indiscernible] of the second question, I mean this is the financial flexibility that we want to maintain, and we can use -- we could use in the future this financial flexibility for helping supporting the equity story, both I would say, first of all, supporting the dividend, supporting the capability of the company to capture all the opportunities we can have. I mean we discussed before about distribution. It is clear that having this flexibility, the financial aspect would be much more sexy for us. And therefore, we can -- at the end, you also have to consider that the metrics calculated does not -- did not consider the cancellation of the Robin Tax. Robin Tax means, in our case, a cash flow, higher cash flow, our net income and cash flow of something what -- something around EUR 90 million per year, which at the end is very, very important. No, the [indiscernible] easy, no, no, -- sorry, it's my bad English for me. The duration is the 10 or average 10 or 5 years. In terms of duration of the fixed rate, the duration of the interest rate, our duration is very, very close to the one of the authority. If you consider we have 2/3 of our debt at fixed rate with a duration of 4 to 5 years, and we have 1/3 of our debt at floating rates. So the aggregate duration is very close to the 1, 2 years that is the duration of -- which is the length of the review of the authority.

---

José Ruiz from Macquarie. Three questions, if I may. The first one is, if you could help us to understand a little bit more this EUR 40 million of additional revenues from gas facilitation? More specifically, is that the service that you're going to be providing by 2018? and I understand that this is just a minimum because I understand you will have more reverse flow around the gas corridor. The second one is, if you could update us on the launch of the vehicle, the joint venture with Fluxys, the assets you want to put together? And the third one is, you mentioned storage in -- gas storage increasing to 10 bcms. My question is, is this a signal that the gas that Europe has been sending to Asia and to other -- diverting to other destinations is coming back to Europe?

---

The EUR 40 million, I think the EUR 40 million is the services revenues capability, is an assumption we have done considering the set of proposal we are discussing with the regulators -- with the regulator during this regulatory period. So it's revenues, part of the revenues are outside the regulatory regime. 20% of the revenue are an update of the regulatory regimes. So considering all the capability to -- the capability of the service proposal roughly, we can estimate an increase of the revenue of EUR 40 million. The environment, the gas evolution and the trend of using more storage than the import, I think, frankly speaking, is my opinion, I'm not a shipper or trading company but is only price -- the problem of price competition is economic problem. That is the reason why, in Italy, we are 90%, 100% because that's part of the industrial sector. The storage are 100% of regulated business, but it's in a way to use as a merchant, the regulated storage. So the possibility to fill the storage during the summer period with low, low tariff, so the tariff is lower than the regulatory framework. That is the reason it's an advantage to cut the logistic cost for the trading company or the shipper. That is the reason why there is interest to fill the storage and to use more storage in the winter period instead the take-or-pay import of gas. But I think it's important because it's an evolution. There is more volatility. This is an evolution of the market condition of gas. So that is the reason that is, and let me say, signal that translation of the take-or-pay in spot quarter [ph]. So in terms of infrastructure, I think it's an evaluation we have to done because we need more flexibility and more interconnection of transmission storage LNG. So we have to combine a network with a strong interconnection, not only for Italy but for at European level. There are lots of questions. For Fluxys, we completed the agreement for the strategic alliance in terms of commitment of investment for Fluxys and for Snam in Italy, and we are working to set the final decision of enter in the share participation of the company, and so share of participation of Fluxys and Snam in the foreign company -- in the asset company.

---

It's Anna Maria Scaglia from Morgan Stanley. Two questions, if I may. The first one is related to the other revenues line. You booked the [indiscernible] EUR 60 million. I was wondering what's the evolution expected there? And if so, the EUR 40 million we spoke before, if those would be included there, even they're not all regulated revenues? And the second question is still related to dividend and regulation. Provided, of course, the level of disclosure by the regulator is almost 0 at the moment, I was wondering, is there a scenario where with the end of the Robin Hood tax, your payout actually would go down, if, let's say, on my numbers of around 5% allowed to return. So under those scenarios, are you willing to consider, longer term, a minimum dividend plus a payout base policy? Or is this way too early to talk about that?

---

I take on the easy one which is the one related to the other revenues. I remember there was an increase of EUR 20 million, from EUR 40 million to EUR 60 million. The major part of the increase is due to some revenues we had, the nonregulated revenues we had for the storage but is related to subcontracts we have with ENI in relation to the Decree 130. So nothing related to the other new services. So for that item, I think that EUR 40 million remain -- as for the future, the level of EUR 40 million remains significant, reasonable at least level for projecting our net income and does not include anything of the additional revenues we were discussing before.

---

Within the regulation, I said before that apart from I'm confident that the regulatory update will be fair anyway for our -- to confirm our business model. Our commitment, as I said before, our -- the main commitment we have is to deliver to our shareholder a sustainable and attractive return. So only to say that it's clear that it's serious to maintain the dividend in 2015 waiting evolution, but the main commitment is to deliver strong return to our shareholder. I think we can analyze the possibility to evaluate the 80%, the payout. I think it's early today to set a dividend policy with the payout.

---

I would say the payout has been always for us the reference for understanding which is the sustainability of our dividends. The target, the guidance has been always in terms of the dividend per share. Today, with the new tax rate, we expect that 20% [ph] would mean something around 80%, so sustainable for the future. This is the starting point. We will see the evolution take into account the reset, the review of the tariff starting from 2016. But again, it's not -- our policy was never, was not in the past linked to the payout. It was a pure dividend per share policy.

---

Enrico Bartoli from MainFirst. First of all, 2 general questions. One, you mentioned that the MIDCAT is, let's say, at your level, a decision. So this is going to unlock a lot of import capacity at European level through the Spanish LNG. Do you think that this is going to cannibalize in some way the medium, long-term perspectives of investments in the gas system in Italy? Then a question on gas. This is, we know, a very, very longer process. There was recently some statement by the Algerian authorities saying that they would like to go on with this project. And what is your feeling of the feasibility considering the international situation at the moment? And then, of course, on some figures, if you can give us the RAB at the end of 2014 and what you expect for the end of this year and possibly also the net debt for -- at the end of '15, please?

---

On MIDCAT, I think it will be an opportunity. It's not a risk for the Italian reverse flow. The first step of the TIGF CapEx plan, 4 years CapEx plan, is the interconnection from the hub of south of France to northeast of France. Northeast of France is the connection with Switzerland and Italy. So in this case, I think, means to put on the market more liquidity of gas.
So it is an opportunity. There's no -- let me say, the more Spanish gas. There is no -- the possibility to jeopardize the investment or reverse flow. When you speak about reverse flow, we speak about interconnection. So the way of the gas depend of the price competition. It's not a physical decision, but depending on the price competition. Today, with the completely connection, with the European gas exchange -- all European gas exchange, we can buy in France, in Germany or in Spain the gas at a different price. So what is important is that there is a strong interconnection through the country. So there is no problem of stop the investment or reverse flow. For Galsi, frankly speaking, today, in the last month, there have been a lot of rumors of Sonatrach and larger operators to speed Galsi. I think, Galsi in terms of value of investment, in terms of the possibility to bring gas in Europe by Sonatrach, by the Algerian country, I think is an event. Because reaching the North of Italy with the investment of connection from Algeria to Sardinia, I think is an opportunity. The problem is that I don't see today the environment ready to sign a long-term contract. It could be a risk for the producer. The decision could be to enter directly in the market. I said before that without a shipper to enter directly in the market, I don't know, but today I think is -- if the market -- in general, the market is not ready to sign and to define, to take a final investment decision for gas like this has been [ph].

---

RAB, the estimation on the RAB at the end of 2013 from 2014. At the end of 2014, our estimation is EUR 24.7 billion, which implies an inflation of 0.6% for 2014. Starting from this element, assuming an inflation of 0.7% and the investment of EUR 1.3 billion, the RAB at the end of 2015 is estimated in EUR 25 billion. Our debt. As far as our debt is concerned, at the end of 2015, I would say that if we consider the cancellation of the Robin Hood tax that should not be -- should not have any payment -- further payment for this year. So a saving of EUR 90 million. And the cash in, we have already realized for the entrance of category called NKGF [ph]. The guidelines of our net debt at the end of the year is EUR 13.8 billion, EUR 13.9 billion. The difference, in particular, I would underline depends on the -- some item in the working capital, that is associated with the balancing mechanism and is not in our power to manage the result of these working capital, but it depends on the position that the shipper will take at the end of the year. So this is the range that cannot be managed by the company.

---

Very quickly just 2 questions. The first, regarding the RAB of the top at the end of '14. If you can give this number. The second regarding the extra return, the incentives on investments. The regulator introduced an auto-based system on the storage and it is probably doing the same also for electricity transmission. Do you expect that also for gas transport, we can see something similar and what are the risks in this case and also if you have a time frame when this could happen?

---

From the RAB of TAG, I would need a few seconds. First of all, for being -- it is clear that TAG operates under a fully regulated tariff regime with a RAB-based mechanism, first of all. But it is somewhat different from the Italian one being in Austria, the regulatory framework based on a fixed book capacity mechanism, which means that there is an exposure to the book capacity. So the quality of the quality, the structure is different. On the RAB, you know that the regulation in Austria recognized the return on equity, which is 9%, something more than 9% and the cost of debt, which is something more than 4%. That applied the first one on the 60% of the asset at reconstruction value. The other one at 40% of the asset at book value. We can give the name of RAB to the sum of the 60% and this 40%. Even if 60% is at the current level and 40% is the book level, this value is more than EUR 1 billion.

---

The second question. First of all, we have to manage the storage because we don't have the final tariff, which would be -- final tariff in July, so the problem. So we are discussing the problem of work in progress and so on. It's not a final decision. Anyway, if -- to be very clear, if that would be the final decision, the intention is to appeal to the administrative court only because the investment we are doing are linked to the Decree 130. So all the investment inside the 130 are committed -- were committed 2 years ago, first of all, but this is a -- it's not a question. The other -- for the transmission, I think is different situation because the problem of putting operations investment is very strong in the storage because the time of expanding before putting operation for the new field is 4 years, 3 years. For the transmission, we can put in operations step-by-step without this type of risk. There's no real risk in the transmission. The problem is in the storage today because we are running the investment, we started 2 years ago. So we cannot put in operation a field during the investment. It's completely different approach. That is the reason why you have to face this [indiscernible] storage because it's very different -- storage are not investment we can decide step-by-step. When we start with the field, we have to complete the field for putting in operations on a different approach.

---

Let's now move to the conference calls just to see if there are some questions.

---

Alberto Gandolfi, UBS. I have 3, please. First one is that today the 10-year bond in Italy is 1.1%, and I know the inflation used by the regulator is not the RAB deflator, but from the RAB deflator you're talking about here, it would appear that you have like a real rate of like 0.6%, 0.5%. So the question here is twofold. One, haven't you been maybe a little bit optimistic on inflation on RAB and your dividends is going to be contingent to inflation. So how do you think about the relationship between inflation and dividends, please? And secondly, what type of discussions are you having with the regulator to avoid the situation we incurred towards the end of last year when there was a clear mismatch between inflation and bond yields. Bond yield is a clear 12-month rolling average. Inflation, I still don't understand where the regulator gets it from. So how can we make sure that this time around the regulator is very congruent, consistent in establishing bond yields and inflation, so that we don't have a mismatch for a couple of years. Second one is that you talked about your ratio targets net debt divided by RAB. Can I ask you, do you have a maximum level for 2016 as well, sort of an exceptional level, could you breach that if regulator were to prove particularly harsh and could you modulate effective CapEx even further? And the last one is that, on Slide 31 when you talk about the new revenue stream, can you talk about, please, margins you would expect on those and, perhaps, if you can give extra indication on longer-term growth in these revenues because the arrow is manually drawn, but it looks like suggesting an exponential growth.

---

In relation to the first question, Alberto, the answer is very difficult. I mean, how can we be sure about the possibility of matching or not mismatching and so on. I think that all of the people familiar with the problem know that it will be something of important [indiscernible] we'll be discussing with the regulator sure that the outcome will be such if -- that we'll permit the company to maintain its equity story and to make the investment that the Italian gas market needs. For the second question, I would say that the maximum leverage -- possible answer is that we don't see in all our sensitivities. It is difficult for us to see the risk of touching level that exceed the one -- the metrics of the current ratings. One of the reference is the 60% to the RAB that you know is considered one of the reference and is difficult for us to imagine -- to touch these thresholds in the 4-year span even if some difficulties occurs. For the EUR 40 million, I would say that the guidelines is that we are discussing and we could expect support in terms of additional revenues for this 4-year plan up to EUR 40 million. It is difficult to have guidelines after the horizon of the plan.

---

Alberto, only to do some comment about the first question. If you remember, all -- the regulatory review, there is no review where we discuss with the regulator each figures. Usually, the discussion using the framework of the regulatory decision, and the regulator usually takes into account all the framework. So risk-free inflation, I don't think that the discussion will be to discuss the inflation without the other parameters, to discuss the risk free without inflation. It's not a mathematical, I can say, composition. So I imagine that the discussion and clarification will be considering the possibility to set a return, which give to the companies, in general, because it's not only Snam, there are other companies, the possibility to maintain the business flat.

---

Just 2 questions on my side. First one was on the unit costs that you mentioned, you are saying -- how you expect them to remain flat in real terms. I was just wondering if there wasn't [indiscernible] aggressive because I suspect you could think that as you expand the network, there should be some economies of scale there. So I was wondering why efficiency could actually be improved on that side on a per-unit basis. And then the second question that I had is again coming back to the review. I understand it's difficult to give some details at the moment, but again we will keep that in your point your being solo as it is today and we will have to see if any quantitative easing in Europe [indiscernible] gone any further. Do you have any sense, talking with the regulator that he may be possibly stepping away from the previous attitude of looking at the 12-month historical average as a risk-free rate and maybe take a longer term horizon on this one because we [indiscernible] that you're currently in those bond yields, one might say that it is pushing you to have, I guess, 2-year average maturity as well than on your debt, which may be not very sustainable from a financing perspective.

---

As far as this question, the guidance that we are giving in terms of operating cost is flat. In real terms, with the current parameter, does not include the possible effect of the optimization of the portfolio in the distribution and the increase of our market share in the distribution. The guidelines is maintaining the current parameter, if I catch your question. So the upside deriving from possible further optimization in our portfolio in the distribution is not included in this guidance. As far as the second question -- I mean, those are the ones that you explained -- you described are some of the large part -- large number of elements, parameters that we will discuss with the regulator in order -- with -- for the review, if not today, the time for discussing this at the -- I mean, we will have the consultation document to be commented and that will be the occasion for us for giving a contributor on the discussion.

---

I've got 3 questions. The first question is on storage. Carlo, I noted, obviously, you've got a lower CapEx in storage for next 4 years and part of that's because of the lack of, I guess, strategy clarity in Italy as well as in Europe. Can you share with us maybe what to look out for? What milestones should we be looking out for? Is there a discussion on the EU level that we should be following and I guess, once we see that, we should expect a higher CapEx in storage. So that's the first question. Second question is back to the international JV that you have with Fluxys. I recognize discussions on future investments aren't finalized. Can we just get a little bit of timelines as to when we should expect that? I assume CapEx, once announced, is over and above the amounts that you've announced today. And lastly, just very shortly on Robin Hood tax. Is there any discussion or appeals by the government on this? If you could just shed some light on that.

---

From the first question, my analysis coming from the increasing role of the storage, not only in Italy but at European level, I think that the only possibility to have resources, gas resources to substitute the take-or-pay the import in case of, let me say, lack of import gas, for example, the Russia gas and so on. I think we have enough storage today at European level. We speak about 100 bcm to consider to cover the analysis period during the winter period with the storage system. And it makes sense to pooling part of the storage for the different countries to create a reserve as we have in the oil system. There is a reason why I said today we are ready to increase the investment in storage, but I -- our objective -- our approach is to create value for our investment. To pooling the storage system at European level is a new way to create value in new storage investment. If you need to cover 4, 5 months of Russian gas, in Europe, we need roughly 40, 50 bcm of storage. So it could be, let me say, the possibility to share the existing storage if the storage or major storages remain empty or to build new storage system to guarantee a system with criteria and rules set by a European body to manage the gas exchange in the storage through the TSO, to the operators. So is the possibility to improve the storage investment, let me say, without considering only the country situation, but considering the gas need at European level. There is a reason why I said, there is no strictly connected with our CapEx plan in storage. We are investing to complete the Italian decree to resolve the Italian problem, but it makes sense to consider an evolution in the storage system at European level. With Fluxys, there is not today intention to put capital employed in the joint venture we are doing today. So it's a share of participation without capital employed right now. For the Robin tax, the question is if -- okay, frankly speaking, today the discussion -- the political discussion is to reduce anyway the corporate taxes, not to increase the corporate taxes, to improve the industrial growth. Anyway, some rumors in the last week was replacement, it's only a rumor, frankly speaking. I am not information about this type of discussion or replacement of Robin Hood with the carbon tax. Anyway, only to say that the costs related to the CO2 was non -- negligible, close to 0. So there is no impact for now.

---

I think we have exhausted more or less 2.5 hours. So I think -- thank you, everybody. And anyways, if you have additional questions, please contact the IR Department. And just remember that the press conference will follow shortly on the same location. Thank you. Bye-bye, everybody.
