But it is somewhat different from the Italian one being in Austria, the regulatory framework based on a fixed book capacity mechanism, which means that there is an exposure to the book capacity. So the quality of the quality, the structure is different. On the RAB, you know that the regulation in Austria recognized the return on equity, which is 9%, something more than 9% and the cost of debt, which is something more than 4%. That applied the first one on the 60% of the asset at reconstruction value. The other one at 40% of the asset at book value. We can give the name of RAB to the sum of the 60% and this 40%. Even if 60% is at the current level and 40% is the book level, this value is more than EUR 1 billion.

---

【回答: Carlo Malacarne (Executives)】
The second question. First of all, we have to manage the storage because we don't have the final tariff, which would be -- final tariff in July, so the problem. So we are discussing the problem of work in progress and so on. It's not a final decision. Anyway, if -- to be very clear, if that would be the final decision, the intention is to appeal to the administrative court only because the investment we are doing are linked to the Decree 130. So all the investment inside the 130 are committed -- were committed 2 years ago, first of all, but this is a -- it's not a question. The other -- for the transmission, I think is different situation because the problem of putting operations investment is very strong in the storage because the time of expanding before putting operation for the new field is 4 years, 3 years. For the transmission, we can put in operations step-by-step without this type of risk. There's no real risk in the transmission. The problem is in the storage today because we are running the investment, we started 2 years ago. So we cannot put in operation a field during the investment. It's completely different approach. That is the reason why you have to face this [indiscernible] storage because it's very different -- storage are not investment we can decide step-by-step. When we start with the field, we have to complete the field for putting in operations on a different approach.

---

【回答: Unknown Executive (Executives)】
Let's now move to the conference calls just to see if there are some questions.

---

【質問: Alberto Gandolfi (Analysts)】
Alberto Gandolfi, UBS. I have 3, please. First one is that today the 10-year bond in Italy is 1.1%, and I know the inflation used by the regulator is not the RAB deflator, but from the RAB deflator you're talking about here, it would appear that you have like a real rate of like 0.6%, 0.5%. So the question here is twofold. One, haven't you been maybe a little bit optimistic on inflation on RAB and your dividends is going to be contingent to inflation. So how do you think about the relationship between inflation and dividends, please? And secondly, what type of discussions are you having with the regulator to avoid the situation we incurred towards the end of last year when there was a clear mismatch between inflation and bond yields. Bond yield is a clear 12-month rolling average. Inflation, I still don't understand where the regulator gets it from. So how can we make sure that this time around the regulator is very congruent, consistent in establishing bond yields and inflation, so that we don't have a mismatch for a couple of years. Second one is that you talked about your ratio targets net debt divided by RAB. Can I ask you, do you have a maximum level for 2016 as well, sort of an exceptional level, could you breach that if regulator were to prove particularly harsh and could you modulate effective CapEx even further? And the last one is that, on Slide 31 when you talk about the new revenue stream, can you talk about, please, margins you would expect on those and, perhaps, if you can give extra indication on longer-term growth in these revenues because the arrow is manually drawn, but it looks like suggesting an exponential growth.

---

【回答: Antonio Paccioretti (Executives)】
In relation to the first question, Alberto, the answer is very difficult. I mean, how can we be sure about the possibility of matching or not mismatching and so on. I think that all of the people familiar with the problem know that it will be something of important [indiscernible] we'll be discussing with the regulator sure that the outcome will be such if -- that we'll permit the company to maintain its equity story and to make the investment that the Italian gas market needs. For the second question, I would say that the maximum leverage -- possible answer is that we don't see in all our sensitivities. It is difficult for us to see the risk of touching level that exceed the one -- the metrics of the current ratings. One of the reference is the 60% to the RAB that you know is considered one of the reference and is difficult for us to imagine -- to touch these thresholds in the 4-year span even if some difficulties occurs. For the EUR 40 million, I would say that the guidelines is that we are discussing and we could expect support in terms of additional revenues for this 4-year plan up to EUR 40 million. It is difficult to have guidelines after the horizon of the plan.

---

【回答: Carlo Malacarne (Executives)】
Alberto, only to do some comment about the first question. If you remember, all -- the regulatory review, there is no review where we discuss with the regulator each figures. Usually, the discussion using the framework of the regulatory decision, and the regulator usually takes into account all the framework. So risk-free inflation, I don't think that the discussion will be to discuss the inflation without the other parameters, to discuss the risk free without inflation. It's not a mathematical, I can say, composition. So I imagine that the discussion and clarification will be considering the possibility to set a return, which give to the companies, in general, because it's not only Snam, there are other companies, the possibility to maintain the business flat.

---

【質問: Olivier Van Doosselaere (Analysts)】
Just 2 questions on my side. First one was on the unit costs that you mentioned, you are saying -- how you expect them to remain flat in real terms. I was just wondering if there wasn't [indiscernible] aggressive because I suspect you could think that as you expand the network, there should be some economies of scale there. So I was wondering why efficiency could actually be improved on that side on a per-unit basis. And then the second question that I had is again coming back to the review. I understand it's difficult to give some details at the moment, but again we will keep that in your point your being solo as it is today and we will have to see if any quantitative easing in Europe [indiscernible] gone any further. Do you have any sense, talking with the regulator that he may be possibly stepping away from the previous attitude of looking at the 12-month historical average as a risk-free rate and maybe take a longer term horizon on this one because we [indiscernible] that you're currently in those bond yields, one might say that it is pushing you to have, I guess, 2-year average maturity as well than on your debt, which may be not very sustainable from a financing perspective.

---

【回答: Unknown Executive (Executives)】
As far as this question, the guidance that we are giving in terms of operating cost is flat. In real terms, with the current parameter, does not include the possible effect of the optimization of the portfolio in the distribution and the increase of our market share in the distribution. The guidelines is maintaining the current parameter, if I catch your question. So the upside deriving from possible further optimization in our portfolio in the distribution is not included in this guidance. As far as the second question -- I mean, those are the ones that you explained -- you described are some of the large part -- large number of elements, parameters that we will discuss with the regulator in order -- with -- for the review, if not today, the time for discussing this at the -- I mean, we will have the consultation document to be commented and that will be the occasion for us for giving a contributor on the discussion.

---

【質問: Maurice Choy (Analysts)】
I've got 3 questions. The first question is on storage. Carlo, I noted, obviously, you've got a lower CapEx in storage for next 4 years and part of that's because of the lack of, I guess, strategy clarity in Italy as well as in Europe. Can you share with us maybe what to look out for? What milestones should we be looking out for? Is there a discussion on the EU level that we should be following and I guess, once we see that, we should expect a higher CapEx in storage. So that's the first question. Second question is back to the international JV that you have with Fluxys. I recognize discussions on future investments aren't finalized. Can we just get a little bit of timelines as to when we should expect that? I assume CapEx, once announced, is over and above the amounts that you've announced today. And lastly, just very shortly on Robin Hood tax. Is there any discussion or appeals by the government on this? If you could just shed some light on that.

---

【回答: Carlo Malacarne (Executives)】
From the first question, my analysis coming from the increasing role of the storage, not only in Italy but at European level, I think that the only possibility to have resources, gas resources to substitute the take-or-pay the import in case of, let me say, lack of import gas, for example, the Russia gas and so on. I think we have enough storage today at European level. We speak about 100 bcm to consider to cover the analysis period during the winter period with the storage system. And it makes sense to pooling part of the storage for the different countries to create a reserve as we have in the oil system. There is a reason why I said today we are ready to increase the investment in storage, but I -- our objective -- our approach is to create value for our investment. To pooling the storage system at European level is a new way to create value in new storage investment. If you need to cover 4, 5 months of Russian gas, in Europe, we need roughly 40, 50 bcm of storage. So it could be, let me say, the possibility to share the existing storage if the storage or major storages remain empty or to build new storage system to guarantee a system with criteria and rules set by a European body to manage the gas exchange in the storage through the TSO, to the operators. So is the possibility to improve the storage investment, let me say, without considering only the country situation, but considering the gas need at European level. There is a reason why I said, there is no strictly connected with our CapEx plan in storage. We are investing to complete the Italian decree to resolve the Italian problem, but it makes sense to consider an evolution in the storage system at European level. With Fluxys, there is not today intention to put capital employed in the joint venture we are doing today. So it's a share of participation without capital employed right now. For the Robin tax, the question is if -- okay, frankly speaking, today the discussion -- the political discussion is to reduce anyway the corporate taxes, not to increase the corporate taxes, to improve the industrial growth. Anyway, some rumors in the last week was replacement, it's only a rumor, frankly speaking. I am not information about this type of discussion or replacement of Robin Hood with the carbon tax. Anyway, only to say that the costs related to the CO2 was non -- negligible, close to 0. So there is no impact for now.

---

【回答: Marco Porro (Executives)】
I think we have exhausted more or less 2.5 hours. So I think -- thank you, everybody. And anyways, if you have additional questions, please contact the IR Department. And just remember that the press conference will follow shortly on the same location. Thank you. Bye-bye, everybody.

B01BN57.eventHeadline: TERNA - Rete Elettrica Nazionale Società per Azioni, 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 26, 2015
B01BN57.transcript_text1:
Thank you. Good afternoon and welcome, everybody, to Terna's 2014 Full Year Results and Strategic Plan Presentation. I am Antonio Colombi, Head of Investor Relations. Before starting, please switch off your mobile phones for technical reasons. So we can start the event, so let me introduce our president, Catia Bastioli.

---

Good afternoon, everybody, and welcome to the presentation of Terna's Strategic Plan and Full Year Results. As you know, this is our first Strategic Plan of Terna's first board of directors. And I like to thank the board members and our management team as well as everyone who is here today and the people who are connected from Italy. The new other thing is that we are in London. This is the first presentation in London and this is a natural choice because 90% of our institutional Investor Days with all the foreign investors and a major part of them work in London. I would now like to introduce my colleagues, and first of all on the stage, Matteo del Fante, who is the CEO of Terna. Matteo, he will come to the stage. And then Pierpaolo Cristofori, who is the Chief Financial Officer of Terna. And in all, we have also board members and also the management team of Terna. So good morning -- good afternoon to everyone.
Today's agenda consists of a very short introduction on my side and then the full year results and then the strategic plan. The information that you will see confirms that Terna is a company of [indiscernible] and is a situation to become the best in class in returns [indiscernible] but also in terms of service to the Italian [indiscernible]. 
When I arrived in Terna, I found a very strong and stable business. This is a very good basis for [indiscernible], for exploiting the new opportunities from the business point of view and the decisions [ph] of the company so high that it is possible to seize new types of challenges. When I had achieved a balance in delivering strong financial results. However, these types of results is not just due to skills in financial and economical [indiscernible]

---

Thank you, Catia, thank you, everyone and good afternoon. Thank you for being here. I will start with a very short feature of our results of 2014 and [indiscernible] by our board. It's a strong sense of results. We are speaking of course across 4 metrics. Revenue achieved just shy of EUR 2 billion. We had a 5.3% [indiscernible] It was the highest contribution on activities by regulated and non-regulated activities and net of Tamini consolidations, it's still a positive result on the revenue side. And that is driving the margin increase of the EBITDA level, and 6% increase of the bottom line was in EUR 545 million net profit for the year. We got here basically with the EUR 1.1 billion CapEx in line with the plan, slightly lower than 2013. The CapEx was a standard breakdown of 80% development of the grid, 12% maintenance and other than [indiscernible], over 300 kilometers of lines and 16 substations. We had a very important increase in CapEx deployment on storage solutions. We reached end of last year over EUR 150 million investment in storage and we now run from 1st of January active the largest storage equipment in Europe for 25 megabytes [ph]. 
Finally we show you the cash flow. We generated [indiscernible].
[indiscernible]

---

Thank you and very good afternoon to everybody. As Matteo just said, 2014 has been a very good year by several measures. [indiscernible] let's see the revenues. On the revenues side, we see here we did almost EUR 2 billion here that caused [indiscernible]. We will get into the details of this plan, across the plan's presentation so we can hear from Matteo afterwards. The difference, which is EUR 11 million, refers to the usual salary dynamics and the provisions that we did across the year. Extent of costs amounted to approximately EUR 137 million with an increase of EUR 5 million as opposed to last year. Most of that, 4 of them were attributable to non-regulated activities, where, as you remember from prior slides, the difference of revenues of EUR 26 million, so that is related -- possible it's also related to other aspects. On the other cost, we reduced the total amount by EUR 9 million. Again, here, we have substantial lower penalties for the record that we did this year on quality of service, which more than offset an accrual that we did for local taxes and some other no regarding effect. So in essence, if we look overall at revenues and operating expenses, the -- we can say that the improvement in performance and the additional margins that we extracted from the nonregulated activities allowed us to accrue resources for the future cost structure of the company. In other words, we are investing on our people and our future of the company, without, of course, hitting profitability in this year.
And in fact, if you move to the next slide, you will see that EBITDA is slightly better than last year, EUR 3 million better than last year, notwithstanding the substantial provision that we did on the labor cost. And stands at approximately EUR 1.5 billion with an EBITDA margin at approximately 75%. Depreciation and amortization amounted to EUR 480 million, up EUR 30 million versus last year as a consequence of the EUR 1.1 billion investments that we did across 2013, 2014. So as a consequence of that, EBIT was slightly down last year, most of it is attributable to the additional depreciation and amortization that we had accounted in the last year.
On the financial side, financial expenses were up EUR 28 million, mainly because of the lower financial income, which is given by the expected lower yield on the invested cash. So if you look at the gross debt and the cost of the gross debt, it actually got down as opposed to last year whereby we were less efficient, so to say, because of the decrease in the yields on the active side.
Cost of gross debt has been broadly stable at 2.3% whereby on the net side, cost of gross debt
[Audio Gap]
On the tax side, we total it approximately EUR 340 million, with a sharp decrease as opposed to last year, less than -- more than EUR 18 million lower than last year, as a consequence of 2 effects, I would say. One is the decrease in the tax rate of the Robin Hood percentage, which went down during the year from 10.5% to 6.5%, and which yielded approximately 1/2 of the difference, more or less EUR 35 million. And we benefited as well from a positive adjustment of the deferred tax fund that we did over past investments due to the cancellation of the Robin Hood Tax, which happened in the first quarter of this year, but we had to account as well for the last year.
[Audio Gap]
As a result of that, our net income was up EUR 30 million, i.e. 6% vis-à-vis last year. And corresponding, as I said, that will increase of 6%.
If you move to the next slide, we will see the investment. On investment side, we invested more than EUR 1 billion, EUR 1.1 billion, across the year. Most of it on the regulated activities, actually 96% on the regulated side, where 80% of the investments refer to development of the grid and as such, they carry a special incentive, as you know. So that's the mix of what we did do last year.
Matteo has already shown some, but among the main ongoing projects that we delivered this year, we followed on the interconnection between Italy and Montenegro, [indiscernible] the cable between Sicily and Mainland. And of course, the additional amount that we spent on the storage systems as Matteo was pointing earlier, EUR 90 million this year.
The rest of the CapEx, approximately 20%, was spent on maintenance CapEx and as such, accounted with the base return.
If you look at the other CapEx, we spent more or less same amount in the last year that was referred to either nonregulated activities or capitalized financial charges, which we have to capitalize when we take into consideration long-term projects.
I would move now to probably the most important slides, at least the slides I would like you to focus more for 2014, by the way, also the last slide, so -- and it's on free cash flow. That's a new measure that we are taking into account going forward. And if you look on the left side of the slide, you will see that on free cash flow, this year, we generated EUR 260 million worth of cash as opposed to actually absorption of cash last year as a combination of factor. But if you look at the different components, i.e., operating cash flow, working capital and CapEx, on all of the 3 components, we scored better than last year.
On operating cash flow, we had certainly a positive effect on the tax side, but as well, we had less cash cost as opposed to the last year.
On working capital, we had a bigger collection of receivables, included some referred to prior years and also a useful component, I would say, was an advance payment that we received in the last quarter of the year for a grant which was related to an investment innovations that we will complete during 2015 as an effort as we will see later in the plan for being able to attract also some special resources either for international or national funds to foster our capital expenditure program.
And of course, the last component is the investment as we did EUR 100 million less investment than last year.
As a consequence of it, on the net debt side, we increased the debt by approximately slightly less than EUR 300 million, EUR 270 million, as opposed to almost EUR 800 million of the last year. And we were able to beat a little bit the forecast that we gave to you on the 9 months results. So we are slightly lower than EUR 7 billion as total net indebtedness, with cash and cash equivalents sitting at EUR 1.2 billion and with a total gross debt of EUR 8.2 billion that you see here as opposed to EUR 8.3 billion of the last year. So substantially stable in the total gross debt. We do not take into account though in this number the EUR 750 million of revolving credit facility that we committed by the end of the year and it is currently fully undrawn, but gives us a cushion of liquidity in order to fulfill our trading, as well, obligations.
So all in all, our financial structure remains solid. We have a residual average life of debt in excess of 5 years, 5.5 years, and a fixed floating ratio of 73% to -- 37%, which as you know has been consistently headed to our policy.
Last and finally, Matteo already covered the point, we have confirmed the willingness to propose a dividend for this year of EUR 0.20 per share.
That's it. So I pass the bat to Matteo for the presentation on the plan. Thank you.

---

So thank you, Pierpaolo. As a new CEO, I had the challenge to pause for a second, look at what Terna did since the IPO, 10 years. And what I discover is that we have filled the infrastructural gap in the electricity transmission space in Italy only in the last year, so we have invested in excess of EUR 8 billion. We have achieved through our investment very significant cost savings for the system, and we have done this providing an excellent result also for our shareholders with TSR above 300% in the period.
There are new challenges and we will discuss them briefly today. But what I want to confirm today is that the unchanged values and focus of Terna for the future will be to remain very conservative on risk taking and risk assessment and to focus and continue focusing on attractive and sustainable shareholder return.
Looking at the challenges briefly, and I will spend a bit more time on each of them shortly.  We clearly have a new macroeconomic scenario, which is impacting our business in several aspect. We have an ongoing change in the electricity market, both at the Italian domestic
[Audio Gap]
Of the new regulatory period kicking in next year but the negotiations are, as you well know, happening during the course of this year.
And what we have done in the plan, we have put on the table a set of management actions that are helping the bottom line of the company, the ability to generate free cash flow with the aim to sustain shareholder return. And the actions are divided, and we will spend more time today on the actions, which I think is what all of you are more interested to hear from us today, relate to increase discipline on our CapEx activities, increase -- and this is clearly an ongoing effort, but we are putting even more emphasis on OpEx discipline. We are going to have a strategy to be more selective on grid expansion, attracting also third-party financing to support our CapEx plan outside the tariff RAB. And we are putting the base for nonregulated activities to give an extra boost to our bottom line and allow us to face the challenges.
So I'll spend another very few minutes on the challenges and then we will really dig into the -- on the, sorry -- yes, and we will dig on the management actions later on.
The first challenge, as I said, is the macro scenario, low growth inflation bottoming. We start to see, and you are monitoring the space as much as we do, some preliminary signs of rebound for the economy overall, labor market, consumer confidence, hiring initiatives, that we probably and hopefully see at the energy demand level as well. In February, we registered a marginal increase on the month-over-month over 2014, we did 0.7 positive figure. Rates are very low. The Q -- the activities are bringing our 10-year risk-free rate at 1.3%. You have treasuries at almost 2%. U.S. treasuries and Italian BTPs at 1.3% is an issue for us. It's clearly, together with inflation, one of the parameters that are going into the regulatory framework, but I'm sure there are going to be question on this, so I will not spend time now on the specifics.
The second challenge or the second scenario that we face is the electricity market. And we believe that we need to look beyond Italy now. There is an energy union moving forward in Europe. We are focusing at the European level on security, solidarity and trust of supply. That goes and has to go through full integration of energy and we believe electricity grids, energy efficiency is a key theme across Europe. The council of Europe has set very specific target for 2030, as you know, 27% decrease on the consumption of energy. There is an ongoing theme on the integration of renewables that is affecting Terna in 2 ways. We need to develop the grid in such a way that we don't lose power generated by nonprogrammable renewables, but we have also to be very efficient on the dispatching market to make sure that those producers don't create problems in our balancing activities.
And finally, there is a clear message at the European level that, as our president, Catia Bastioli stated, is also very present at Terna on research, innovation and following the European focus on a -- in a green agenda and the reduction of emissions across Europe.
The third challenge, which is clearly the one that is affecting us more directly and that's the one where we're spending the bulk of our time and attention in 2015, because it's clearly driving a lot what we will be able to make next year and the following, is the regulatory review. As you know, there was a preliminary 2015, '18 guidelines document that was generically referring to secure, efficient and flexible electricity market. There are references to the integration of the Italian grid with other European Union countries.
But as you are aware, in January there was a new document, the first consultation document setting the scene for what are the criteria, preliminary criteria, that the regulator is putting on the table to be shared with us, with the market and with the other companies affected by the new regulatory regime. And we start talking there about more selective approach to CapEx. That means potentially new incentives mechanism for future CapEx from 2016 onwards. There is the opportunity to increase the attractiveness of public financing, which was not very clear in the past. It has already been clarified in the gas space and, hopefully, it will happen in the electricity domain as well. There is a mention that has been welcomed by us, and I'm sure by the financial community as well, to consider extending the regulatory period from 4 to 6 years. We're fine with that. And there are signals that the regulatory framework could evolve into more sophisticated modern [indiscernible] output-based framework that, as you are very familiar with, had been tested in the more advanced countries in Europe. We are open to that. We have answered in a positive fashion, but it takes a bit of work to put down the metrics to actually implement the new regime.
And let's now move on what we are planning to do, the actions. We have tried to organize the rest of the presentation in terms of actions in 4 pillars. CapEx discipline, how we are going to optimize our CapEx activities; grid expansion, with our usual ordinary RAB CapEx plan and third-party financing adding to that; the nonregulated business, with services, with the integration for the first year 2015 for 12 months of Tamini and interconnectors, so merchant lines that are funded by third parties and Terna plays an EPC role in the transaction; and finally, across the board, we want to bring discipline in the OpEx space and this relates to labor, organization and costs and external costs.
In dotted lines, we have -- we are pointing here to what we call potential upside in the plan. So what you see in dotted square box, the Italian railway high-voltage network is not in the plan in terms of figures. And same is not in the plan, other Italian and international EPC, BOOT business on transmission, energy efficiency and other interconnector facilities that we will be working on. All this is driving our bottom line and specifically, our EBITDA.
Putting some numbers on the pillars. We are reviewing and lowering our CapEx plan for the 5 years to 3.2 versus 3.6 we announced 1 year ago. Grid expansion, we are lowering our growth rate from 5% to 3%, but that allows us to reach EUR 13.4 billion at the end of the period. And on traditional, we are showing here cumulated revenues of EUR 400 million for services, EUR 600 million for Tamini and EUR 400 million revenues of 1 EPC interconnector transaction.
Annually, and this will kick in gradually, but sooner than the end of the plan. For sure, we are targeting EUR 30 million annual
 
[indiscernible]
On the regulated side, as all of you are aware, the most important project this year is the submarine link between Sicily and the continent that we're committed to deliver in 2015, and that would help, if you remember the beginning of my presentation, to bring also Sicily in a single market with no congestions with the rest of the continent.
Moving to the nonregulated. We have the interconnections project going on. Most of you are aware that there is a specific law that is asking us, Terna, to perform EPC and to help private energy-intensive companies to build interconnections. And we're reserving to them space basically in our public lines, so the project will move along the lines of our public interconnections with France and Montenegro. In the figures, as you will see later, we are targeting a 10% standard EPC margin for this activity specifically, where we expect, and that's why we also put the European flag, we are expecting also to have support from European funds.
In natural, I would say a logic grid extension transaction is the potential acquisition, which I repeat is not in our figures today of the Italian railway high-voltage network. The rational transaction, we believe, is very clear, optimization in terms of CapEx deployment. We can provide energy to the railways. Their network can support or can help in some specific areas improve the national grid. So it's something that would make a lot of sense for the system.
And second efficiency that we will create is that we will be able to maintain reorganizing, and this is part of what Pierpaolo anticipated, our focus on organization and labor efficiency, reorganizing our workforce because, at the moment, we are negotiating a transaction without the transfer of headcount in the perimeter of the deal.
The assets that are owned currently by Ferrovie are more than 9,000 kilometers of lines. They own more than 400 primary stations, but the process at the moment is in the hands of the regulator that is assessing also with the help of external technical support the value of the grid for the system in order to quantify a RAB and allowed return link to the RAB. And Terna will come in at that point. So for us, there is no transaction on the table until, obviously, we have a formal recognition from the regulator of what we are buying and how much what we are buying is going to yield us in terms of revenues.
The third pillar is nonregulated. And here, I repeat, our unchanged value and focus. We're going to be capital-light and keep a very low risk profile in the space. But we still wanted today to give you more concrete and meaningful numbers for the 3 main business lines that we have on nontraditionals where we are doing currently a lot of work to get those activities, especially the upside potential you don't see in the numbers, but believe me, in that bottom part of the page, there is a lot of attention and a lot of efforts from our management. But going back to what you see in the numbers, what we are committing to the market today, we have 3 business lines, as anticipated. In nontraditional, we have services that will cumulate EUR 400 million over the plan and we are assuming a 50% EBITDA margin. We have the consolidation for the full plan of Tamini at the moment, targeting a 10% margin on EUR 600 million revenues. And we have the interconnector I mentioned.
It's also very important to say that on nontraditional, the focus we are putting is both domestically and abroad on leveraging on the core capabilities of Terna. So if we want to go out of our core business that I think makes all of us, you as investor and us as management, very comfortable, if we want to go out, we believe that we want to go out with a competitive edge, and the competitive edge of Terna is the excellence in transmission. As you might remember, we were the second operator in Brazil and we still have employees. They are asking us, the employees, only a few weeks ago to go and support the operation even if we have sold, that we have no financial or legal obligation to do that, but we'll still send in our experts to support. And I can mention those and some examples where our expertise is required in the specific domain of transmission. So we are now looking outside Italy. B058ZV4.eventHeadline: Coca-Cola Icecek A.S., 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 06, 2015
B058ZV4.transcript_text1:
Good morning and good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our Year-End 2014 Results Conference Call. In this call, our CEO, Burak Basarir, will briefly talk about our operations in 2014; then our CFO, Orhun Köstem, will share with you the financial review of the year. Following Burak's closing remarks, we will start the Q&A session.
Before we begin, please kindly be advised of our cautionary statement. This conference call may contain forward-looking management comments, including projections, and these should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary language contained in this earnings release. A copy of the release and financials are available on our website at cci.com.tr.
Now let me turn the call over to Burak.

---

Well, thank you, Deniz. Good afternoon, everyone. As you know, 2014 was a very challenging year for the beverage business, both in Turkey and international operations. Despite tough headwinds, CCI delivered 7% consolidated volume growth and double-digit revenue growth.
In 2014, transactions grew ahead of the volume growth in Turkey. In line with our long-term strategy, transitions towards immediate consumption packages in the sparkling category continued in Turkey. Accordingly, transaction figures for IC packages continue to increase, which creates opportunity by new recruitment and supports profitability of the category in the long run.
CCI delivered very strong performance in international operations as well, despite the macro and geopolitical situations in key markets, including recent devaluations in Central Asia and declining oil prices, political instability in Pakistan and Iraq.
In 2014, international operations showed double-digit top line growth and a marginal EBITDA margin increase. CCI generated positive free cash flow in 2014 despite the high CapEx additions, especially in international operations.
Now let me turn into our contribution to growth for the past year. Turkey sales volume increased by 1%, adding 4 million unit cases; and international operations delivered 14% growth, adding 69 million unit cases to our top line volume numbers. Year-to-date total volume growth was almost in the 3 million cases, resulting in 7% over a strong 13% growth of last year.
International sales volume now account about 49% of our total volume compared to 46% a year ago. International sales contribution is led by Pakistan at 21%; Iraq 9%; and Kazakhstan 9% of our total consolidated volume.
How did we do on the category side in 2014? We grew across all beverage categories, which is a great news. Sparkling is 71% of our total volume mix, and the category posted 5% growth, driven by our 3 core brands: Coca-Cola, Coca-Cola Zero, Fanta, Sprite and particularly in the international operations.
Still, excluding water, grew by 16%, led by mainly juice and iced tea categories. Water, on the other hand, grew by 11% in the same period. As still beverages' portfolio growth was higher than sparkling in the last year, the share of the stills category in the total mix was slightly down.
Now let's briefly review Turkey operations. Overall, Turkey volume growth slowed down as the sparkling category contracted 5%, while still category posted double-digit growth, driven mainly by juice and iced tea segments. The shift of sales mix towards immediate consumption packages continued in all categories, creating recruitment opportunities in our Turkish franchise.
In 2014, the construction in -- contraction in future consumption packages adversely impacted sparkling category expansion, and hence, weighed on the volume growth in Turkey.
On the other hand, total transaction numbers in sparkling categories were almost flat due to strong iced tea performance, despite the contraction of the category. In line with our strategy to address health and wellness trends, sugar-free segment continued its strong growth.
Coca-Cola Zero grew almost 50%. The new product launch of Coca-Cola Zero PET 2.5-liter in the first quarter surpassed Zero PET 1.5-liter in the third quarter, so far with the strong growth.
While sugar-free segment makes only 3% of our total sparkling volume, we believe there's a substantial opportunity for sugar-free segment growth going forward. 
Still beverages, excluding water, grew at high teens in 2014 on the back of double-digit growth both in iced tea and juice categories. Cappy brand maintained its strong momentum, with all subcategories posting over 10% overall growth.
Fuse Tea delivered over 50% volume growth, supported by successful IC pack introductions, such as can 250ml and 500ml packages and new peach sugar-free flavor expansion.
The water category grew at 5% in 2014 despite the contraction in Home and Office Delivery segment, as the focus on profitable growth of water category to iced tea packages in the total portfolio continue to increase.
The non-ready-to-drink tea category grew by 12% in 2014. As you know, we only do sales and distribution of our Dogadan brand.
In 2014, while average price increases was only 4% in Turkey, the fourth quarter average price increased by 16%, thanks to the increase of the high-selling, large-factor [indiscernible] effective from October '14, as well as the favorable package mix.
We are starting 2015 with a better price base in Turkey, which will support margins, given the stable outlook in raw material prices, but of course, the currency fluctuations will always be on our radar screen.
Now let's move into international operations. In line with our guidance, international operations delivered mid-teens growth in 2014, with substantial market share gains below our median markets.
Pakistan posted 17% volume growth in 2014 despite the devastating floods, political unrest in the high season. In 2014, Pakistan's growth rate was in line with last 5 years' average growth. We led industry growth with a market share increase from 31% in 2013 to 35% in '14.
Now let me throw down the line that the Coca-Cola brand is that #1 cola brand in Pakistan. Successful campaigns such as returnable glass bottle 250ml under-the-cap promotion, surprise promotion Fanta flavor launch and the Ramadan campaign supported the strong volume growth in Pakistan.
Central Asia posted 16% volume growth. Kazakhstan, the largest market in the region, delivered 19% volume growth in 2014, supported by market share gains in the sparkling category. Our market share gain in the sparkling category increased from 48% in 2013 to 49% in 2014. Both sparkling and iced tea categories posted double-digit volume growth in Kazakhstan, in spite of sharp devaluation in February and unfavorable weather conditions in Kazakhstan.
Successful Nowruz, FIFA World Cup and Fanta Youth Festival campaigns supported the volume growth across the Central Asia.
Middle East posted 7% volume growth in '14. On the back of the security situation in Iraq, as we all know, Iraq volume grew by 6%, with strong organic growth in South, compensating for the contraction in the northern part of the country.
Sparkling category market share in Iraq increased from 22% in 2013 to 29% on the back of continuous improvement in our Iraq market, the market execution and successful marketing campaigns.
In addition with our plants, we brought production records in high season in almost every geography we operate in, in the international operations. And our new facilities in Multan, Pakistan; Astana, Kazakhstan; and Dushanbe, Tajikistan are planned to be operational in the second quarter.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Orhun for an update on the financials.

---

Thank you, Burak. Good morning, and good afternoon, everyone. Before I move on to and talk about the numbers, let me briefly give, as always, a backdrop of the financial information. Coca-Cola Icecek reports in Turkish liras. Our international operations and functional reporting currencies are U.S. dollar, except for Pakistan, where the functional currency is rupee and reporting currency is dollars. So therefore, it is quite important we understand the Turkish lira movement against, especially dollar, and the inflation prevailing at the time of the financial statement.
The annual inflation in 2014 was 8.2%. And if you look at the average dollar tier rate, it has moved about 8.6% -- sorry, 14.9%, and year-on-year FX rate has moved about 8.6%. So quite a bit of volatility on that front.
And if you move over to talk about the financial performance that's on Slide 11, I will not necessarily go through the volume performance. Burak has given a thorough analysis of the commercial performance, basically, other than saying on volume trends, we're pretty much in line with our original guidance, which was high-single digit. But obviously, the constituents or the contribution to that performance has been different between -- among different geographies.
In Turkey, first of all, we've seen a net revenue growth of about 5% in 2014. And as you remember in our earlier discussions, the revenue growth for most parts of the year was slow in Turkey and primarily driven by mix effect, rather than price increases. And such increases are implemented in the last quarter of the year, so therefore, on a per-unit-case basis, you've seen the last quarter prices in Turkey coming up just under 16%, as we had described in our last call, basically.
On the international side, on dollar basis, the revenues were up by, again, just under 12%. The average prices throughout 2014 was 2% less than 2013, mainly by 2 reasons, one of them is obviously the devaluation that we've seen in Kazakhstan, the 19% devaluation of tenge was actually quite visible in the revenue line. But otherwise, the markets where we have relatively lower net revenue per case, which is obviously, Iraq and Pakistan, continue to have a higher share in the overall mix.
If we move on to the other page, which is 12, to talk about the profitability. Obviously, as we discussed, we've seen quite a favorable year in terms of raw material pricing in 2014.
In Turkey, the resin prices were down, of course, in mid-teens; aluminum prices were down, can prices were down in the low-single digit. The only raw material item which had a price increase was sugar. And as you remember, the prices of sugar in Turkey increased by about 10% in June.
However, the gross profit margin in Turkey actually contracted by just over 200 basis points and was realized at 39.8% in 2014 for 2 reasons, obviously: one, a slow revenue per-case growth throughout 2014; and then the impact of currency volatility, that was instrumental in Turkey's overall cost base.
If you look at the international operations, the cost of sales was more or less -- the growth in cost of sales was about 11.4%, which was more or less in line with the net sales growth. And our gross profit margin was up by 20 basis points to 32.80%.
Similar to Turkey, we have seen a quite favorable raw material environment. And of course, unlike Turkey, we have seen favorable prices for sugar as well in many of our markets, usually to the tune of high single to low double digits in 2014. So on a consolidated basis, our gross margin contracted to 36.4%. That's, again, primarily driven by the gross margin contraction of the Turkish business.
If you look at the operating expenses, the operating expenses in Turkey increased by about 4%. If you look at 2014 in general, in international operations, our OpEx per unit case was flat. So from this angle, actually, less contribution toward potential profit leak at the OpEx level. Having said that, of course, our EBIT and EBITDA numbers, obviously, reflecting the impact of the gross margin contraction.
In Turkey, EBIT was down by 16%, with about 200 basis points contraction of EBIT margin to about 80%. And EBITDA margin was down just under 300 basis points or about 12%.
On the international side, our EBIT was up by 11%. EBIT margin was flat, about 12.7%, 12.8% levels. And then EBITDA, again, increased by about 12%, and our EBITDA margin remained flat. So all in all, if you look at on a consolidated basis, we've seen an EBITDA margin contraction of about 110 basis points.
Now if you look -- go back and compare to our initial guidance for 2014, you'd remember, we first expected a flat EBITDA margin and revised it to a contraction under 150 basis points. Basically, what has taken place is that we have looked -- we've seen quite a, I think, important achievement on the international front, given that the things that has been taking place from devaluation in Kazakhstan and war breaking out in Iraq and floods and political volatility in Pakistan, these are our largest markets of operation outside of Turkey, we have been able to maintain the profitability together with the growth of the business.
Obviously, the original plan potentially was to expand the margins across international territories, but given the backdrop in 2014, we believe we delivered successfully in those markets. And Turkey, again, given the pricing policy that we described to you a year ago, we were expecting the margin contractions, so therefore, at the end of the year, we've seen a margin contraction in line or a bit better than our margin revision that we presented to you back in November.
Now if you look at the financial expenses and break it down, that's on Page 13, our interest income is almost flat, although our interest expense has increased by about TRY 50 million. That's obviously a function of us refinancing the debt on our balance sheet, which was basic in 2013, which was basically bank debt with a short-term maturity of 1.5 years on average, with a longer-term debt instruments, such as the Eurobond and product placement, which brought our average maturity at the end of 2014 to under -- just under 4 years, 3.6 years, but of course, bears to highest interest expense.
The FX loss, unrealized FX loss in 2014 was half of that in 2013 at TRY 149 million. So overall, if you look at the net-net financial expenses from TRY 257 million a year ago, it came down to TRY 194 million -- minus TRY 194 million in 2014.
Again, together with the EBIT performance and together with the financial income in the FX, and the FX loss has come down to TRY 93 million from about TRY 200 million to TRY 203 million. And in 2013, we saw our net income increasing by 28% to TRY 315 million in 2014.
Now the source of those financial expenses, if you go on to the next slide, which is 14, I've mentioned that, actually, on gross terms, has declined to TRY 1,140,000,000. But at the same time, our cash has also declined in the same period. And if you look at our net financial debt, our net financial debt has moved from $750 million to about $812 million at the end of 2014.
You would remember, end of 2013, there is still cash that we're carrying and debt that we're carrying in our balance sheet, that lead then into 2014, met the bank that we had closed down with the proceeds we received from Eurobond and private placement. So both a decrease of -- debt and decrease of cash are due to that -- possibly due to that movement as well. The majority of our debt is in foreign currency. Obviously, 86% is in dollars. Some -- about 13% is Pakistan rupees, basically. And as we discussed, it has a duration of about 3.6 years.
And the last part of our debt is now maturing in 2018. Our net debt has moved from 1.8x to just under 2x, 1.96x at the end of 2014, still at just under the level we want to maintain, which is about -- or at the level that we might maintain our net debt-to-EBITDA result, which, as you know, is about 2x in general.
And if you move to the cash flow performance, we believe one area which we have been able to manage quite successfully is the components of the cash flow. If you look at our net operating cash -- cash flow generated from our operating activities has increased by about 13% in 2014. Now that's a function of also our management of our net working capital, where we're reducing net working capital as a percentage of revenues from 13% a year ago to 11.3% in 2014.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. On behalf of the Investment Analysts Society in Southern Africa, we would like to thank at the outset, Sanlam, Dr. Johan van Zyl, members of the board, the executive for hosting us here today in the presentation of the results for the period ending December 2014.
Sanlam is one of the pillars of South African society. It is the custodian of people savings and of investments and in more recent years focused on capitalizing on the opportunities in the emerging markets of this world.
Sanlam was formed, came into being or just after the first World War in 1918. It is a mutual company and demutualized itself in 1998. It is -- today, it has a market capitalization of ZAR 160 billion. It is one of the top biggest companies in South Africa in terms of market capitalization, and employees just on 13,000 people, and it is the home for people savings and also for employment. As I said, there is full of society, and this is manifested in the share price, which has risen from some ZAR 6, some 12x to 13x over the past few years since listing. So Dr. van Zyl and to the members of the management, who will be addressing us this morning, once again, thank you, and we look forward to having greater insight into Sanlam as a company, as an enterprise the past, the present and the future.  Thank you.

---

Thank you so much for that kind introduction. It's always nice to be hosted by the Investment Analysts Society here in Johannesburg when we do announce our results. Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. Welcome. We will be talking a bit on what we've done in the last year, but before we start just a bit of welcome and I would like to welcome the Sanlam Chairman, Desmond Smith, the Chairman of our Audit and Risk Committee -- Audit Committee; Philip Rademeyer, number of executives that we have over here, Yegs Ramiah, [indiscernible], Themba Gamedze. I see Temba Mvusi here. Hubert Brody that's joined us recently from Imperial. And then, people will help me with the presentation, Ian Kirk, our CEO-Designate and presently the Deputy CEO of Sanlam; Kobus Möller, our Financial Director; and also Andre Zeeman, our Chief Actuary and Risk Officer.
Ladies and gentlemen, I'll be handling mainly the strategy and the operating environment. If we start off, then we will have Kobus Möller talking a bit about strategic delivery, and what has happened into the financial review. Priorities will be handled in the businesses by Ian and I will end off with 1 or 2 things that we plan to do in the rest of the year and issues that we have to look out for.
If we really look at the strategy, it is all about maximizing shareholder value. And we have a diagram that we really would like to drive in our own case returns on group equity value, which is the measure that we put forward. This is how we incentivized. This is how we measure ourselves. And in order to do that, we have a whole lot of strategic pillars within the business. We want to grow the business, operational efficiencies. Key part is capital optimization, diversification, transforming our business. And then, there's a whole lot of other strategic enablers like concentricity, doing the right thing, responsible -- products, a prosperous society.  These are the things that we focus on. If we really look at the key part of what we do. South Africa is still our home. It is a big part of what we do. We have a mature business here. So it's really about maximizing the return on the South African business. There is a lot of efficiencies and effectiveness issues that we have to do and that we have to drive out efficiencies, so it's about getting the return on our investment, a lot of it is mature. This is where we get the cash flow. This is where we get the dividend that we actually pay.
And then through the process on the right, the capital management, drive out the surplus capital as old more capital policy -- or capital-intensive policies mature, using that capital, using some of the profit to apply to -- into higher growth areas, where we get higher returns, so it's really about that sourcing of new growth opportunities, making the investments and then growing those businesses and through both investment, but increasingly so also through organic growth, because our footprint is also quite big.
And that is the story. It's been the story for a while. And we think there is quite a bit of it left. A few remarks on the operating environment. The environment is being fairly tough. Not the toughest that we've seen, but it is a difficult environment to operate in.
The business environment itself is characterized by weak global economy. It's not only low-growth rates in South Africa and unemployment that is driving things, but the pressure on the South African economy, I think, is very prevalent, and we also see it in our own numbers. Global demand has dropped off quite a bit, particularly for resources. We've seen in our own economy also substantial industrial action and we were impacted heavily by it.
In our Sanlam Sky business, for instance, we write quite a bit of our business in the platinum area. Rustenburg has been one of our major branches. And as we know, for full on 6 months last year, we sold way under what should have been done in that area, because of industrial action. Just as we got that right and got that going, we had low churning and other things that put pressure on how people see it and then their ability to save.
And all of this, resulted in relatively low level of growth in the economy, but particularly so in disposable income with large segments of our particular retail client being under pressure.
In Africa, outside of South Africa, much more resilience despite pressure on income from resources, also in the oil-producing countries, but a lot of currency volatility, fortunately increasingly. We are about a basket of areas that we work in. It is about a portfolio of businesses. And in that lies an inherent stability. We focus on those areas, where there are opportunities and maybe close to that a little bit, where we have headwinds. And overall, the result is a very pleasing one.
And India, growth is below the long-term potential, but massive optimism after the elections with share prices goes on doubling in the last few months or so. Investment markets, lots of volatility and lots of momentum investors and so forth, and particularly the value investors being hurt in many areas.
Lots of risk aversion in the market, and very difficult to get things right. But having said that a few numbers here, you can see the economy, the growth and so not doing very well. And in the long term, this is the picture that we have to play in about 70%, 75% of our business. This is the CAR that we've been built with. It is a tough one.  So increasingly, we're diversified. If you look at interest rates, a key part of our results and how things go forward. This is the 2 top lines there. The 9-year bond rate and the 5-year bond rate determine actually our discount rates for our middle market and our lower end of the market both of them.
And if you really look at the top there, we've seen a 10 basis points lower discount rate that we're using for the middle and the affluent market, which has had a slightly positive effect and negative effect coming from the increase in the discount rate for the lower end of the market. The net value of new business impacting about 2% negatively by not so much. I think the absolute levels of the curve much more the point than the shape of where we're at. So new business margin because of those movements about 5 basis points down. But by and large, I think not much movement coming from interest rates.
You've seen a slight pickup in the short-term interest rates, which of course a 20 basis points tick up there, a slight tick up you can see in the lower end. The short-term interest rates, we have a lot of cash that we've invested at that rate, so our profit being slightly higher on that.
If we look at the equity markets, a major driver is that average Alsi up about 17% in the 2 years. We haven't had as great a year in 2014 as in the previous year. And this has resulted, of course, negatively on particularly our headline earnings, where we include a lot of our investment and Kobus will talk a bit about that.
But by and large, I think fairly pleasant picture on the bond side as well. On average, a higher base and because we didn't fizz in our asset management type business off the base, you would see the base was 17% up. We've done pretty well in those businesses.
If you really look at the exchange rates, increasingly as we move offshore, these things do impact us. The rand weakened about most of the pillar, against most of the developed currencies, where we operate. And you would see places like the U.K. and Europe having a bigger contribution to our profits, because the rand is weakened. That has helped us. In Botswana and India less so, but still a strengthening of those currencies relative to the rand. The rest of Africa, though, I spoke about currency volatility at the beginning, you can see we've been hurt by those currencies weakening against the rand by 3%.   Overall, the net result from financial services, our operating profit up 1.7% because of currency issues.
New business volumes up by about 1.4%, but value of new business coming mainly out of Africa down by 0.3%. So not too much, but overall a positive contribution coming from the currency valuation. 
If we look at what's been achieved in the past year in the delivery, a key part of what we're driving [indiscernible], of course, the results. But we really look at the business quite carefully. We do a lot of investment into the business upfront, incur new business strength as long as that is positive, and which it makes our hurdle rate, so that we can get the profits into the future. We treat a lot of our business like that. It is all about capital, the management, the investment decision and so. Within that sort of a framework, our net operating profit per share increased by a very credible 26% over the past year. We're very just about that, normalized headline earnings a bit lower, mainly because the market didn't contribute as much in the past year, only about a 10% increase in the market as opposed to close to -- well, close to 20% increase in the previous period. So normalized headline earnings fairly flat. And in that, we incurred quite a bit of new business strength, because of the growth that you see below. New business volumes up 18% on how you know across the board, net funding flows up ZAR 42 billion. Those things don't mean as much. They're very positive and but you know an indication that things have gone well. They say nothing about margin. If we look about the margin stuff, our net life value of new business up 21%, up to ZAR 1.6 billion. And that of course, a big chunk of that incurs new business strength, particularly on the risk side, the EB side and so forth. This is where we had a negative impact because of the high growth on the actual profit that we've shown. But we will talk about that later when Kobus comes with his financial results. The margin is fairly flat on a per product basis maintained a bit of mix towards the higher or the lower yielding margins, more savings products in South Africa as opposed to risk and that sort of thing.
Group equity value, which is really a key part of what we try to drive. Group equity value at the end of December was of last year, ZAR $46.84 per share. We're pretty proud of what is being achieved there with a return on group equity value over the past year of 18.5%. On a normalized basis, that can help the market, which has been fairly flat about 18% return. This is how we measure ourselves. We have hurdles that we would like to achieve, and that is probably the main reason why we trade at the -- as the share price trade at substantially above the group embedded value. It is because our return is substantially more than simply the unwind of the discount rate.
So overall, if we look at the efficiencies in the business, the trick is not to only be bigger, but to be better. And the big part of it lies in growing the value of new business. I'm very happy to say that this has been a recurring story with about another 20% increase gross value of new business, 20% up over the period. In EB, we've had a very large single policy at a bit of a lower margin, overall, it decreased the margin a little bit. You would see that coming down. But on a per product basis, the margin very similar to the previous years, and increasingly you see the new territories that we've added and how it just makes a difference with the cherry on top. We're very proud of what is being achieved here. As I've said, of course, this incurs quite substantial new business trends on the risk in EB side, with EB's contribution being a major part of the growth there. And therefore, it's -- it impacted negatively on operating profit, despite of that still the 26% growth is very credible.
Quality is key for us. We don't like to write business that will disappear before we made our money. You've see a slight uptick in 2013 in the second half from -- in lapses, surrenders fully paid ups. I've always said that any fool can sell a $2 ice cream for $1 and some people in the short term industry are quite good at that. I think Sanlam over a period of time -- Santam has demonstrated that it knows how to balance this issue of growth and profit. And to achieve the growth if you strip out the sell business to achieve 12% for the 20 -- almost a 25% market share in these tough times is an incredible achievement, given that the margin also moved up well above the top end of the target range. So business is in good shape, far more diversified now. It's got a good -- very strong positioning in the traditional intermediated space and the Specialist space, it's got unique positioning moving that into Africa and they got the direct business, which has started with short-term insurance, now moving into the small business insurance and into the life and then that model as well. It won't be just the South African story, it will also be a story in Africa. And I think this move into Africa and India Southeast Asia on the Specialist business side is also very important. On the Santam side, it's a 3-legged stool, so the investment is made, then we moved the Specialist business in there and then we moved the reinsurance business in there as well. And you can see, if you strip out and if you look at the results of Santam, you'll see the significant increase in businesses has been sourced into the Santam group from the strategy from outside of South Africa. But of course, the focus has to remain on pricing accuracy, on managing the supply chain, on improving the risk management on the ground, in Specialist businesses, in particular, you've got to make sure that you're on the good risks and that you're not on the bad risks? Because if you're on the bad risks at the wrong rate, you can really get clobbered. And that can be seen as well. And that's why it's important to work with other stakeholders. 
We’re pleased to see the new minister now taking control in Corporate Governance and Traditional Affairs. He is talking about the back-to-basic strategy. He is talking about pairing up the particularly distressed municipalities with the stronger ones. It was some of the political guys have jumped onto that. But we know from the discussions with the minister and the from the local government authorities, that there's a really need to move these very weak municipalities with the stronger ones. Fearing is very, very important. And it's a critical component for us in the Santam business, as you know, because the risk on the ground is influenced by storm water drainage systems and building protection systems and et cetera or all with come adherence to that. So those are really the priorities. Business -- the business is in good shape and the strategies are well-indoctrinated within the business [indiscernible] aligned around that. So I'll now hand back to Johan to take us through the outlook.

Thank you, Ian. Not bad for 7 weeks -- 9 weeks, sorry. I missed the 2. It must have been the last 2 weeks. I have only one slide and I need to talk a little bit on the outlook and what we see. We don't expect a massively quick increase in the economic growth expectations in most regions. In fact, we believe that we are in for a tougher period with a lot of volatility and then particularly, commodity-based economies will struggle. People like ourselves. And, therefore, we have to set the business up to be able to deal with some of these headwinds in conjunction with what is happening in the economy, we've had tremendous investment market returns of the past 4, 5 years. And certainly, since 2009, well above the average. We think the ratings are becoming much more demanding. And from here forward, it will be quite tougher to, again, achieve those sort of returns. Therefore, we think we're in for a bit more volatility looking forward. And therefore, you know we're likely to decrease our exposure in terms of simple equity exposure. But a big part of our business is still based on average value of assets under management and things like that. And we think there will be some headwinds there, but we are preparing for that, and I think we're well-priced with a diversified base different countries and so to take quite a bit of this expected strength out of our results. A big focus is on the growth areas in the world. And that will -- 2 or 3 pockets in South Africa, but increasingly into Africa the emerging markets and then 2 or 3 niche areas also on the high end of what we're doing. In these cases, we still think in spite of the headwinds, we can grow our offshore base quite substantially by investing a bit more money as we have, but increasingly by growing our existing investments. We already have substantial, when you look at the group equity value of over ZAR 20 billion outside of South Africa. If we keep on growing this close to 30%, it will have a massive effect on carrying the whole of the Sanlam return towards a higher base. And I think we priced for that, but we see a lot of that happening. So there's been a big focus on rather getting to grow the business increasingly, the deal that we've done with Santam, taking a 35% equity stake in our General Insurance, a deal with getting our people from Sanlam Investments involved in growing our businesses into Africa. And so increasingly getting skin on the table and growing things, I think, will be a key part. 
And if I look at the challenge that Ian will have and his new team that he will set up in the next few years, it's in a way Sanlam-izing a lot of these investments that we've done in the past year, corporatizing them a bit more, getting more of our people in there so that we cannot only drive the relationship part of things but also the actual result to the excellence and levels of excellence that we're used to here in South Africa. 
There's a number of investment opportunities under consideration. We know that, and we've been waiting for a long time to increase our stake in India. You would have seen our Indian partners are -- for the first times in their 40 years or so are cash fash[ph] through the injection of money into that business. So we'll be partnering them in the areas surrounding India. They have a lot of human capital, great people there and then expanding our Shriram base into some of the surrounding countries into Southeast Asia. I think that's a good strategy for us where we -- becoming thin on people. We've added close to 15 countries that we operate in the past 4, 5 years and from most South African companies would be a bit of a stretch coming from Bellville maybe more so, but we've done pretty well. We have this first mover advantage and is really capitalizing on that. 
And then the last word, ladies and gentlemen, is on regulatory change. We know it's part and parcel of where we operate, and we can't hide behind the fact that the South African economies will govern.  I mean we haven't fallen over in 2007, '08. We haven't massive failures of companies because of bad management and these kinds of things. But in spite of that, we have what is happening in the rest of the world, if you know citizens' brain for blood. And it reminds me of my friend, GT Ferreira, who often talks about save the brain for blood. He says a mule likes to talk much more about his mother, the horse, than his father, the donkey. So people only talk about the great things that they've achieved and so forth. In our own case, I think we have a solid thing. We have great things. In spite of that, we also have to look at the downside, which is what is happening elsewhere and have become part and parcel for the course. 
We have SAM. Many of these initiatives that we've been talking about and planning for many years are now on us. From next year onwards, this is how we'll run the business. This year onwards, we have a dual SAM measurement and the old basis of looking at how we calculate Solvency and economic capital and so forth. And we're feeling our way towards that. We don't know yet. And therefore, on the capital side, we haven't been massively expansive on how we treat capital. We've been treating this, we think, very responsibly and conservatively. We have enough capital, but we're not going to run around and do stupid things now only a year later to say, "Well, we need some of that capital back." It's a key part of how we operate. And the rest of the year will be used to sort that out. 
The TCF regime, that has been with us for a while and that we've been battling with, particularly conflict of interest, the whole area about do we pay commissions, do we pay fees and a whole range of things. What sort of product do we have? Do we expand into savings even though we know at the lower end, for small amounts, there's no value to the client? But in South Africa, we need to save. It's an imperative. We've chosen, for a long time, not to go into areas where we can't clearly illustrate to the client this value. These are things that we have to look at. Now there are new opportunities. We got Treasury to agree that we need, at least on the lower end of the market, a product that is very tax friendly, low fees to really get the savings rate up, so we'll be pushing part of that. 
And then on the retail distribution review, which has been announced, we're in negotiations with the government. There's a lot of to-ing and fro-ing. They have a massive slew of regulations. We believe, from industry side, by focusing on 4 or 5 top things, like what we do business, we can achieve maybe about 90% of the result instead of trying to drown ourselves in regulation and so forth. I think we've made good progress on this. 
Within Sanlam, we've already done a lot of work, and we've prepared ourselves over the past 5 years. We have a business in the U.K., where we can see what is coming our way. Therefore, nothing is new to us. It's simply the implementation thereof. But it takes time away from focusing on the future, and it gets a lot of our effort and focus and time focusing on the past. It is becoming more difficult to do business. We know that. But within this framework, it is not trying to outrun the lion. I think it's being faster than the competition, and we've done a lot of that work. I think we will sit and thinking about the opportunities really going forward. We have a solid base, many moving parts and a lot of option value in this moving forward. 
With those few remarks, ladies and gentlemen, I want to end off that we're very proud of our results. I think the operational part is great but of additional new business trend that we've encountered because of the high growth levels but overall, a very solid result across the board. 
I would now like to invite a few people to come and help me with answering questions, Kobus Möller on our results, Andre Zeeman on the actuarial stuff and Ian on some of the general issues and maybe Santam. Please come and join me here in the front. And if you do have a question, ladies and gentlemen, just ask your name -- announce your name and fire away.

【プレゼン: Unknown Executive (Executives)】
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. On behalf of the Investment Analysts Society in Southern Africa, we would like to thank at the outset, Sanlam, Dr. Johan van Zyl, members of the board, the executive for hosting us here today in the presentation of the results for the period ending December 2014.
Sanlam is one of the pillars of South African society. It is the custodian of people savings and of investments and in more recent years focused on capitalizing on the opportunities in the emerging markets of this world.
Sanlam was formed, came into being or just after the first World War in 1918. It is a mutual company and demutualized itself in 1998. It is -- today, it has a market capitalization of ZAR 160 billion. It is one of the top biggest companies in South Africa in terms of market capitalization, and employees just on 13,000 people, and it is the home for people savings and also for employment. As I said, there is full of society, and this is manifested in the share price, which has risen from some ZAR 6, some 12x to 13x over the past few years since listing. So Dr. van Zyl and to the members of the management, who will be addressing us this morning, once again, thank you, and we look forward to having greater insight into Sanlam as a company, as an enterprise the past, the present and the future.  Thank you.
