【プレゼン: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
Thank you so much for that kind introduction. It's always nice to be hosted by the Investment Analysts Society here in Johannesburg when we do announce our results. Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. Welcome. We will be talking a bit on what we've done in the last year, but before we start just a bit of welcome and I would like to welcome the Sanlam Chairman, Desmond Smith, the Chairman of our Audit and Risk Committee -- Audit Committee; Philip Rademeyer, number of executives that we have over here, Yegs Ramiah, [indiscernible], Themba Gamedze. I see Temba Mvusi here. Hubert Brody that's joined us recently from Imperial. And then, people will help me with the presentation, Ian Kirk, our CEO-Designate and presently the Deputy CEO of Sanlam; Kobus Möller, our Financial Director; and also Andre Zeeman, our Chief Actuary and Risk Officer.
Ladies and gentlemen, I'll be handling mainly the strategy and the operating environment. If we start off, then we will have Kobus Möller talking a bit about strategic delivery, and what has happened into the financial review. Priorities will be handled in the businesses by Ian and I will end off with 1 or 2 things that we plan to do in the rest of the year and issues that we have to look out for.
If we really look at the strategy, it is all about maximizing shareholder value. And we have a diagram that we really would like to drive in our own case returns on group equity value, which is the measure that we put forward. This is how we incentivized. This is how we measure ourselves. And in order to do that, we have a whole lot of strategic pillars within the business. We want to grow the business, operational efficiencies. Key part is capital optimization, diversification, transforming our business. And then, there's a whole lot of other strategic enablers like concentricity, doing the right thing, responsible -- products, a prosperous society.  These are the things that we focus on. If we really look at the key part of what we do. South Africa is still our home. It is a big part of what we do. We have a mature business here. So it's really about maximizing the return on the South African business. There is a lot of efficiencies and effectiveness issues that we have to do and that we have to drive out efficiencies, so it's about getting the return on our investment, a lot of it is mature. This is where we get the cash flow. This is where we get the dividend that we actually pay.
And then through the process on the right, the capital management, drive out the surplus capital as old more capital policy -- or capital-intensive policies mature, using that capital, using some of the profit to apply to -- into higher growth areas, where we get higher returns, so it's really about that sourcing of new growth opportunities, making the investments and then growing those businesses and through both investment, but increasingly so also through organic growth, because our footprint is also quite big.
And that is the story. It's been the story for a while. And we think there is quite a bit of it left. A few remarks on the operating environment. The environment is being fairly tough. Not the toughest that we've seen, but it is a difficult environment to operate in.
The business environment itself is characterized by weak global economy. It's not only low-growth rates in South Africa and unemployment that is driving things, but the pressure on the South African economy, I think, is very prevalent, and we also see it in our own numbers. Global demand has dropped off quite a bit, particularly for resources. We've seen in our own economy also substantial industrial action and we were impacted heavily by it.
In our Sanlam Sky business, for instance, we write quite a bit of our business in the platinum area. Rustenburg has been one of our major branches. And as we know, for full on 6 months last year, we sold way under what should have been done in that area, because of industrial action. Just as we got that right and got that going, we had low churning and other things that put pressure on how people see it and then their ability to save.
And all of this, resulted in relatively low level of growth in the economy, but particularly so in disposable income with large segments of our particular retail client being under pressure.
In Africa, outside of South Africa, much more resilience despite pressure on income from resources, also in the oil-producing countries, but a lot of currency volatility, fortunately increasingly. We are about a basket of areas that we work in. It is about a portfolio of businesses. And in that lies an inherent stability. We focus on those areas, where there are opportunities and maybe close to that a little bit, where we have headwinds. And overall, the result is a very pleasing one.
And India, growth is below the long-term potential, but massive optimism after the elections with share prices goes on doubling in the last few months or so. Investment markets, lots of volatility and lots of momentum investors and so forth, and particularly the value investors being hurt in many areas.
Lots of risk aversion in the market, and very difficult to get things right. But having said that a few numbers here, you can see the economy, the growth and so not doing very well. And in the long term, this is the picture that we have to play in about 70%, 75% of our business. This is the CAR that we've been built with. It is a tough one.  So increasingly, we're diversified. If you look at interest rates, a key part of our results and how things go forward. This is the 2 top lines there. The 9-year bond rate and the 5-year bond rate determine actually our discount rates for our middle market and our lower end of the market both of them.
And if you really look at the top there, we've seen a 10 basis points lower discount rate that we're using for the middle and the affluent market, which has had a slightly positive effect and negative effect coming from the increase in the discount rate for the lower end of the market. The net value of new business impacting about 2% negatively by not so much. I think the absolute levels of the curve much more the point than the shape of where we're at. So new business margin because of those movements about 5 basis points down. But by and large, I think not much movement coming from interest rates.
You've seen a slight pickup in the short-term interest rates, which of course a 20 basis points tick up there, a slight tick up you can see in the lower end. The short-term interest rates, we have a lot of cash that we've invested at that rate, so our profit being slightly higher on that.
If we look at the equity markets, a major driver is that average Alsi up about 17% in the 2 years. We haven't had as great a year in 2014 as in the previous year. And this has resulted, of course, negatively on particularly our headline earnings, where we include a lot of our investment and Kobus will talk a bit about that.
But by and large, I think fairly pleasant picture on the bond side as well. On average, a higher base and because we didn't fizz in our asset management type business off the base, you would see the base was 17% up. We've done pretty well in those businesses.
If you really look at the exchange rates, increasingly as we move offshore, these things do impact us. The rand weakened about most of the pillar, against most of the developed currencies, where we operate. And you would see places like the U.K. and Europe having a bigger contribution to our profits, because the rand is weakened. That has helped us. In Botswana and India less so, but still a strengthening of those currencies relative to the rand. The rest of Africa, though, I spoke about currency volatility at the beginning, you can see we've been hurt by those currencies weakening against the rand by 3%.   Overall, the net result from financial services, our operating profit up 1.7% because of currency issues.
New business volumes up by about 1.4%, but value of new business coming mainly out of Africa down by 0.3%. So not too much, but overall a positive contribution coming from the currency valuation. 
If we look at what's been achieved in the past year in the delivery, a key part of what we're driving [indiscernible], of course, the results. But we really look at the business quite carefully. We do a lot of investment into the business upfront, incur new business strength as long as that is positive, and which it makes our hurdle rate, so that we can get the profits into the future. We treat a lot of our business like that. It is all about capital, the management, the investment decision and so. Within that sort of a framework, our net operating profit per share increased by a very credible 26% over the past year. We're very just about that, normalized headline earnings a bit lower, mainly because the market didn't contribute as much in the past year, only about a 10% increase in the market as opposed to close to -- well, close to 20% increase in the previous period. So normalized headline earnings fairly flat. And in that, we incurred quite a bit of new business strength, because of the growth that you see below. New business volumes up 18% on how you know across the board, net funding flows up ZAR 42 billion. Those things don't mean as much. They're very positive and but you know an indication that things have gone well. They say nothing about margin. If we look about the margin stuff, our net life value of new business up 21%, up to ZAR 1.6 billion. And that of course, a big chunk of that incurs new business strength, particularly on the risk side, the EB side and so forth. This is where we had a negative impact because of the high growth on the actual profit that we've shown. But we will talk about that later when Kobus comes with his financial results. The margin is fairly flat on a per product basis maintained a bit of mix towards the higher or the lower yielding margins, more savings products in South Africa as opposed to risk and that sort of thing.
Group equity value, which is really a key part of what we try to drive. Group equity value at the end of December was of last year, ZAR $46.84 per share. We're pretty proud of what is being achieved there with a return on group equity value over the past year of 18.5%. On a normalized basis, that can help the market, which has been fairly flat about 18% return. This is how we measure ourselves. We have hurdles that we would like to achieve, and that is probably the main reason why we trade at the -- as the share price trade at substantially above the group embedded value. It is because our return is substantially more than simply the unwind of the discount rate.
So overall, if we look at the efficiencies in the business, the trick is not to only be bigger, but to be better. And the big part of it lies in growing the value of new business. I'm very happy to say that this has been a recurring story with about another 20% increase gross value of new business, 20% up over the period. In EB, we've had a very large single policy at a bit of a lower margin, overall, it decreased the margin a little bit. You would see that coming down. But on a per product basis, the margin very similar to the previous years, and increasingly you see the new territories that we've added and how it just makes a difference with the cherry on top. We're very proud of what is being achieved here. As I've said, of course, this incurs quite substantial new business trends on the risk in EB side, with EB's contribution being a major part of the growth there. And therefore, it's -- it impacted negatively on operating profit, despite of that still the 26% growth is very credible.
Quality is key for us. We don't like to write business that will disappear before we made our money. You've see a slight uptick in 2013 in the second half from -- in lapses, surrenders fully paid ups. Mainly the Section 14 transfers, which is about administration, but we are also net gaining from a whole lot of that, which we don't show in the net number, but this is our book and the lapses as a percentage of book in the middle market. You can see after the strain that we've taken in the first half of the year a substantially better second half, also better than the second half of last year, and that is pretty good for us. And this goes to show a bit about the health of the South African consumer and our focus on different segments of the market. We feel happy with that. And overall, we don't see too many problems there for us. In the lower end of the market, persistency is a big issue. You've seen in the later half of 2013, industrial action, resulting and particularly that Rustenburg platinum area, in the later half of 2013, the beginning of 2014, with lapses ticking up a little bit, and have big chunk of that coming exactly from that. As soon as things started normalizing, we were able with [indiscernible] and the team there were doing a sterling job, getting things back to where we would like it to be and you see the persistency increasing there and lapses coming down a bit, so overall also a pretty pleasing story in terms of quality.
Always -- a slide on the experience variances and it's been a big part of the profit, where we simply do better on what assumptions are. Again, a number of sources of this. The big bulk of this experiences vary coming from risk, where we outperform in terms of what we assumed the assumptions to be, still well within that range of 3% and 4% of the value of enforce, but still a pleasing number at close to ZAR 1 billion of positive experience variances and of course, that help quite substantially in getting the return on group equity value up quite a bit.
If we look at our investment performance, I think we've had a very good year, a very sterling year. In fact, in a year where particularly, as I've said earlier, where value investors struggled. No clear direction in the market, difficult to fund opportunities, but I think our team [indiscernible] has done a sterling job. We've outperformed the benchmarks consistently by between about 100 and 200 basis points over the past 3 to 5 years rolling basis. And I think that puts us in a very good state. And a big part of our results is the shop window that is being created there under [indiscernible] to ship actually not only for the investment side of the business, but for a whole lot of our saving industry coming through SPF, personal loans businesses and so forth. So overall, I think a very credible number and something to be really proud of.
We're also in this business achieved quite a bit of -- on the profit side, achieved quite a bit of performance fees that Kobus, I'm sure, will allude to. The theme of diversification is key, not only in South Africa, but also in once we go beyond diversification on essentially for France. We used to be at middle market business only focusing on African business around 10, 15, 20 years ago. We've been able to diversify that middle market base. We've added the high end of the market through businesses in Malaysia, the mass affluent space, the high network space in Sanlam personal wealth, used to be Sanlam personal investments that we rebranded. In the lower end of the market through Sanlam sky, really expanding our business quite a bit on what we do and then the back end and the investment size and then going -- following our clients offshore in the high end and to niche areas in the developed markets, and into Africa, Southeast Asia, India, Malaysia and so in the middle market. So this is a key part. If we really look at our equity value, where our investments and value sit around 50% now in life business, down from about 80%, 10-odd years or so ago, a substantial contribution from general insurance, investment management, credit and banking, admin, health other stuff, surplus capital and so, so a much more, I think, robust and diversified base.
And if we look at the profit that, that base generates to the right hand side there also much more diversified. Life being particularly profitable, once you've added the African businesses on to that. General insurance doing well. Investment management across the board carrying a bit more than its fair share of credit and banking, while only being 9% of our investment contributing roughly about 14% of our profit. So we're in the -- must be in some of the sweet spots in that area, so overall much more diversified.
And if you look at that picture of diversification geographic stuff, every year we're strengthening that. We're into 10 African countries now, actually 11 by adding Mozambique there. We're into India and Malaysia, places where they speak English, the emerging market side. In the developed markets areas, we're into U.K., Ireland, Switzerland and we have now presence in Australia and U.S.A.
And these businesses now contribute roughly about a quarter of our profit about 15% or 2/3 of it from the African base, the emerging markets base and about 1/3 of it from the developed market space, both of those businesses grew quite substantially on average close to 30%, but more importantly gave us a return of roughly 28%. So that's a big part of our business more than 25 doing very well. We'll see most of these places, they speak English, which means we can support them from Johannesburg.
And although we maybe small in the countries we then can because of having a big base that we spread between the businesses, we spread that fixed cost investment, we can operate as if we're big in those places with the support coming from South Africa, following a partnership approach where we have great partners in those countries.
So overall, we're very happy with that approach. It provides opportunities to increase our investments to broaden our footprint and so forth. So overall, I think, a pleasing -- having been at that for quite further a while, I think Johan [indiscernible] have done a great job in creating footprint with many moving parts, where we have optionality into the future. And if you really look at how the businesses is growing from a traditional South African base 10 years or so ago to 1 that is much more diversified, where the traditional base still is important. We've added some new business into that traditional base like credit and so. So about 40% of what we use to have 10 years ago, still doing well, 60% of profits coming from new areas that we've added to that.
The entry-level market, Namibia, our emerging spaces, the rest of Africa, other international so doing fairly well.
And if we really look the contribution to net operating profit over that time, not only have we've been able to grow the size of the pie, but also the composition. And this is the key part of it. We are now have many moving part, we have optionality as I have said, and it's a really -- I think a great story if you look at the progression. And into the future, it provides lots of optionality. You can now partner and focus on the area with potential, wait a little bit if there are headwinds in other areas and drive the things forward.
The overall picture is as you see in terms of investments on the right-hand side of the picture there, we now have 23% of our investments offshore, but they give us or gave us 26% of our profit on the left-hand side.
And in terms of life, the future and so forth, you can see a pretty picture, a big chunk of it is offshore. Of course, a big part of our investments into Africa and India and so forth, not on the life side, but a big part of it is in general insurance side and also in credit and banking, and overall those complexes doing very well for us.
Capital efficiency, a key theme over the past 10, 12 years. We've redeployed close to ZAR 30 billion over the past 8 to 10 years into buying back shares into your, first of all, selling our stake in APSA, then using that money wisely and buying back shares when we were underpriced.
Buying businesses like African Life, building other businesses of that base, going into Africa, into the U.K., we have returns of well over 20% from those investments. So overall, it's done very well for us. In the past year, net basis ZAR 1.9 billion invested, we've done deals of around ZAR 3 billion, ZAR 3.2 billion. We sold some businesses in the U.K. And in India, reinvested that money elsewhere, so ZAR 1.9 billion on net basis invested. We realized another ZAR 930 billion from our operations, mainly returns on surplus cash, also a small part of dividends that we didn't pay out, the cash dividend added to that part of that ZAR 930 billion. We also got ZAR 185 billion from selling part of our stake in emerging markets, where we have short-term insurance exposure to Santam. They own now 35% of that. It's key that they support us there through their expertise, but also by having skin on the -- in the game.
So a key part of that and then discretionary capital at the year end, up about ZAR 3.3 billion, substantially allocated for acquisitions. Having just a word or 2 on that, we have quite a big pipeline. This is what -- how we came to that. We have quite big pipeline for that ZAR 3.3 billion. We already announced towards the end of last year, ZAR 700-odd million due with buying a small -- 30-odd percent stake into mid scheme [ph]. There's a big movement in India towards lifting the FDI limit of 26% in insurance to 49%. All indications are -- is that the rules it's already been announced. It's been through decree by the pause that be in India. They're now sorting out the rules. We think that should be done in the next month or so. And to take up our additional option of going to 49 there and the insurance companies will be another ZAR 600 million, ZAR 700 million. And then we have a whole lot of smaller bolt-on type transactions, both in South Africa, but also in -- particularly Africa and elsewhere, and that will take, in my mind, the bulk of what we have available.
Hopefully, we will add again during the year to this number. So -- but a pretty picture. I think with that sort of a basic story, very similar to what we've been talking about over the last 5 years, another step I think towards realizing our objectives, I would like to hand over to Kobus Möller, our Financial Director to talk a bit about the numbers. Kobus?

And how much capital have you guys really got sitting down unencumbered to help finance your expansion? I know you said that you often use the profits in the countries in which you are into to finance expansion. But if you're looking at the acquisition strategies that you might be pursuing, do you believe the group has sufficient capital to really make a big difference?

---

【回答: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
Yes, we have. We have ZAR 3.3 billion. We've pulled it up on the capital slide and so forth. If we really squeeze things, there may be more. But we would be inopportune to do that now because we're changing the whole capital regime from one that we've been using for 20 years or longer to one that we will be using next year. And while we think we're adequately capitalized, we simply don't know, because it's a new way. And we don’t go into the new regime, which is risk based, for people to have less capital. I can guarantee you that. The idea from government and from the regulations is to have more capital. So let's cross that bridge when we get there. We don't know, by towards the middle and end of this year, how that thing will pan out, and then we will show you exactly where we are. At this moment in time, we're adequately -- don't expect too much. It is a new place. And we've seen across the world, in Solvency II, which is our SAM environment that people have to carry more capital. So the ZAR 3.3 billion is more than adequate, we think. The already existing exposure that we have offshore is about ZAR 15 billion in the Emerging Markets. The ZAR 3 billion will add us another 20%. That's a big chunk in 1 year. We don't want to run ahead for -- of ourselves. There's another question here, Brian at the back.

---

【質問: Brian Mushonga (Analysts)】
It's Brian Mushonga from Crédit Suisse. We've seen a lot more players interested in acquiring assets in Africa and being prepared to pay eye-popping sort of prices. How has that affected your own expansion strategy in Africa? And is that why you're looking to Lusophone and Francophone countries now versus your strategy in the past?

---

【回答: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
As in most of the Anglophone countries, we already have a footprint. We're very happy with the partners that we have. And we may have 1 or 2 blocks missing, like Investment management or maybe pension funds business or a General Insurance business or whatever, and we will still buy those things. But the big focus for us is really using and growing what we already have, and the big reason for that is simply because what has happened in the past 2 years. We've seen massive flows coming from private equity funds from some of our competitors into Africa, and prices are 4x booked, not being off the scale at all. In fact, that is, certainly in the past 6 months or so, become the norm. We struggle to see how you can make those things work, certainly in the next 20 years from that base, and yet, people rush in. And they want to be part of the African story, and they sell it to their clients and so forth. And therefore, I think we have a big first mover advantage and while everybody will be wondering what they've bought. Because often, those things that are available, we've looked at in the past 10 years, and some of them we wouldn't have touched at all and still, they go at 4x book. It tells you a story about a fool and his money.

---

【質問: Unknown Analyst (Analysts)】
One more question, if I may. It's for Ian and Santam. Santam Re is obviously very exciting going in behind specialized business up in Africa. And how far along are you in terms of progress of making sure that you know what programs you are on and duplicating exposure? I know it takes a while to built those systems, get the data, but I suppose that's the success or failure of reinsure at the end of the day.

---

【回答: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
Yes. I think we're making solid progress, Greg. We're not rushing. We're not rushing into it. We realize that this is a different market. It's a new market for us. We've been amazed with the amount of data and amount of modeling information that we have been able to get in a fairly short period of time. But we don't set them targets from the Santam side. They've gotten to decide what they can do. And if it's within the risk appetite, we will ride the business. You can see from looking at the numbers that it's progressing quite nicely. But building a reinsurance business, you don't want to rush the thing. It's going to take time. And we're talking 5 or 7 years' story. But I mean we're making very acceptable returns at the moment relative to the hurdle, and I think it's important to diversify within the overall Santam story.

---

【回答: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
All right, ladies and gentlemen, we have 1 question on the webcast. Can you read it for us, please?

---

【回答: A. Zeeman (Executives)】
The question comes from WJ Defris [ph] from Avia Capital Markets [ph]. He said, "Your persistency levels have improved and have been on a downward trend since 2007. How can you improve these levels further? And what are your views on incentivizing policyholders to remain loyal?"

---

【回答: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
Well, if you sell them the right product, they'll stay with you. If you sell -- so for us, the thing -- the whole issue about persistency is before you issue the policy, making sure that this client -- this is exactly what the client wants and so forth. And I think, we've said it many times, a big part in running that is the modeling. In banks, they have a credit scoring model before they give you credit. In our own case, we run the odds model that determines, by looking at how long have you been in a stable job, what's your income or your available income, would you be able to keep this policy on the books for a number of years and not to sell things that don't work. I think that is the critical thing, and that is how you manage it. A second part of it, and this was what anyone will tell you, is simply management information. Once a client is on the book, really keeping close to it, knowing when to run your debit run order, when to do the debit run. For some people, it's on the 15th of the month, for others, on the 21st and others, a day before the other people get paid. So these things are critical, but that means staying close to the client. And that information is where we've done a much better job than in the past. And clearly, we can always do better. We think the numbers where we are, relative of course to what we've assumed, is where we make great money. We can lift the hurdle a little bit but then lose a lot of business by not writing at that front. We think we're relatively close to the sweet spot. But it's always -- persistency is always the number that you keep relative to what you've assumed. That's where the really sweet spot is. It's not our persistency of 10%, losing 10% of our book relative to our peers, who may lose 15%. It is relative to what we assume we will have, and that will come through then in positive experiences variances and these kind of things. That is really the key. Andre, that's you're game as well.

---

【回答: A. Zeeman (Executives)】
Yes. And of course, to keep the client, you need consistent good investment performance, good service and things like that as well.

---

【回答: Johan van Zyl (Executives)】
Yes, but that goes, to my mind, actually, without saying. People have a choice. And if you compare the companies in South Africa, a pretty competitive bunch. I would have liked for them to be useless, but they're not. They come with credible offerings and on the service side. And so you have to what -- the differences are essentially marginal between us. It's a bit like our rugby teams, marginal difference and often, the ref and the bounce of the ball that determines the outcome, not necessarily the player. 
Ladies and gentlemen, any last questions? With that, thank you so much for the support. Like always, it's been a pleasure to share with you. I haven't said anything about our new building. It is brand new, and it's still a bit like -- it feels a bit like Kimberley coming here with a hole on the side here where they're putting up another building. But we really appreciate your coming up, and it's part of our drive to -- around our new brand that we've consolidated. We've consolidated a lot of our businesses in this building. We would like to increase our presence here in Harten [indiscernible] and Johannesburg in particular and then use this also as a base and as a very visible base into Africa where a lot of our African people. So thanks a lot for supporting us, and good luck.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our analyst conference and my first conference as new CEO of Geberit. I would also like to take the opportunity to welcome those who are viewing this conference via webcast. Together with Roland Iff, I am pleased to report to you about another very successful year for Geberit. Our presentation is structured as follows: First, I will give you an overview of 2014 and comment on sales development over the last year. Roland Iff will then present the financial results and thereafter, I will introduce the most important new products which we launched this year and give you an outlook of the construction industry and following a few comments regarding Sanitec, I will also comment on perspectives for Geberit in 2015. At the end, I will summarize and take your questions. 
In 2014, the Geberit Group was able to further improve the already very solid results achieved in the previous year. Sales amounted to CHF 2.4 billion, corresponding to an increase of 6.4% in local currencies. The operating cash flow increased by 10.8%, reaching CHF 657 million, a new record level. With 27.3%, the EBITDA margin exceeded our midterm target corridor of 23% to 25%. The operating result also significantly increased by 13% to CHF 577 million. The EBIT margin reached 24.0%. The net income increased by 14.4% to CHF 499 million, corresponding to a margin of 20.7% of sales, also a new record level and first time above 20%. Earnings per share increased by 14.6% to CHF 13.28. At CHF 460 million, the free cash flow exceeded last year's excellent performance by roughly 4%. The Board of Directors proposes a distribution of CHF 8.30 per share to be distributed as a regular dividend. This corresponds to an increase of about 10%. Furthermore, the Board of Directors decided to resume the share buyback program started in 2014 and which was interrupted due to the Sanitec acquisition. 
Last year, we were once again able to introduce various new important products. Among others, we launched the Omega flushing systems with corresponding actuator plates. Omega flushing systems offer maximum flexibility, with 3 different system heights. In addition, the extra small actuator plates can be mounted at the front or at the top and provide an elegant, minimalistic design. In addition, we expanded in 2014 our Geberit Monolith family. We introduced WC module Monolith Plus with odor extraction directly from the toilet bowl orientation light and electronic flush activation. In China, we introduced a Monolith washbasin module developed specially for the middle class that is entirely produced in China. The module is available in 4 different options, with different ceramics and faucets. Further, we introduced new and revised Geberit wall draining system, slimmer in design and even easier and safer to install. As an example, for our regular extensions of our pipe and product portfolio, we introduced in 2014 the patent Geberit Sovent fitting. The Sovent fitting increases the flow performance by 40% and hence, enables relatively small-sized drainage stacks especially for high-rise buildings. 
Last year, Geberit invested roughly CHF 100 million or 4.4% of sales. This corresponds to an increase of 7.7% versus the previous year. Capacity expansion represented roughly 1/3 of the total investments. Over 40% of investments were dedicated to modernization and rationalizations and investment into new products accounted for 1/4 of the total investment. Let me now continue to highlight a few selected investment projects last year. We completed the newly built production facility in Ruse in Slovenia and started with production in July 2014. In Ruse, we produced fittings for our drainage piping systems, exposed cisterns and walls. The total investments amounted to EUR 60 million, which was in plan. A second key investment in 2014 was the expansion of our Italian production site in Villadose. In Villadose we produce our Geberit drainage pipes. The expansion addresses the volume growth in this important product line. The total investments amounted to EUR 12 million as we took up cap production in October 2014. 
An important event in 2014 was the 50th anniversary of our concealed cistern. Since 1964, Geberit sold more than 60 million concealed cisterns. We celebrated the success with our customers on the occasion of various events. For example, with 5 VIP gala events across Europe that were attended by 3,800 customers. To address a broader customer base, we conducted 36 so-called construction site parties, with 8,500 customers, to strengthen our customer relationships and our brand reputation. 
In addition to the 50th anniversary, we further invested into our customer relationships. As an example, the slide shows our customer activities 2014 in Germany. In total, we conducted 60,000 individual customer visits with our sales force. On top, more than 10,000 customers participated in 1 of our 200 events in Germany, addressing specific topics, for example, training on fire protection with live demonstrations or sales trainings together with AquaClean or new product demonstration with our on-tour events. 
Let me now comment on the development of our number of employees. Organic sales growth initiatives contributed to a slight increase of the headcount. Overall, the number of employees at the end of the year 2014 increased by 21 respectively, 0.3%, reaching 6,247 employees. Sales per employee increased to CHF 380,000, an increase of 3.5%. Roughly half of Geberit employees work in production, followed by nearly 1/3 in sales and marketing. Roughly 13% of our employees are active in administration or development, and we have a high number of apprentices which currently represent 4% of our employees. 
The total environmental impact declined further by 1.6% despite the currency-adjusted sales growth of 6.4%. We also achieved a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and water consumption by 1%, respectively, 0.5%, versus the previous year, and our recycling rate increased further and reached 85%. In the context of our social engagement, we funded and carried out again a social project in 2014. Ten Geberit employees, paired with 8 apprentices, spent 2 weeks in Varanasi, in India, to renovate the sanitary infrastructure of Kiran Village. Koran Village is a school for 360 children, mostly handicapped. The project was planned, funded and carried out entirely by Geberit. 
Let me finish the review of 2014 with an overview of our investments over the last 5 years. The slide shows that we have -- that we follow a long-term investment strategy, with continuous investments in all key areas: into our infrastructure, in R&D and new products and in marketing. These continuous investments build the basis for our future value creation. Let me now comment our sales development 2014 in more detail. 
The sales growth rate in local currencies of 6.4% corresponds to a sales increase of CHF 146 million. The negative currency effect of CHF 34 million or minus 1.5% lead to an overall sales increase by CHF 112 million or 4.9%. In the first half of 2014, sales increased at a higher pace compared to the second 6 months. The stronger growth in the first half of the year can be explained by the relatively weak sales in the first half of the previous year 2013 and the mild winter at the beginning of 2014. All global regions recorded a positive sales growth in local currencies. Europe grew by 5.9%, with positive growth rates in all countries and regions. Sales in America increased by 6.4% and in Middle East and Africa, we were growing by 21.2%. Far East/Pacific also recorded double-digit growth rate, with 12.8%. 
Let me now give you a few comments on the different countries and the market developments last year. We outperformed the market in Germany, which showed a higher growth in the first half of the year compared to the second half of the year. We outperformed the market in Switzerland, which was running at full capacity and achieved the growth rate of 6.6%. We generated a currency-adjusted growth rate of 4% in Benelux, where the construction industry is still in crisis. Lower growth rates were recorded in Italy due to a weak market environment. And although the Austrian market is declining since the second half of 2014, we increased sales over the entire year by 2.5%. The Central and Eastern European markets showed, in 2014, a mixed picture. Our sales were growing by 11.7%, driven by double-digit growth in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. In the Nordic region, we faced challenging markets and recorded a sales growth of 2.4%. In France, we achieved a sales growth of 3% despite an overall weak economy. We outperformed the already strong market in U.K., with a double-digit growth rate of nearly 20%. On the Iberian Peninsula, we achieved a slight growth in a stabilized market environment, which is still on historically very low level. In America, the residential sector further recovered. However, the most important sector for Geberit, the institutional sector, remained weak during 2014. In Far East/Pacific, we have seen a slowdown of residential markets in some of our key markets, for example, in China. However, we achieved a double-digit growth in China, India and also in Southeast Asia. The total region grew by 12.8% in local currencies. In Middle East/Africa, the region grew by 21.2%, with double-digit growth rates in the Gulf region as well as in South Africa. 
I come now to the sales growth per product area. Both product areas, Sanitary Systems and Piping Systems, grew to a similar extent. The Sanitary Systems generated sales growth of 5.1% to CHF 1.37 billion. Piping Systems exceeded sales of CHF 1 billion with a sales growth of 4.6% in Swiss francs. All product lines contributed to growth, with positive growth rates in local currencies. The product line with the highest sales levels, insulation systems, grew by 7.5%. Building drainage systems showed the strongest development, with almost double-digit growth. Roland Iff will now lead through the financial results 2014.

---

Ladies and gentlemen, good morning. For 2014, the group, Geberit Group, can once again present very solid results. Many key figures show all-time high levels. And despite the challenging market conditions, sales development measured in local currency lies slightly above our midterm target corridor and profitability was improved again. I start my presentation with the overview of the most important key figures. Overall, sales increased from CHF 2.2916 billion to CHF 2.4044 billion, corresponding to 4.9% increase. In 2014, currency exchange rate had a negative impact on sales in Swiss francs again. Changes in exchange rate negatively influenced sales by CHF 34 million, which impacted sales growth by minus 1.5%. The 2 major currencies, euro and US dollars, both weakened about 1.3% over the period. The operating cash flows and operating results increased over-proportionally to sales. The net income and EPS also increased at double-digit rates, growing faster than sales. At CHF 498.6 million, the net income reached a margin of 20.7%. And with CHF 460 million, we were also able to again increase our free cash flow. 
In 2014, the EBITDA margin increased by 140 basis points to 27.3%. In absolute terms, EBITDA grew by CHF 64.3 million or 10.8%. On the EBIT level, the increase was CHF 66.2 million or 13%. In the reporting period, the overall unfavorable currency development impacted the results only slightly negatively. 
In the fourth quarter, profitability was improved as well. The previous-year EBITDA margin was exceeded by 1.3 percentage points. Coming to some of the individual cost elements. Due to a favorable volume and volume development and shift in our market mix, the customer bonus quota increased also in 2014 as it already did in 2013. Material cost, as a percentage of sales, decreased from 26.1% to 25.1%, also due to slightly lower raw material prices. After having seen rising purchasing prices in the third quarter, the trend turned again in the fourth quarter. An increase versus the previous year was also recorded in personnel expenses. The cost increase of 1.8% is slightly higher than the increase in workforce, which grew by 1.4% or 84 employees on average. At year end, as we already heard, the increase was then only 0.3%. Further additional cost resulted from tariff increases on average in the group, about 2%, lower pension related expenses had a certain compensating effect. The additional employees, due to the volume growth, were mainly recruited in the European sales and production companies. Marketing expenses were on the previous year's level. In total, other operating expenses increased by 2.8%, which is clearly under proportional to our sales growth. 
The analysis of the EBIT margin development summarizes what I commented before. The volume increase resulted in a margin increase of 1.4%. In 2014, the product mix was neutral. The previously mentioned increase in operating expenses led to a negative impact of only minus 0.4%. The small currency movements did not have a material impact on margins. The overall net margin impact between sales and purchasing price development in 2014 was positive again, and more than compensated the negative impact from the increase in our sales deductions. All in all, EBIT margin increased by 1.7 percentage points versus previous year. 
Net income almost reached CHF 500 million with CHF 498.6 million, corresponding to an increase of 14.4% versus previous year. This, compared to the operating results over-proportional increase, is mainly attributable to a slightly lower tax rate and an improved financial result. The improvement in the financial result is due to foreign currency losses, which we incurred in 2013. And the slightly over-proportional EPS growth of 14.6% to CHF 13.28 is driven by the share buyback program started in Q2 2014. 
At CHF 460.4 million, Geberit achieved a 3.6% higher free cash flow than in the previous year. Whereas net cash flow improved in line with the operating profitability, free cash flow growth was slowed down because of an increase in net working capital. This net working capital increased results from a planned inventory buildup to secure delivery performance for certain products. Net investments intangible assets were CHF 7.1 million above previous year, mainly due to the already mentioned production-related projects. Out of this free cash flow of CHF 460 million, a dividend of CHF 282 million was paid and we bought back shares over the second trading line in the amount of CHF 37 million. Corporate cash therefore increased by about CHF 140 million. 
As of the end of 2014, the cash position in the balance sheet therefore increased to almost CHF 750 million. Net cash amounted to CHF 739.2 million. Last year's pension liabilities increased again significantly. The net increase of CHF 67.6 million is, on the one hand, due to lower interest rates which led to a higher DCF value for these liabilities. And the other hand, it is partly compensated by an again, improved capital coverage of the Swiss pension plans. In 2014, this major change does not have a P&L impact, as the net amount is charged to equity. But higher -- but the higher liability level will lead to higher pension cost in 2015. The equity ratio was therefore also reduced from 74.8% to 70.6%. The financing of the group, however, remains solid and we continue to have a basis for an attractive payout policy. 
Based on this solid financial situation, the Board of Directors is proposing to the Annual General Meeting a dividend of CHF 8.30 per share. This corresponds to an increase of about 10% versus prior year. On that basis, CHF 312.7 million will be distributed, corresponding to a payout ratio of 62.7%. The Annual General Meeting will be held on April 1, 2015. Subject to the approval by the Annual General Meeting, the share buyback -- sorry, the dividend will be paid out on April 9. In addition, the Board of Directors has decided to continue the share buyback program started in Q2 2014. On a second trading line and over a period of 2 years, we had announced that the time to buy back shares in the amount of 5% of the capital. The shares will be canceled thereafter. As we had to interrupt the program while the Sanitec transaction was ongoing, we only purchased 123,000 shares for a total of CHF 37.4 million so far under the program. This is only 6.5% of the total buyback volume announced at the time. With this, I would now like to hand it back to Christian Buhl.

---

Thank you, Roland. I will now make a few comments on the key product introductions 2015. We will introduce in 2015 a new, premium shower toilet, the AquaClean Mera. You see the picture on the slide. The new Mera combines innovative technology, comfort and design. Smart comfort functions, such as an automatic WC lid, seat heating and an orientation light are combined with a rimless ceramic toilet bowl to ensure highest standards for cleanliness and hygiene. The market introduction of Mera will be in September this year. In the product area of Piping Systems, we will introduce a new hygiene flush system to avoid stagnating water in drinking water systems. The automated flushing ensures safety and highest quality of drinking water in all buildings, especially in public buildings like hotels, hospitals or schools. The hygiene flush can be easily operated with a Geberit app on standard mobile phones. Another important product introduction this year for drainage systems is the new shower channel CleanLine for floor even showers. From an end-user perspective, the Clean Line convinces[ph] with an elegant design and an easy and practical way of cleaning. The advantages for the installers are an easy and secure installation. 
Especially for the developing markets in Europe, we will introduce new actuator plates, Delta. The actuator plates are designed for the middle mass market and are clearly differentiated to our premium segment with the Sigma actuator plate family. After the short tour through some of the new products, allow me now to comment on the outlook in the building industry for 2015.
In Europe, we expect no recovery and individual markets will develop again very differently. We are confident about positive market growth in Germany and in U.K. In Switzerland, the construction market is running on a high level. However, the impact of the new ForEx reality on the Swiss construction market remains unclear. We are still cautious about the Austrian market development. And we see a mixed picture in Central and Eastern Europe, with a positive development in Poland and mainly uncertain outlooks in the rest of the Eastern region. We expect no recovery in Netherlands, Belgium, Nordics, Spain and Portugal. And we foresee further declines of the markets in France and in Italy. 
For North America, the recovery in the residential building sector has slowed down over the last 6 months. The outlook for the institutional sector remains uncertain, with the healthcare segment still declining, while the educational sector presents an unclear picture on a still historically low level. 
Let me now comment on the outlook for Asia. We foresee a further slowdown in the residential market in China. And we are generally positive about India and expect positive growth in this region. The markets in North and Southeast Asia are expected to remain rather flat, with the exceptions of Indonesia and the Philippines. For Australia, we expect generally a positive development of the building sector. 
In the Middle East and Africa region, we see a continued positive growth trend for the Gulf region and we expect also positive market growth rates for South Africa. For the Northern African region and Near East, we are very critical due to the ongoing difficult political situations. 
Let me now give you an update on the Sanitec acquisition, which we closed on February 10. I will start with a short recap of the overall deal rationale. 
Sanitec is the European leader in bathroom ceramics and complementary products. The bathroom ceramics product range includes toilets, wash basins, tanks, bidets, urinals, and ceramic shower trays and represents roughly 75% of Sanitec sales. The ceramics complementary products include bathroom furniture, bathtubs and shower solutions and are responsible for the remaining 25% of sales. The acquisition is a combination of 2 complementary businesses fitting to the European sanitary market. Geberit today is based on sanitary technology and focusing on technology products installed primarily behind the wall. Key decision-makers for us are professionals and qualified installers and planners. Our innovations drive plumbing standards and we build a strong B2B brand over the last decade. Sanitec, on the other hand, strength's is design, with its in front of the wall product portfolio for bathrooms. Hence, the key decision-makers and the influencers are end-users, architects, showrooms and retailers. Innovation in this category drives future bathroom trends. And Sanitec comprises a portfolio of long-standing local end-user brands across Europe. The acquisition of Sanitec is an expansion of our current strategy, based on our 4 pillars. We add the strategically relevant product portfolio of bathroom ceramics and complementary products. Thereby, we expand our focus from sanitary technology behind the wall to sanitary products and design in front of the wall. 
The complementarity of the 2 businesses leads to a compelling acquisition rationale. First, with Sanitec, we will get better access to end-users and their influences, which is of increasing importance in markets where installers are a less-qualified and less-educated. Access to end-users is also key for our shower toilet business Geberit AquaClean. Second, we are able to leverage our combined position at our existing common customers, mostly wholesalers where we can add value. Thirdly, we will leverage the combined product portfolio to increase sales. For example, in projects across Europe. Fourth, with Sanitec, to get access to ceramics know-how and high-quality capacity, which is a key success factor for our shower toilet business, which we are growing in Europe. 
Fifth, the acquisition is an expansion into a long-term attractive market segment of bathroom equipments. And last and finally, we will create, with this acquisition, the European leader in the sanitary products industry. And we'll remain and keep our strength -- strong position in Europe. The combined pro forma sales for 2014 -- sorry, the pro forma net sales for 2014 are CHF 2.9 billion. This is still based on a euro and Swiss franc of CHF 1.20. We will have 3 equally strong product areas: 40% will be Sanitary Systems; 30% are today's piping business; and 30% will be ceramics and complementary products. Central Europe remains the biggest region with 50% of sales; followed by South Europe with 14%; Nordics 11%; and Eastern Europe with 10%. 
We will integrate the Sanitec organization by function into the Geberit Group. This means that the corporate and sales organization will be fully merged. The operational functions, with manufacturing, product management, logistics, will be complementary integrated into the Geberit Group. The integrated organization will allow us to capture sales and cost synergies of at least EUR 45 million in the midterm, with first synergy impact in 2016. The one-time integration costs will be on the level of the one-time synergy level. To address the increased importance of an integrated marketing and brand management behind the wall and in front of the wall, we expanded the Geberit Executive Board by the Marketing & Brands functions. I will now hand over to Roland Iff, who will present to you the financials of the transaction.

---

Thank you, Christian. Now after a second short extension of the acceptance period, we now own 99.8% of the Sanitec shares. As we are well above the 90% threshold needed to start a squeeze-out procedure to obtain ownership also of the rest of the shares-- of the still outstanding shares, this procedure was already started. The total amount invested is CHF 1.4 billion. This is about CHF 200 million below the amount announced as as of October 14 last year. The difference is mainly due to lower debt to be replaced at Sanitec, and we could also partly benefit from the strength of the Swiss franc. However, on the currency side, we don't -- we did not have the full benefit as we hedged the major part of the FX exposure back in October when we announced the transaction. The financing currently in place consists of a CHF 900 million bridge loan, a 3-year EUR 400 million loan and the currently not used 5-year CHF 300 million revolving facility. The CHF 900 million bridge loan will be replaced by Swiss franc and Eurobonds over the coming weeks. The goodwill resulting out of the first consolidation of the Sanitec Group amounts to about CHF 1 billion. In the currently ongoing purchase price allocation analysis process, part of this goodwill will be allocated to other assets, which then will be depreciated over their lifetime. The remaining final goodwill will not be amortized, but is subject to annual impairment testing. 
Let me now briefly comment on Sanitec's financial results 2014. Sanitec's full year sales 2014 decreased by 1.8% to EUR 689 million. Measured in local currencies, sales were up by 0.7%. The 2 regions, South and Central Europe, showed a sales decrease but Northern Europe, Eastern Europe and U.K. were growing in local currencies. The operating profit improved by 6%, due to an improved operational performance, and led to an EBIT margin of 11.4%. On a comparable basis, an increase of 80 basis points. The EBITDA margin increased to 15%. The integration of the 2 companies will have consequences on the reporting. An important change for the Geberit Group will be that we align our sales reporting with Sanitec and switch from reporting sales to reporting net sales or using the IFRS term, revenue from sales. The difference between the 2 numbers are mainly the bonuses and cash discounts we pay to wholesalers. In 2014, Geberit achieved net sales in the amount of CHF 2.0891 billion. Customer bonuses and cash discounts amounted to CHF 350.3 million. Can you give us an indication what January -- how much January accounts for full year sales? I suppose it's less than 1 month on average. But is it half or 3/4? That would help, so that we can make an assumption what the 11 months of consolidation will be in 2015. My second question also goes to Sanitec, or the combined strategy, Sanitec and Geberit. What would be, for my mind, obvious, or a way to go for incremental sales would be to do kind of packaged deals or packaged offering, i.e. combining the ceramics with installation systems on one hand, just to make an example, or electronics that you have in the public areas together with the ceramics from Sanitec. Now if you would do that, the question is, are you prepared to kind of sacrifice some margins on the Geberit side in order to get a push for Sanitec's market presence, i.e. should we expect some kind of a margin sacrifice on the Geberit side? That's my second question. And the third is -- goes to the share buyback. The original idea was to buy this 5% back in 2014, 2015. Now, with the suspension over half a year, should we expect also that you expend on the -- also an expansion on the timeline, or is it still the target to conclude the 5% buyback in 2015? Thank you.

---

Thank you for your questions. I will start with #2 and #1 and #3 will answer -- Roland Iff. You're right. The long-term strategy is clearly that we can use combined product portfolios to make better product offerings, combined with products behind  the wall and in front of the wall. That will take time. It's too early to say what will be the impact, for example, on margins. But we are now currently combining the business plans and will then, in the second half of the year, also give new guidance of this combined company regarding our sales targets, midterm sales targets and our margin targets. But you are basically right with your assumption that the product bundling, also technology-wise, is one of the drivers of this acquisition.

---

Regarding your first question. Sanitec has a similar seasonality as we have. So if you divide full year sales by 11.5, you're not that far off for the assumption. And then the share buyback program, that's correct, that we announced at 5% at the time, and said that the volume should be around 530 million. That is not achievable anymore now with this long interruption. We will start as of today. But we don't give any indication as right now, how much we can invest until the final date, which remains in Q2 2016. So there's no ambition or idea yet to extend it. We will just do whatever we can within this remaining period. But we will not achieve the 5%.

---

Christian Arnold, Bank Vontobel. Again, question on Sanitec. You mentioned the CHF 1 billion additional goodwill, which then will be partly transferred into other intangible assets, so to say. Could you give us a rough indication, I mean, I know you don't have the analysis concluded. Nevertheless, it's -- I think it's important to know if it's 50% of this CHF 1 billion or 75%, rough indication for how these intangible assets will look like afterwards? Then, in terms of reporting, on slide -- I think, the combined financials, combined sales, is this a new reporting in terms of regional split-up? Are you going or you will still show all sales on country levels, like you do today? And the last question would be on the increased networking capital inventory. You mentioned, somewhat related to product, could you give us -- is it Mera, which resulted in this higher inventory or which kind of product is the reason for that? Thank you.

---

Thank you for the questions. I start with #2 and 3, and #1, will answer, Roland. The reporting, in terms of country will not change. We will have the same reporting structure in terms of the geographical split. Regarding the increased inventory level 2014, I can say it was not Mera, because Mera will be introduced this year. So it's not Mera, but we don't go into the details which product it will be -- was.

---

In terms of split of the goodwill, it certainly will not be 50%. It will be a significantly lower number. With -- in our models, we use 20% and then said we amortize it over 10 years. That those 20%, because that will be allocated to amortizable asset. But I -- that's what we used in our model. Frankly, I do not know yet because we could only start that exercise now. Now we have to go company by company, subsidiary by subsidiary, looking into their balance sheets said and then decide, is there some need for revaluation or not. So I -- we put in 20% in the models. But that number can be as wrong as it -- or right. But it certainly will not be 50%.

---

So what, 20% intangibles will be amortized [indiscernible]

---

So then the goodwill would only be CHF 800 million at the end, and CHF 200 million would be distributed over various assets. But again, this is an assumption which is not really based on the work we are doing right now. It's just an experience we have from other exercises.

---

Martin Hüsler, Zurcher Kantonalbank. I also have 3 questions. First of all, a clarification. On the slide where you mentioned the impact of that SMB decision. You show an EBIT margin decline by roughly 50 basis points. I was just wondering, that if this does not include the impact of the rebate you gave in Switzerland, that's question #1. Question #2, can you give guidance for CapEx 2015, for cap rate and also including Sanitec? And the last question is about raw material. Coming -- it came down further in Q4. What is your guidance for this year? Does it -- only Geberit standalone? Does it come back further?

---

Thank you for your questions. Your first one, regarding the impact of the SMB decision. The 50 basis points decline of the EBIT margin are excluding any price rebates in Switzerland. Second, regarding your CapEx guidance 2015, we expect CapEx this year total, including Sanitec, of CHF 150 million to CHF 160 million. One part is Sanitec and the other one, our increased CapEx, as you have seen in my presentation mainly to the logistics center and the manufacturing side in Langenfeld. Regarding raw materials. We expect, for the first half of the year, lower raw materials for commodity plastics driven by the lower oil price. We don't expect a significant decrease for special plastics due to supply and demand balance in management in the value chain. On the metal side, we expect lower copper prices in the first half of the year as somehow sideway development of aluminum. And for nickel, we are still cautious if there could be a price increase, especially then in the second half of the year. Overall, we expect slightly lower raw material prices in the first half of the year. Maybe from the...

---

So question from the webcast. Remo Rosenau, Neue Helvetische Bank. Are some smaller disposals we see in the Sanitec peripheral product range, a possibility looking forward? Or is it just everything fitting just perfectly?

---

I understand the question. But the answer is too early or the question's too early to answer. We acquired the company 4 weeks ago. We will see what fits and what not. But I can't just answer now. It's just too early.

---

And the second question from Remo Rosenau. The tax rate was very low in the last few years due to the favorable tax deal with Germany. This effect was expected to reverse again gradually over the next few years, and could you update now us on this effect, and if the Sanitec deal has any impact on this tax deal whatsoever?

---

[indiscernible] doesn't have an impact on [indiscernible] the guidance for the moment is combined around 15% for 2015 and 2016. Midterm, it's in the area of 18% to 20%.

---

Okay, a question from Robbie Fryer from [indiscernible] Capital. It is fair to assume that Geberit will drive the productivity of Sanitec to at least the productivity of the benchmark in the ceramic segment?

---

We will definitely -- first of all, I remarked before, Sanitec is already a benchmark in the ceramics industry, meaning that the margin level of Sanitec compared to competition is on a high level already, because they had one Sanitec program running for 5 years where they increased the profitability already. For sure, we will improve profitability more. It's one source of the synergies. But we have to be clear. The margin level of Sanitec will never reach the margin level of the Geberit standalone business.

---

Then a question from Manish [indiscernible] from Société Générale. What is your long-term target net debt-to-EBITDA? Should we interpret that you will distribute all your free cash flows and dividends and buyback from 2015 onwards?

---

No. We will drive back the debt as we did it in the past, but you have seen, we will refinance the bridge loan which we have in place now with bonds, which have slightly longer terms, so probably will take -- no, it will take longer than in, for example, when we did Sanitec to bring down the back -- the debt.
Any further questions in the [indiscernible]?

---

Martin Flueckiger Kepler Cheuvreux. Two questions, please. Firstly on the Q4 margin, if I remember correctly, as you had to recently, or in January, you had guided for an EBITDA margin of 26% to 27%. Now I realize, for the full year, it's only a small discrepancy. But apparently-- but obviously, for the fourth quarter, it's quite a significant one, at least comparing to the consensus this morning. Yet, quite an outstanding increase in the EBITDA margin in Q4. Were there any surprises for you in there? And if you could elaborate a little bit, similar to your full year 2014 EBIT bridge, what the key drivers were particularly in the fourth quarter, that would be very helpful. And then coming back to the euro discount of 10% in Switzerland. Is that across the portfolio, or we can see this only on selective product lines? And also here, with this respect, what are the main criteria regarding the duration of these discounts?

---

I start with question 2. Question 1, I hand over to Roland Iff. First, a 10% currency rebate in Switzerland is across the entire portfolio. The level of this rebate will depend on the development, the further development of the currency rate. That's the meaning of temporary. We will review regularly this rebate based on the development on the currency, mainly euro to Swiss francs.

---

Q4 main drivers, I would say, 3. One is, as the volume is going back and the sales companies adjusted their rebates, they give to wholesalers and that's always a whole year rebate. But then the adjustment falls into Q3. So if you look at the bonuses as a percentage of sale, it was significantly lower than for the other 3 quarters. Second, in the third quarter, we had seen this rising raw material prices, and then that turned against -- raw material prices were better than what we had expected in -- at the end of Q3. And then thirdly, operating expenses were right in line with sales growth or operating expense were with what's in line with sales growth, and there you usually have some volatility. So that is difficult to plan, then, for the full year. So that's probably -- it was at the lower end of our expectations after 9 months.

---

Torsten Wyss from UBS. Just one question. On the raw materials, I mean, with the full year results, topline results, you indicated like a rather negative raw material development in Q4 on higher metal prices, if I remember correctly. Now you did state that you're not negative on the metal prices, at least not on copper. Plastic is going to come down. That's quite obvious. Still, you say you expect a slight lower raw material level in H1. Wouldn't we rather have to expect substantially lower raw materials in 2015 or at least in H1? The impact must be quite strong in a positive way for you, mustn't it?

---

You can now debate what is the meeting between slight and then strong, which is a kind of wording debate as well. But you're right. That it's in favor of our side, that's right. But we are so cautious for certain raw materials, especially for the special plastics, depending on supply and demand management, in the value chain before, which you can't really control, so you have to not only look at the raw materials itself, so you have to take into account as well the prefabrication steps and that's the reason why we are slightly, maybe conservative in your point of view.

---

Speaking about slight and strong. I mean the impact in Q4 was 150 basis points year-over-year positive. I would assume for the full year '15 to have also, at least 150 basis points less cost of goods sold in percentage of sales. Would you agree with that indication?

---

Maybe one item I didn't mention before when Mr. Flueckiger asked his question. We had a very favorable mix in Q4. Piping Systems was flat, all the growth was coming from Sanitary Systems. That helped as well. So I wouldn't see that as the benchmark for full year 2015, 2016 -- '15, '15.

---

Patrick Appenzeller from Helvea Baader. I have 2 questions. First of all, I want to double check the costs related to Sanitec in '15 and also the other years. When I understand it correctly. You have this integration costs, one-time synergies, which you will obviously book in the current year. So what-- does that mean we have to expect CHF 45 million integration costs you book operationally? I assume in '15? And the transaction costs, the same question here, CHF 50 million, you mentioned. Is that where it will -- that be booked? In which years? And synergies, you say nothing this year. Do we have to expect like '15, in '16, '17 in -- 30 in '17 and 45 in '18, is that the best assumption? And the other question there is related to Q1. February probably is -- has a very strong base. We will see how much will be. But do you expect still organic growth in the first quarter, given the tough weather comparison?

---

So I start with question 2. We, as you know, we don't give any quantitive guidance before our first half results in August. So therefore, I only can repeat what you said. We have a strong base effect in Q1, driven by Q1 2014. Regarding your first question, the integration cost, the CHF 45 million. That will be spread along the integration period, which will take 2 to 3 years. So don't expect the CHF 45 million integration costs to be booked in this year. And the synergy, how they will develop over the full capture of CHF 45 million until midterm, meaning more or less, 2018, that they would gradually increase. But I can't tell you exactly how the pace will be. Just one thing, we will start to capture synergies as of next year. And we'll end up at CHF 45 million in 2018. Regarding the transaction costs, I ask Roland to comment.

---

Total transaction cost of CHF 23 million. Out of this CHF 23 million, we have booked CHF 3 million in 2014, CHF 15 million will be booked in 2015, split half between financial fees which go -- and below the EBIT line and the other half is above the EBIT line. So that's consulting expenses. And then CHF 5 million will be amortized over the lifetime of the financial instruments. So that's related to the bonds and the bank loans which will remain in place. In addition, we will have this year, a one-off cost out of the purchase price allocation exercise. That means we will have to reevaluate our inventories and then you turn those, obviously, at least once per year. So that whole revaluation difference goes into the P&L immediately. And we will have then, what I said before, from that part of the goodwill which goes to amortizable. The depreciatiable assets-- that's going to be in the 2015 and '16, '17 results as well. We will give more guidance with that when we publish the H1 results.

---

And we will work within adjusted net earnings, adjusted EPS for 2015 to exclude all these one-off effects, which many of them are noncash.

---

---

No, not yet. As what Roland Iff just said, that we will currently combine the business plans and fill up the new business plan. And we will communicate new guidance in the second half of the year regarding sales and also margins, the combined business.

---

A question from Michael Watts from Berenberg. In the outlook, you say that challenge in this sector remains complex and huge from today's perspective, are expected to become even more pronounced in the medium term. In what way do you expect these challenges to intensify?

---

There are more markets which are still in a crisis, are not developing and they are still declining markets. We don't have any signs that also midterm, the picture will improve.

---

Two questions from Tobias Loskamp from HSBC. Do you expect any negative impact on renovation behavior in Germany from the introduction of regional rental caps by the German government?

---

I have to be open. I don't know the answer. Very little. I don't know.

---

And second question, how much of your cash will you invest in the Sanitec acquisition?

---

It's about CHF 250 million.

---

Christian Arnold, Bank Vontobel. A follow-up question on your CapEx guidance of CHF 150 million. You have mentioned the investments you are planning and then there are some investments for Geberit. Nevertheless, it looks like that it's quite a big portion coming from Sanitec, compared to the size, when we compare Sanitec to Geberit. So I wonder if investments is somewhat lagging, as Sanitec used to be owned by a private equity? Do you have to invest more in Sanitec, compared to Geberit in the coming years? And with that, this CHF 150 million, is that some of the guidance we could also use for the years after 2015? And the second question relates to net working capital. As -- if I'm not mistaken, also again, compared to Geberit, Sanitec has higher net working capital when we compare the absolute size. Are you able to bring that down or do we have to do, for the time being, calculate with higher net working capital? Thank you.

---

So regarding your first question, if you look at the history of Sanitec, you see they have invested last year, about CHF 25 million, EUR 20 million, last year, which is a little bit lower in terms of sales compared to Geberit, but not substantially lower. In the other CHF 150 million to CHF 160 million, we have included about 30 -- CHF 25 million to CHF 30 million for Sanitec. Your question, if there is an underinvestment or an additional investment need, of course, there was a private equity owned company. The question is too early to answer. We are currently reviewing all the sites, and we are making corresponding plans and concepts. But it's just too early to answer this question. Regarding the net working capital, Roland?

---

I wouldn't say that they have a significantly or higher net working capital than Geberit, they have a similar seasonality as we have. So it increases over the course of the year and then comes down back at the end of the year. What they had at the, last, at the end of 2014, they had some higher inventories as well, due to the lower volumes which they have seen in Q4. But nothing in particular.

---

There is one.

---

Martin Flueckiger, from Kepler Cheuvreux. You actually just gave the key word, lower volumes at Sanitec in Q4. Now that we have seen organic sales decline, and I think on underlying terms, the EBIT margin was also, I think, slightly declining in Q4 for Sanitec. Have recent developments changed or adjusted your approach in integrating Sanitec, or to push for cross-selling synergies in any way?

---

No. The recent development of Sanitec does not have an influence on -- that's what you're mentioning. Maybe one comment to the lower margin of Sanitec in Q4, slightly lowered margin compared to Q4 2013. That was mainly driven by the sales decrease, the volume decrease. Sanitec has a higher operating leverage compared to the Geberit business. It's higher fixed cost base. So lower volumes have a high impact on the margin. The margin was positively influenced in Q4 and Sanitec also by the product mix and by sales increases. So it was mainly driven by lower volumes, and it doesn't have any impact on our considerations regarding the integration.

---

Question from Robert Donald from Brummer. Market shares. Could you -- could the group update us on its view of its market share in its key markets and also update us on the penetration of integrated flushing systems per key market? In other words, where does the group see the best medium-term growth outlook?

---

We don't talk about market shares and technology penetration numbers, especially not in specific markets. But I can comment, as you see that with the sales result, 2014, in all the markets, more or less in Europe, we were able to outperform the market by technology, by various strategy, meaning having the technology selling higher value product. So we outperformed the markets, we increased market shares, but we don't talk about in detail about our market shares. About the outlook, we are confident in these markets that we are well-positioned to further increase our market penetration, be it by technology, be it by existing products.

---

And a question from Ms. Daripa from GEO Capital. You mentioned integration in the sales team between Sanitec and Geberit. Do you believe Sanitec's sales team can be trained to deal with wholesale customers, brackets behind the wall products? It seems like the skill set might be slightly different, compared to retail customers.

---

I understand the question. It's a question which is quite early. We are in the preparation phase of integration. We started the integration in second quarter this year. So it's too early to answer the question, but it's clear. It is one of the key challenges to train the respective sales forces to the broader product portfolio. 
Okay. I think -- no questions anymore. Thank you very much for attending our conference. Good afternoon.
