And then coming back to the euro discount of 10% in Switzerland. Is that across the portfolio, or we can see this only on selective product lines? And also here, with this respect, what are the main criteria regarding the duration of these discounts?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
I start with question 2. Question 1, I hand over to Roland Iff. First, a 10% currency rebate in Switzerland is across the entire portfolio. The level of this rebate will depend on the development, the further development of the currency rate. That's the meaning of temporary. We will review regularly this rebate based on the development on the currency, mainly euro to Swiss francs.

---

【回答: Roland Iff (Executives)】
Q4 main drivers, I would say, 3. One is, as the volume is going back and the sales companies adjusted their rebates, they give to wholesalers and that's always a whole year rebate. But then the adjustment falls into Q3. So if you look at the bonuses as a percentage of sale, it was significantly lower than for the other 3 quarters. Second, in the third quarter, we had seen this rising raw material prices, and then that turned against -- raw material prices were better than what we had expected in -- at the end of Q3. And then thirdly, operating expenses were right in line with sales growth or operating expense were with what's in line with sales growth, and there you usually have some volatility. So that is difficult to plan, then, for the full year. So that's probably -- it was at the lower end of our expectations after 9 months.

---

【質問: Torsten Wyss (Analysts)】
Torsten Wyss from UBS. Just one question. On the raw materials, I mean, with the full year results, topline results, you indicated like a rather negative raw material development in Q4 on higher metal prices, if I remember correctly. Now you did state that you're not negative on the metal prices, at least not on copper. Plastic is going to come down. That's quite obvious. Still, you say you expect a slight lower raw material level in H1. Wouldn't we rather have to expect substantially lower raw materials in 2015 or at least in H1? The impact must be quite strong in a positive way for you, mustn't it?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
You can now debate what is the meeting between slight and then strong, which is a kind of wording debate as well. But you're right. That it's in favor of our side, that's right. But we are so cautious for certain raw materials, especially for the special plastics, depending on supply and demand management, in the value chain before, which you can't really control, so you have to not only look at the raw materials itself, so you have to take into account as well the prefabrication steps and that's the reason why we are slightly, maybe conservative in your point of view.

---

【質問: Torsten Wyss (Analysts)】
Speaking about slight and strong. I mean the impact in Q4 was 150 basis points year-over-year positive. I would assume for the full year '15 to have also, at least 150 basis points less cost of goods sold in percentage of sales. Would you agree with that indication?

---

【回答: Roland Iff (Executives)】
Maybe one item I didn't mention before when Mr. Flueckiger asked his question. We had a very favorable mix in Q4. Piping Systems was flat, all the growth was coming from Sanitary Systems. That helped as well. So I wouldn't see that as the benchmark for full year 2015, 2016 -- '15, '15.

---

【質問: Patrick Appenzeller (Analysts)】
Patrick Appenzeller from Helvea Baader. I have 2 questions. First of all, I want to double check the costs related to Sanitec in '15 and also the other years. When I understand it correctly. You have this integration costs, one-time synergies, which you will obviously book in the current year. So what-- does that mean we have to expect CHF 45 million integration costs you book operationally? I assume in '15? And the transaction costs, the same question here, CHF 50 million, you mentioned. Is that where it will -- that be booked? In which years? And synergies, you say nothing this year. Do we have to expect like '15, in '16, '17 in -- 30 in '17 and 45 in '18, is that the best assumption? And the other question there is related to Q1. February probably is -- has a very strong base. We will see how much will be. But do you expect still organic growth in the first quarter, given the tough weather comparison?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
So I start with question 2. We, as you know, we don't give any quantitive guidance before our first half results in August. So therefore, I only can repeat what you said. We have a strong base effect in Q1, driven by Q1 2014. Regarding your first question, the integration cost, the CHF 45 million. That will be spread along the integration period, which will take 2 to 3 years. So don't expect the CHF 45 million integration costs to be booked in this year. And the synergy, how they will develop over the full capture of CHF 45 million until midterm, meaning more or less, 2018, that they would gradually increase. But I can't tell you exactly how the pace will be. Just one thing, we will start to capture synergies as of next year. And we'll end up at CHF 45 million in 2018. Regarding the transaction costs, I ask Roland to comment.

---

【回答: Roland Iff (Executives)】
Total transaction cost of CHF 23 million. Out of this CHF 23 million, we have booked CHF 3 million in 2014, CHF 15 million will be booked in 2015, split half between financial fees which go -- and below the EBIT line and the other half is above the EBIT line. So that's consulting expenses. And then CHF 5 million will be amortized over the lifetime of the financial instruments. So that's related to the bonds and the bank loans which will remain in place. In addition, we will have this year, a one-off cost out of the purchase price allocation exercise. That means we will have to reevaluate our inventories and then you turn those, obviously, at least once per year. So that whole revaluation difference goes into the P&L immediately. And we will have then, what I said before, from that part of the goodwill which goes to amortizable. The depreciatiable assets-- that's going to be in the 2015 and '16, '17 results as well. We will give more guidance with that when we publish the H1 results.

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
And we will work within adjusted net earnings, adjusted EPS for 2015 to exclude all these one-off effects, which many of them are noncash.

---

【回答: Roman Sidler (Executives)】
A question from Amy Gala [ph] from Citi. Can you comment on your medium-term expectations in terms of organic sales growth and EBITDA margin after the Sanitec deal?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
No, not yet. As what Roland Iff just said, that we will currently combine the business plans and fill up the new business plan. And we will communicate new guidance in the second half of the year regarding sales and also margins, the combined business.

---

【回答: Roman Sidler (Executives)】
A question from Michael Watts from Berenberg. In the outlook, you say that challenge in this sector remains complex and huge from today's perspective, are expected to become even more pronounced in the medium term. In what way do you expect these challenges to intensify?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
We have still difficult markets in Europe, as I've shown in my presentation. There are only a few, very few markets which are really going good or positive. There are more markets which are still in a crisis, are not developing and they are still declining markets. We don't have any signs that also midterm, the picture will improve.

---

【回答: Roman Sidler (Executives)】
Two questions from Tobias Loskamp from HSBC. Do you expect any negative impact on renovation behavior in Germany from the introduction of regional rental caps by the German government?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
I have to be open. I don't know the answer. Very little. I don't know.

---

【回答: Roman Sidler (Executives)】
And second question, how much of your cash will you invest in the Sanitec acquisition?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
It's about CHF 250 million.

---

【質問: Christian Arnold (Analysts)】
Christian Arnold, Bank Vontobel. A follow-up question on your CapEx guidance of CHF 150 million. You have mentioned the investments you are planning and then there are some investments for Geberit. Nevertheless, it looks like that it's quite a big portion coming from Sanitec, compared to the size, when we compare Sanitec to Geberit. So I wonder if investments is somewhat lagging, as Sanitec used to be owned by a private equity? Do you have to invest more in Sanitec, compared to Geberit in the coming years? And with that, this CHF 150 million, is that some of the guidance we could also use for the years after 2015? And the second question relates to net working capital. As -- if I'm not mistaken, also again, compared to Geberit, Sanitec has higher net working capital when we compare the absolute size. Are you able to bring that down or do we have to do, for the time being, calculate with higher net working capital? Thank you.

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
So regarding your first question, if you look at the history of Sanitec, you see they have invested last year, about CHF 25 million, EUR 20 million, last year, which is a little bit lower in terms of sales compared to Geberit, but not substantially lower. In the other CHF 150 million to CHF 160 million, we have included about 30 -- CHF 25 million to CHF 30 million for Sanitec. Your question, if there is an underinvestment or an additional investment need, of course, there was a private equity owned company. The question is too early to answer. We are currently reviewing all the sites, and we are making corresponding plans and concepts. But it's just too early to answer this question. Regarding the net working capital, Roland?

---

【回答: Roland Iff (Executives)】
I wouldn't say that they have a significantly or higher net working capital than Geberit, they have a similar seasonality as we have. So it increases over the course of the year and then comes down back at the end of the year. What they had at the, last, at the end of 2014, they had some higher inventories as well, due to the lower volumes which they have seen in Q4. But nothing in particular.

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
There is one.

---

【質問: Martin Flueckiger (Analysts)】
Martin Flueckiger, from Kepler Cheuvreux. You actually just gave the key word, lower volumes at Sanitec in Q4. Now that we have seen organic sales decline, and I think on underlying terms, the EBIT margin was also, I think, slightly declining in Q4 for Sanitec. Have recent developments changed or adjusted your approach in integrating Sanitec, or to push for cross-selling synergies in any way?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
No. The recent development of Sanitec does not have an influence on -- that's what you're mentioning. Maybe one comment to the lower margin of Sanitec in Q4, slightly lowered margin compared to Q4 2013. That was mainly driven by the sales decrease, the volume decrease. Sanitec has a higher operating leverage compared to the Geberit business. It's higher fixed cost base. So lower volumes have a high impact on the margin. The margin was positively influenced in Q4 and Sanitec also by the product mix and by sales increases. So it was mainly driven by lower volumes, and it doesn't have any impact on our considerations regarding the integration.

---

【回答: Roman Sidler (Executives)】
Question from Robert Donald from Brummer. Market shares. Could you -- could the group update us on its view of its market share in its key markets and also update us on the penetration of integrated flushing systems per key market? In other words, where does the group see the best medium-term growth outlook?

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
We don't talk about market shares and technology penetration numbers, especially not in specific markets. But I can comment, as you see that with the sales result, 2014, in all the markets, more or less in Europe, we were able to outperform the market by technology, by various strategy, meaning having the technology selling higher value product. So we outperformed the markets, we increased market shares, but we don't talk about in detail about our market shares. About the outlook, we are confident in these markets that we are well-positioned to further increase our market penetration, be it by technology, be it by existing products.

---

【回答: Roman Sidler (Executives)】
And a question from Ms. Daripa from GEO Capital. You mentioned integration in the sales team between Sanitec and Geberit. Do you believe Sanitec's sales team can be trained to deal with wholesale customers, brackets behind the wall products? It seems like the skill set might be slightly different, compared to retail customers.

---

【回答: Christian Buhl (Executives)】
I understand the question. It's a question which is quite early. We are in the preparation phase of integration. We started the integration in second quarter this year. So it's too early to answer the question, but it's clear. It is one of the key challenges to train the respective sales forces to the broader product portfolio. 
Okay. I think -- no questions anymore. Thank you very much for attending our conference. Good afternoon.

B1Y1SQ7.eventHeadline: Jeronimo Martins SGPS SA, 2014 Earnings Call, Mar 05, 2015
B1Y1SQ7.transcript_text1:
Ladies and gentlemen, the conference will now begin with Mr. Pedro Soares dos Santos, Chairman of Jerónimo Martins Group. Mr. Pedro Soares dos Santos, you have the floor.

---

Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and thank you for joining this call to present Jerónimo team's full-year results. 2014 was not a business as usual year, neither for the food retail sector nor for our Jerónimo teams. Food deflation hit Portugal and Poland harder than we expected, forcing our companies to find new strategies and tactics to manage in a tougher environment. Despite all the challenge, our main business outperformed their respective markets and post positive like-for-like sales in volumes. This means that our capacity to track and retain consumers was reinforced during the year. All in all, we ended 2015 stronger and better prepared to face the future.
We delivered in our main objects of growing sales ahead of the market where we operate and manage to have EUR 851 million to our consolidated sales that increased to EUR 12.7 billion.
Total sales were very much support by expansion, mainly in Poland, where Biedronka opened 211 new stores. Year -- in a year of strategic review of the whole value proposition, Biedronka decide to implement a sales booster program to regain like-for-like sales more. And there are already signs in line with what we expected. At the same time, the company is adjusting the pace of expansion to more selected criteria in terms of new locations.
Biedronka's present network scale, both stores and distribution centers, allow us to keep growing at a different region without compromising our target to reach the 3,000 store check. Still, Biedronka benefited from the large share of the group CapEx in 2014, EUR 361 million, and will continue to be our main priority in terms of investments in 2015 and in the coming years.
As we expect food deflation to continue in Poland in 2015, Biedronka will have to be very strict in terms of cost discipline while focused on reinforcing innovation in its offer to make sure it takes most of it out of the current store network. In 2014, Biedronka's contribution to the group's EBITDA increased to 78%, stressing its rule of our main growth and profitability drive. The combination of deflation at the top line with inflation at the cost level, mainly in wage and rent sales, negatively impacts Biedronka's EBITDA margin and, as a consequence, the group's profits.
Despite extra pressure at all fronts, Jerónimo's teams increased by 41% its cash flow generation to EUR 267 million. The strong consolidated pro forma results also in those proven capacity outperformed its market. Strong cash flow generation combined with a solid balance sheet create the necessary conditions for the group to continue investing in its future growth.
As we approach the end of our second full year of operations in Colombia, I do believe that Ara will play an increasing important role in our portfolio and further expansion plans. This year, we will test our business model in a very different region of the country, which we will provide that with value strategic insight as we go forward.
Because -- before giving the floor, 2014 allow solid -- does not reflect our full potential to deliver, although solid does not reflect our full potential to deliver. After incorporation 2014 learnings, it's now time for us to execute at our best level in all the countries.
Thank you, once again, for your attention. I'll now leave you with Ana Luísa.

---

Thank you, Mr. Pedro Soares dos Santos. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you again for joining the call. I will start by bringing you some context to the year. In Poland, GDP and private consumption remain stable. The pressure came from food deflation. Debt, as seen in other European markets, accelerated along the year, particularly in the second half, reaching minus 0.9% in the year, which compares with food inflation of plus 2% in 2013. In Portugal, the food retail market remained under pressure in an enduring difficult environment. Food deflation was at minus 1.3% in the year, with higher levels in Q2 and Q3 and sometimes [ph] a slowdown towards the year-end.
This environment brought one further challenge to our performance. We were surprised by much higher than expected levels of food deflation, both in Poland and in Portugal. We believe that we should not manage against deflation, and we did not, as this would risk our competitive position. Therefore, our profitability was impacted by the imbalance between top line deflation and cost inflation. Managing in this deflationary environment, our main companies are becoming stricter on their cost structures to protect profitability.
2014 was also marked by Biedronka's strategic review. Our biggest company took the year to identify opportunities to grow not only organically, but mainly in the current selling area, a plan to take the full potential from the existing stores we've built and is now being implemented. In this context, group sales grew 7.2% to EUR 12.7 billion, with reinforcement of the competitive position of all our banners. Food deflation, already mentioned, together with very competitive market realities, pressured EBITDA and net results, which declined 5.6% and 21.1%, respectively. Despite the pressure on profitability, the strong cash flow generated by our own main business, Biedronka and Pingo Doce, more than compensated the startup investments.
Net debt stood at EUR 273 million with gearing at 16.7%, an extremely solid financial situation. Despite all the challenges, there were key achievements in the year that allowed us to reinforce our competitive position. First, all our banners focused on sales growth and market share increase, and delivered positively on these objectives.
Biedronka, Pingo Doce sales grew ahead of their respective markets and increased market shares, ending the year with a stronger competitive position. To deliver on these objectives, there were 2 fields of action, like-for-like performance and organic expansion program. For Biedronka, the store opening program was the main driver of the 1.1-percentage-point market share increase in the year. Our Polish company has, in terms of like-for-like performance, 2 difficult quarters in the beginning of the year. Nevertheless, volume performance on a like-for-like base improved in Q3 and Q4. Pingo Doce's performance was driven by the like-for-like growth, and the company gained 0.6 percentage points of market share, reaching 18.2% by the year-end.
The second achievement, strong cash flow generation. In 2014, the group generated a cash flow of EUR 267 million, EUR 78 million more than 2013, although it kept investing in business to guarantee future growth. And despite the pressure of deflation on profitability and the evolution of losses from the new businesses, pretax ROIC was at a healthy 21%. Regarding the income statement for the fourth quarter of the year, I highlight the following. Top line grew 7%, supported by expansion and positive volume performance of Biedronka and Pingo Doce. Total margin went from 21.7% to 21.3%, reflecting the commercial developments in the different businesses.
The increased weight of the operating costs from 15.2% to 15.7% of sales, mainly resulting from the imbalance between food deflation at the top line and cost inflation, impacting the capacity to dilute operating cost. At the EBITDA level, the losses from Ara and Hebe were EUR 15 million in the quarter. As a consequence, EBITDA margin was 100 basis points lower than previous years. The profit in associated companies was down from EUR 5 million in Q4 2013 to EUR 1 million in Q4 2014. Worth mentioning that in Q4 '13, this having benefited from a one-off income, the underlying figure being similar in the 2 periods.
Minority interests were at minus EUR 4.6 million in the quarter. And I recall that in Q4 '13 figure was impacted by negative one-off items affecting Pingo Doce's results.
Looking now to the income statement of the year, I would highlight the EBITDA margin decline of 80 bps, strongly impacted by the deleveraging effect of deflation that in the case of Biedronka was not offset by the volumes growth. The financial expenses, which were EUR 34 million, EUR 4.5 million below previous year, mainly due to the improvement of the average cost of debt, which in 2014 was at 3.7%.
Non-recurrence were at EUR 9 million incorporating several different items as indemnities, some impairments and contingencies. And effective tax rate increased from 22.9% to 25.1% mainly due to the increase of the wage and value of losses in the new businesses.
Moving now to the cash flow statement. The free cash flow was EUR 267 million, EUR 78 million more than in 2013 already after CapEx payments of EUR 486 million. This performance reflects the real strengths of our businesses, and is the result of a solid operating performance despite all challenges and a strict management of the working capital that remains the key area of efficiency in our businesses. Also contributing to the cash generated was the decrease in the CapEx payments following the slowdown in Biedronka's expansion. The strength of the balance sheets was reinforced, and net debt was reduced by EUR 73 million, ending the year at EUR 273 million. Net debt to EBITDA was at 0.4 and interest covered at 13x, with a gearing of 16.7%, clearly reflecting a solid financial position for the group. In line with the established dividend policy, the Board of Directors will propose on the General Shareholders Meeting of April 9, a growth dividend of EUR 0.245 per share, representing a dividend yield of 2.24% over the average share price registered in 2014.
I will now go into a more detailed analysis of our businesses' performance starting with the group. Group sales increased EUR 851 million to EUR 12.7 billion, a growth of 7.2%. The negative internal basket inflation in Biedronka, Pingo Doce and Recheio impacted the group's like-for-like growth that was slightly negative at minus 0.4%, a word to the fact that the group like-for-likes following Biedronka and Pingo Doce's solid performance improved in the last quarter of the year and was positive at plus 0.6%. The sales of Ara and Hebe reached EUR 152 million and increased EUR 72 million related to 2013, including the exchange rates impact.
In the business areas, I will start with Biedronka that during 2014, and always guided by the mission of putting consumer satisfaction in preference at the center of all these decisions work mainly on 2 priorities. One, improved sales density, opportunities to improve its offer and, hence, to grow share of wallet were identified. And the company ended 2014 with a clear plan to uplift its sales density to be implemented throughout 2015. Two, reinforce its presence in the markets. To guarantee that the company continues to grab the potential identified in the market, 211 new stores were opened and 3 new distribution centers were built to support expansion and efficiency.
When analyzing the sales performance, we need to start by saying that food inflation deteriorated very fast, impacting our internal basket deflation that was at minus 1.8% for the year. Biedronka like-for-like performance in the year was slightly negative at minus 0.8%. Throughout the second semester, there was an improvement of the volumes on a like-for-like basis, more expressive in Q4, which reinforces our confidence for 2015.
Biedronka total sales grew 9.5%, reaching in 2014 EUR 8.4 billion. The banner led the market share increases in Poland and ended 2014 with a total market share of 16.9%, 1.1 percentage points more than in the previous year. Market share gains were stronger in the last 2 quarters of the year.
In Portugal, food retail sales evolution remain on negative ground during the year, and the consumer remained very price-sensitive. Pingo Doce led the market share gains in the sector and ended the year with a market share of 18.2%, 0.6 percentage points more than in 2013.
The volume growth on a like-for-like basis more than offset the effects of the internal deflation, and allowed the company to post 1.2% growth in its like-for-like sales in value, excluding fuel. Total sales grew 1.7% to total of EUR 3.2 billion, the company having added 5 new stores to its network, of which 4 are managed by third parties.
Recheio continues to operate in a tough environment for both HoReCa and traditional retail. Despite sales in the year declining by 0.7%, volumes were positive at 1.5%, and the company invested in commercial actions to protect its sales and strengthen its client base. 
Just a few words on the new businesses. Ara had a good year executing the established brand. 50 stores were opened, and we already started preparing the next region to be operating in the second half of 2015.
The management team in Colombia acknowledges that throughout 2014 gained important insights on the local consumer as well as on the fundamentals of our business in its markets. Hebe's team focused on further developing its expertise on the beauty sector.
Group EBITDA was 0.2%, of which generated by Biedronka. The EBITDA decline reflects the deflation in Poland and Portugal, the intense price investment in both markets and increase in the startup losses from Ara and Hebe. The losses from the new businesses impacted the group's EBITDA by EUR 58 million, EUR 16 million more than in 2013.
Group EBITDA margin was 5.8%, 80 bps below previous year. Biedronka's EBITDA margin was 6.8%, 100 bps below previous year. This performance mainly reflects the impact of minus 1.8 basket deflation at the top line and a 3% inflation at the cost structure, which did not allow the dilution of costs in sales.
Despite being positive, volume growth in the company was not enough to offset this effect.
Pingo Doce delivered strong volume growth, which together with strict cost management, compensated the impacts of the internal basket deflation. The company's EBITDA margin was at 5.8%, in line with previous year. Recheio margin declined, resulted from the investment in commercial actions and the impact from deflation on cost dilution. The consolidating investment program that amounted to EUR 470 million focused on expansion, this being easily understood by the relevant opportunities we have in such a fragmented market as Poland, and also because of our new venture in Colombia, where we are just starting to build our market positions. Investment in our current store base is also strategic to protect productivity and continue to provide a good shopping experience to our consumer.
This nature of investment represented 25% of total CapEx. Finally, one of the key areas in our cost advantage is our logistic infrastructure. In 2014, we opened 5 new distribution centers, 3 of which in Biedronka. Pingo Doce began the restructuring of its logistic infrastructure with the opening of one DC in Southern Portugal, and Hebe has a new and fully fit warehouse. In 2014, the CapEx in the new businesses amounted to EUR 43 million, 65% of which was invested in Ara, mainly on the opening of 50 new stores. Up till now, all our stores in Colombia are rented.
For 2015, food deflation should continue to impact the sector, at least in the first half of the year. Promotions are also expected to continue to play a relevant role during this year.
We will maintain our focus on top line growth through the opening of new stores, but particularly by improving productivity in the current store network. In what regards organic expansion, our plan will be focused in our 2 growth markets, Poland and Colombia. This expansion investment is part of the total CapEx program estimated to be between EUR 500 million and EUR 550 million for this year.
In what concerns productivity of the current networks, the main priority will be to implement the measures to improve Biedronka's offer. The company will be focused on its sale booster program throughout the year. Biedronka will also work on adjusting its cost structure to become better fit to operate in a low-inflation scenario and in accordance with the new pace of expansion. We, hence, confirm the EBITDA margin floor to Biedronka at 6.5% for 2015, as announced in Biedronka's Day. Pingo Doce will continue strengthening its relationship with the consumer to keep growing sales and gaining market share. For Ara, 2015 is the year to validate the model in a different region while continuing to develop the key pillars of our offer to the Colombian consumer. EBITDA losses from the new businesses are expected in the range of EUR 60 million to EUR 70 million in 2015. I would close this presentation by saying that we feel confident on the foundations we are building to deliver the growth potential we clearly see in Poland and in Colombia. And as we enter 2015, we are fully committed in taking the most out of our Biedronka operation, including our presence in the big urban centers in Poland with a selected expansion, while reinforcing the innovation in our value proposition.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your attention, and I am now ready to take your questions.

B4TP9G2.transcript_text1:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported our financial results for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2015, and overall, we are very pleased with the solid growth in sales and improved bottom line results. Our profitability remains driven by 3 fundamental elements: a broad assortment of products at compelling prices; an aggressive store network expansion strategy across Canada; and a focus on productivity and cost reduction initiatives that drive improved operating results. I will briefly go over the fiscal 2015 results and store expansion highlights, and Michael will provide you with a more detailed update on our financial and key operating initiatives for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended February 1, 2015. 
From a financial point of view, fiscal 2015 was an excellent year for Dollarama. We were able to deliver strong top line sales growth of 12.9% for the year. These sales were driven by continued expansion of our store network and strong same-store sales growth of 5.7%, including a strong performance in the fourth quarter as same-store sales increased by 8.5%.  We continue to generate strong margins through our compelling merchandise offering at truly great value. This year, our margin was 36.9% as we absorbed part of the headwinds related to the weak Canadian dollar, but benefited from the positive scaling effects of higher sales on occupancy costs as well as continued logistic efficiencies.  Our net earnings improved by 18% to $295 million in fiscal 2015, while diluted earnings per share increased by 27% to $2.21 per share. 
From a real estate point of view, we opened 9 -- 81 net new stores over the past 12 months compared to 89 net new openings in the same period last year, thereby increasing our total store count across Canada to 955 stores compared to 874 stores at the end of Q4 last year. The quality of available real estate, combined with our unique value proposition, has allowed us to reach out to our customer base to increase traffic to our stores and improve our store's economics. For fiscal 2016, we expect to keep up the same pace by opening another 70 to 80 net new stores, focusing on markets that remain underpenetrated by dollar stores.

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Correct.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, I -- David...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
The numbers...

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
You know how boring we are, David. So I don't know. I can't -- I'm not sure...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, there's been numbers circulating of the many billions of dollar available and -- for consumers and that they'd use that to spend. But to tell you the truth, we don't measure that specific to that dollar amount, so it's hard to say.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, I would agree with Michael there.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Well, how do you look at demand in 2016 fiscal year when you think about your budgeting process? You think about oil prices going down, you think about the potential impact on employment in Canada, do you make your guidance a lot more conservative? Or could you give us some idea of what you think the cadence of sales growth can be this year relative to normalized last year?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No, we look at all those factors obviously. And so we -- and we look at historically how we've performed under these circumstances. Just in the last 5 years, you've had wide fluctuations, whether it was the currency, the inflation in China, the energy, like prices going up quickly and coming down now. So for us, yes, we do factor that, but otherwise, it's business as usual. Nothing structurally major changing around us that would have us re-question our model or our projections and direction.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Okay. And just back to the oil prices. As it relates to product procurement costs, is there -- how much of a natural hedge is there with falling oil prices in your product procurement costs of the Far East?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, product procurement. Well, when it's going up, you'll hear a lot about it, and when it's going down, you don't hear about it. And that's life. So I think it may have -- we're going to the Orient in about a month and we'll get it directly and confront them as you've just confronted us in the same way. But we're going to get the same answer. All of a sudden, oil is a very small part of a product -- of the product. And when it goes up, it's a huge part of the product. So we're going to hear that over and over again. And we're going to hear about the labor and we're going to hear about everything else that's offsetting those decreases in the buying of oil, the oil-based products. And there -- I think prices in the Orient, and namely in China, are stable. And it may be as a result, generally speaking, of the oil prices. It's hard to measure those things.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
And again, I think with all the factors that were raised, we're all on the same-level playing field more or less. And as long as we keep in sync this in terms of value proposition and compelling this compared to our competitor, that's the model. And so you have to factor that also.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Fair enough. Just on the tax rate, it was, I think, 26% in the quarter. Is that the level you expect it to be at next year? Or is it going to be a 27%?

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No. It's -- we're close to the statutory tax rate, which is 26.7%. We had a onetime refund there. So that's -- but the statutory rate, the rate that you should be using is closer to 26.7%, 27%.

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Okay. That's helpful. And last question. Just on your distribution center in Montreal, I mean, it's, I guess, innately inefficient given pack sizes and so on. How do you get that to be more efficient now going forward? Is there much room there that makes a material benefit in future years? Or it is what it is for now?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, you have a distribution center of so many square feet. You keep putting more and more stores into that distribution center, you're going to lose some efficiency. We've expanded once. I don't think we can expand much more, but there's no question that, that inefficiency is worth absorbing compared to going elsewhere and opening another one. So yes, it's a little more inefficient because you're tighter and you're bumping into each other in the DC, in particular in the DC as opposed to the other warehouses that are strictly warehouses. So the DC is a little less efficient than ideally could be. But if you compare that to any other alternative, you'd be very happy with the -- I'm very happy with the results.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
I just wanted to go back to items above $1. I just want to make sure I correctly understand that number. So it's a SKU or item count reference, right, when you talk about 71.5%, not a share of dollars, right?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
A share of dollars.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Share of dollars. Okay.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
So have you been able to take certain items from $1 to $1.25 to offset the FX impact, and that's part of what's going on here in terms of driving that rate up then?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I think the answer would be yes. We've taken some items from $1 to $1.25 as we've taken some items from $1.50 to $2. I guess we try and avoid that as much as possible. We'd rather cancel the item and buy something new. If we're going to do that, it's not our choice to mark up an item by 25% or more at all. So that's why we are absorbing as much as we can until we can no longer do so. But the preference again is to check out that item, cancel it and buy something new.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Okay. Just thinking about your new store program. Larry, I know this is kind of a conceptual vague question that may have an equally vague answer, but when you think about store saturation in the dollar store space in Canada, do you look at it like -- we all of sort of calculate it on a pop per 1,000 basis, but how do you guys approach it? Is it really sort of 1 store at a time assessed for viability in a geographic trading area? Or do you also keep an eye on sort of the macro which is store saturation?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
That's a good question. Look, I thought we were saturated in Québec when we opened our 100th store. We're almost 250 stores now. The model changes and the model affects how many stores you can eventually open. The model has changed over the last 20 years from one price point to this multi-price point. And it has allowed us to go into areas that we formerly would not have considered at the $1 price point. So the store penetration population is something we look at -- well, let's put it this way. I was in Ontario this week and I teased my guys there saying that we're better penetrated in Québec that in Ontario so you should get off your tushes and move a bit. So in that sense, I'll use it. But really, every city and every country, you can talk all you want, but trying to get penetration in Downtown Vancouver is just almost impossible. And there's a lot of people that live there. So every province is different. Every country is different. And it's tough to use that penetration other than to get people moving as the guideline, I think, it goes store-by-store, opportunity-by-opportunity. You look at it, and then you make a call. That's the way we do it anyways.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
And as you've progressed on taking items above $1 up to a greater percentage of your business, has that also though allowed you to take on slightly higher rent expense and still make a good return?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I would think that, that is so.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, definitely.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, Michael is saying yes. So there you go.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Michael's obviously right.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
He is obviously right.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
And last question. Just in the quarter, like obviously gross margin being up 25 basis points pre-rent was a very strong outcome. Was there any dynamic as a result of the prior year ice storm disruption that helped...

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
For sure. I think in December last year, we were down 11% or something like that. It was ridiculously low. And...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. For December, it was minus 7.5%.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Okay, and this year?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
And this year, yes, the transaction, if I recall, it was down 3.1% in Q4 last year. So it clearly had an impact this year.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. And the same thing is happening in the Maritimes right now, by the way, but this is February, it's not Christmas, thankfully.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Yes. So then on gross margin rate though in the quarter, I assume that the negative impact on seasonal sales last year, which is a high margin category, would have potentially, this year, contributed to a gross margin recovery with less disruption.

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
It's more the scaling, I'd say, that is the impact. So yes.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
Just a question on the freight cost. I presume you're buying mostly FOB, the Orient. I'm wondering if you're saving significant amounts on freight at the moment?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Absolutely not. Mike, please confirm that too.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, yes, yes. Yes, not significantly saving.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
No, we are not. No, there's not even -- never mind, you can remove the word "significant."

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
They are also greatly impacted by the demand, not just the cost of oil. And the demand is very high right now and so you're competing for the same boats, and so the freight industry is happy.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
So with the resurgence of the American economy, it more than offsets the gasoline price, unless you're a better negotiator of freight rates than we are.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
Yes, I expect not. And then just on the use of your POS systems, does that help reduce the packaway? Like does it help you forecast seasonal demand or is seasonal demand so volatile or variable that it's hard to reduce packaway with the systems?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, I guess it definitely gave us more information. Now instead of having 1 packaway for a season, we're able to split it in a more efficient way. But the other -- the savings I was alluding to before are in terms of when you change over seasons and you actually do the packaway, packing away will be quicker with the Wi-Fi application. And therefore, you have to have POS before, but now with the Wi-Fi to actually do the -- so you have time savings.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
So let me add to that. POS is putting more of the right stock into the right stores. So hopefully, our packaway will be less and less as time goes on because the ideal is to buy 100 dozen to a store and to be sold out with the last customer on December 24. And as POS gets more sophisticated, that's the goal. And it's improving every year, but we're far from there. And I'm looking forward to the day that we can sell out of Christmas, have no packaway and satisfy every single customer until 5:00 on December 24. And I repeat that every season, yes.

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And just one question on the general preferential tariff that I guess we've been dealing with now over a few months. Before you'd said there wasn't much impact on your business, and I'm just wondering if that's still the view.

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. Well, it had an impact, but not material in the sense that we said we would be able to manage it, which clearly we've done, and we'll continue to do. So it's just part of the headwinds that we deal with, but we're equipped to manage it like we're equipped to manage the currency, the energy cost inflation, the merchandising inflation and so on.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
It's not fun, but if you're -- we're talking about the duty rate increases here.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, yes, yes.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
If the duty goes up from 5% to 6.5%, well, you'll have that to deal with. But if the duty -- if there was no duty on, as an example...

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
Paint rollers.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
On paint rollers, as Neil will testify, go ahead.

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
And it goes up to 15.5%, well, then it's much less fun, as my father put it. So we have to find alternatives, other countries and other suppliers. And it's part of the buyer's job to find a way.

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And so is it much of a percentage of the goods that are creating those problems? Or is it...

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
Thankfully, it's not at all material.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. We name the 2 extremes. Well, 1 -- we name 1 extreme there.

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, that's the most extreme.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, so buy your paintbrushes now.

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
Paint rollers.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Paint rollers now...

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
Not paintbrushes.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Before that goes through the system at -- from Dollarama to Rona or wherever.

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Just first question, the 1,400 store target you have, over what time frame is that -- do you expect that to be achieved?

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
I think it's safe to assume, we said 70 to 80 stores for F '16. In the future, I'd be -- I tend to say 60 stores per year-ish. So that's a 7 to -- 6 to 7 or 8 years of runway in front of us.

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Okay. And then for the F '16 stores, are all the locations pretty much locked in or -- that now you're looking at locations?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. They're pretty much locked in, yes.

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes.

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Perfect. Okay. And I mean, let's just say if Walmart would announce tomorrow that they're going take over 50 of the Target locations in Canada, is that a concern for you? Or would it be a positive as it would drive more traffic to the shopping centers where there's [indiscernible]?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I think it would be a positive. I don't know if they're going to take 50, but you may be giving us some insight there. But any location that Walmart takes will drive a lot more traffic than, well, Zellers or unfortunately, Target was drawing. So I think it's positive.

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
And the assumption there is that the product mix obviously is different enough that there won't be a lot of overlap.

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
There's very little overlap.

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
And Chris, as you know, we've got the experience of our current stores. So with -- which overlap with the 380 other Walmart stores in Canada. And again, these stores -- our stores perform very well.

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Okay. And then just in terms of your store traffic, it sounds like from the press release that you've excluded the impact of the ice storm. The traffic was roughly stable compared to the year-ago quarter. Is that right?

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No. It's -- well, this year, it was much more positive. Obviously, last year was negative 3.1%. This year was positive 3.6%. So the average of that is slightly positive.

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
And that's more or less in line with what you were expecting?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, yes.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
I just want to go back to a couple of comments you made with respect to the penetration rate currently over 71% over $1 right now. You mentioned you have less opportunity items at $1. You've now had the $2.50 and $3 price points in for coming up on 3 years now. I'm wondering if you can just discuss your thoughts on potential to have an increase to the maximum price point of $3 right now. What goes into that and when you may need or consider implementing a higher price point?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, that's a good question I've been asking myself and we've been asking ourselves. I think it's going to depend a lot on the foreign exchange. There's only so much managing you can do. And it's happened very quickly. I'm getting calls from individuals who know me, what are we doing about that and how we're going to absorb that. And everybody in Canada has those concerns, and it's making retail in Canada a lot more difficult and a lot less fun. It's not fun to increase something. It's not fun to increase prices, period, especially how competitive everything is. And you don't know what your fellow retailer is doing or how he's handling it. So the speed at which this Canadian dollar has lost value is a concern to everybody, and we're going to have to look at it very quickly and soon. Just again, to take an item from $2 to $2.50 or $2.50 to $3 is not very, well, I'll use the word, fun. Now would that necessitate going above those price points? Not for now, we hope, but we have to fight very hard to -- we'd be able to say that going forward at a $1.30, $1.35 Canadian dollar, that we can maintain our price points without looking at them very carefully.

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
So how far in advance do you have to make that decision prior to...

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, I would say that as an example, I would say, 6 months to 1 year.

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
Okay. And if you were to introduce a new price point, would you maintain the, say, 6 or 7 number of price points that you currently have offered and eliminate others? Or would you just add additional price points?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, now you're getting ahead of all of us here. I can't answer that question because I don't know the answer to it. I would like to eliminate some and add some if that's what we have to do, but I don't know. I can't answer that question.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
Okay. And then very last question. Is there any update on the progress of what's going on down at Dollar City in terms of expansion or number of new stores or anything you can provide us on that front?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, there's, again, nothing material. No major change, but for us, it's going -- it's -- they're meeting expectations clearly, and so it's still very much alive.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
Most of my questions have been answered, but just one more. Given all of the discussion we've been having on the call today, do you have any updated thoughts on credit cards and when you might move to accepting credit cards?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. No update, especially that the debit card continues to -- penetration continues to increase steadily and especially in the last quarter. So as long as that's very much alive, there's -- we'll continue with that and there's no intention to, at this point, to implement credit cards.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I agree with Michael 100%.

B5B1S13.eventHeadline: Dollar General Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 12, 2015
B5B1S13.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Labrielle, and good morning, everyone. On the call today are Rick Dreiling, our Chairman and CEO; Todd Vasos, our Chief Operating Officer; and David Tehle, our CFO. We will first go through our prepared remarks, and then we will open up the call for questions. Our earnings release issued today can be found on our website at dollargeneral.com under Investor Information, Press Releases.
Let me caution you that today's comments will include forward-looking statements about our expectations, plans, predictions and other nonhistorical matters, such as our 2015 forecasted financial results and capital expenditures, our planned fiscal 2015 operating and merchandising initiatives, and our 2015 and 2016 store growth initiatives and our beliefs regarding future consumer economic trends. Important factors that could cause actual results or events to differ materially from those reflected in or implied by our forward-looking statements are included in our earnings release issued this morning, our 2013 Form 10-K, which was filed on March 20, 2014, any subsequently filed Form 10-Qs and in the comments that are made on this call. We encourage you to read these documents. You should not unduly rely on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of today's date. Dollar General disclaims any obligation to update or revise any information discussed in this call.
We will also reference certain financial measures not derived in accordance with GAAP. Where available, reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP measures are included in this morning's earnings release, which I mentioned is posted on dollargeneral.com.
The purpose of our call today is to discuss our performance for the fiscal Q4 2014 quarter and fiscal year and our outlook for the 2015 fiscal year. At the end of our prepared remarks, we'll open the call up to your questions on those subjects. [Operator Instructions] Now it's my pleasure to turn the call over to Rick.

---

Thank you, Mary Winn, and thanks to everyone for joining our call. Today, we reported results for the fourth quarter 2014 and the full year.
2014 was a unique year for Dollar General as we generated record operating results, but our strategic actions to acquire Family Dollar were unsuccessful. However, as our results and outlook indicate, Dollar General has a very promising future. Today's accelerated store growth plans for 2016 and expanded capital return plan for shareholders reaffirm our continued confidence in our long-term growth prospects. Returning cash to shareholders remains a top priority, and we plan to return approximately $1.6 billion to shareholders during 2015 through both share repurchases and the initiation of a regular cash quarterly dividend of $0.22 per share.
I'm excited about another great year in 2015 as we look to capitalize on the numerous opportunities ahead of us. We have been and remain focused on Dollar General's core business, and we are confident that Dollar General is well positioned for sustainable growth, creating shareholder value going forward.
Let's recap some of the highlights for 2014. Full year sales increased 8% to a record $18.9 billion, and sales per square foot increased to $2 -- $223. 
2014 marked our 25th consecutive year of same-store sales growth as we delivered same-store sales growth of 2.8% for the year. Importantly, our trends improved as we moved through the year. Our same-store sales for the fourth quarter increased 4.9%, marking our fourth consecutive quarter of acceleration. In the quarter, same-store sales growth was balanced across both consumables and non-consumables. The non-consumables categories have had -- now had 4 consecutive quarters of improvement with notable strength in apparel and home.
For the year, GAAP earnings per share increased 10% and adjusted earnings per share increased 9%. Net income in the fourth quarter increased 10%. Earnings per share improved 16% to $1.17 per share.
For the quarter, the recent West Coast port slowdown negatively impacted our earnings per share by approximately $0.02 as higher margin merchandise coming through the West Coast port was delayed. This estimate includes incremental costs for shipments that had to be diverted to alternative facilities on the East Coast.
For the 28th consecutive quarter, we increased both our customer traffic and average ticket. We generated significant cash flow from operations of $1.3 billion, an increase of more than 8%. 
During the year, we returned $800 million to shareholders through the repurchase of 14.1 million shares of common stock.
As our results indicate, we continued to make great progress in 2014. We opened 700 new stores and exceeded our combined remodels and relocation targets with 915 stores, increasing our selling square footage by 6.3%. We broke ground on our 13th distribution center in San Antonio, Texas to help us serve our growing store base in the southwest and generate efficiencies.
On the merchandising front, we continued to innovate and improve the sales productivity of our stores. We successfully completed our first full year of tobacco sales and saw positive year-over-year performance after the anniversary. Our renewed focus on $1- to $5-items continued to gain traction with our customers. Now more than 75% of our SKUs or 76% of our sales in the fourth quarter were items priced at $5 or less. I'm pleased to say that we continued to increase our overall market share in consumables in both units and dollars across all markets over the 4-week, 12-week, 24-week and 52-week periods ending January 31, 2015. As we experienced last quarter, our emphasis on affordability continues to pay off as our unit share growth continues to outpace our dollar share growth over any period measured in the last 52 weeks.
In 2014, we successfully stabilized our shrink performance in the second quarter. Shrink had a modest positive contribution year-over-year to our gross margin performance in the second half of the year. This should bode well for 2015. 
We relaunched our customer satisfaction survey at the beginning of 2014 to reevaluate those aspects of the store experience that have the greatest impact on satisfaction and customer spending. We have seen the response from our customers improve consistently over the last 6 months as we measure what is important to them. We are constantly striving to fill the need to meet the changing demands of our customers. Looking ahead to 2015, we are cautiously optimistic for our core customer. For the first time in a number of years, there appears to be the potential for tailwinds to outweigh the headwinds for macro trends. And the consumer is more positive, as indicated by the recent consumer sentiment levels and consumer confidence having recently been at the highest level since August of 2007. It is my belief that these consumer confidence readings are impacted by a headlines job number that has improved and by lower energy prices. Offset to these positives are the elevated underemployment rate along with the continuing low labor participation rate, and we are watching these factors closely.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Todd to talk about our initiatives for 2015.

---

Thank you, Rick. Moving on to 2015, our core operating priorities remain clear: driving productive sales growth, enhancing gross margins, leveraging process improvement in IT to reduce cost, and strengthening and expanding our culture of serving others. The team is focused, and we are excited about our initiatives for 2015. 
We continue to be committed as ever to providing our customers with everyday low prices they know and trust at Dollar General. Affordability will play a key role as we look to expand SKUs across the store at the sweet spot of $1 to $5. Growing transactions and item units will continue to be key to our market share performance as we build upon our track record of success. 
In anticipation of changes to the competitive landscape, we've been testing several different labor models to determine the potential impact on sales growth. The goal of the test was to strategically target labor investments to grow market share in a competitive environment while providing for positive financial returns. Our experience in this test and learn has been positive, and we are selectively investing in store labor this year. The store operations team has specific metrics and timetables for achieving results. The great part of this is that we can be nimble in making adjustments to the model as appropriate. While I won't go into more detail today, I look forward to sharing more specifics and results as we roll through the program in 2015. 
In addition, we have realigned our store operations management structure to optimize the scale of our divisions, regions and districts to improve accountability and maximize mentorship and teamwork, all while driving stronger, more sustainable results. We made the alignment changes based on feedback we received from our field teams and a strategic evaluation of our operational structure and store growth plans. The result is an operational structure that allows our field leaders to focus on store standards and ultimately create a better and more consistent shopping experience for our consumers. For 2015, on average, we have reduced the number of stores per district. By optimizing the scale of our districts, we will reduce the time our district managers spend driving so they can invest more time mentoring and coaching our store managers on developing and strengthening their teams. This should result in improved store standards and drive incremental sales.
On the merchandising front, we're in the midst of repackaging our private brands across both select consumable and non-consumable categories. The goal of the repackaging is to enhance our customers' perception of our private brand quality and value for the price. We had a test launch of the new packaging in select products with very encouraging results, and the majority of these repackaged items are expected to be on the shelf by midyear. We continue to grow our private brands with SKU count up 6% over 2013 and penetration of about 24%.
We are continuously looking for ways to leverage technology and engage our customers. We completed the initial rollout of our digital coupon capabilities in August and began to aggressively launch the program at the end of September and throughout the fourth quarter with our Fast Way to Save promotion. To date, sign-ups have significantly exceeded our expectations with about 1 million customers having registered for the program. With more than 35 million digital coupons downloaded already, activations and redemptions are having a strong impact on sales of coupon-specific items.
