【回答: David Tehle (Executives)】
Yes, I think as we look at our operating margin, clearly, we do expect better performance than we saw in 2013 and 2014 given some of the product category headwinds we had from tobacco in those years. As we look forward, I think as we look at shrink and category management and foreign sourcing, again, we still think we have room to expand the operating margin. Now we've got to make a decision, and I've said this many times, in terms of how much of that to let fall to the bottom line and how much to invest back in our pricing because ultimately, our #1 goal remains selling units through the box and making sure that we continue to grow our transactions. So -- but again, there's still room there, particularly when you look at shrink, category management and foreign sourcing.

---

【質問: John Heinbockel (Analysts)】
And then, Rick, just as a follow-up on DG Market. When you look at what Aldi's doing, Lidl coming, does that format hold greater importance to you strategically than it might have a couple of years ago? Can you -- before you leave, can you kind of get it on the right track? And then is it -- do you see more -- the impact will be more in -- and if you do go forward with it, more in the format itself or learnings that you take back into the core dollar stores, be it produce, expanded food? Or we're not really going to see that?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, I think as I look at what we do best and probably, I would say, John, right now, the best format we have, when you mention competitors like Aldi, is our 7,500-square-foot box. Yes, there's some -- Aldi has some more consumables in it. But you have to remember, we're a convenience shop. We're not a destination shop. And I think that 7,500 box, when you look at that producing $223 a foot, you look at where it has come from, we believe that is the best piece we've got. When I think about Dollar General Market, I think you hit the nail on the head. I think that learnings are what we're extracting from that. And the fact that some of those learnings eventually are going to work their way into that 7,500 highly productive box.

---

【質問: Daniel Binder (Analysts)】
David, we'll be sorry to see you go, but congratulations on your retirement.

---

【回答: David Tehle (Executives)】
Thank you.

---

【質問: Daniel Binder (Analysts)】
My question was related to expansion this coming year. And then as you step it up to 7% square footage growth next year, is there a particular regional focus that you'll have?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Dan, that's a great question. The store base is going to expand pretty much uniformly all the way through United States. Obviously, we've just entered Oregon, Rhode Island and Maine. So there's probably a little bit more emphasis there, but the idea is to spread it out across the United States.

---

【質問: Daniel Binder (Analysts)】
And you cited this focus on price investment. Just curious if you could comment on what you're seeing in the competitive landscape this past quarter and early this quarter?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Good. Todd, you want to take that one?

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
Yes. Sure, Dan. What we've seen is in our channel and really across retail, it's always competitive. But what we've seen is a pretty rational competitive set, if you will. When you look at it, definitely much more rational than it was in fourth quarter of 2013. But there's pockets here and there we see, depending on the format that we see out there, that there are some competitors that may get a little hotter than others. But I -- we are committed to ensuring that we drive units and that we look at our share very, very intently each and every week to ensure that we're staying very competitive. But I think the biggest thing to take away is we are squarely EDLP focused, so everyday low price focused in everything we do.

---

【質問: Meredith Adler (Analysts)】
Lots of luck to you, David.

---

【回答: David Tehle (Executives)】
Thanks, Meredith.

---

【質問: Meredith Adler (Analysts)】
I got a couple of questions. And when David was talking about the things that would drive the operating margin, he didn't specifically mention higher sales of discretionary items. Even though I know that your apparel and home business is doing well, but do you see, as the customer feels better, that there is a potential to drive more high-margin sales?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Again, I think the answer to that is yes. We've worked really, really hard on the non-consumables side, Meredith. And I have to be honest, it took us a little longer to get there than we wanted. But I'll tell you what, the team that Todd and David assembled down there are really clicking now. And that's really encouraging about the non-consumables side is the rate of sell-through. And we're seeing a much larger -- a much higher sell-through on those goods, which, to your point, brings out the incremental margin, helps us with the incremental margin.

---

【質問: Meredith Adler (Analysts)】
Great. And then, I guess, my other question is maybe just a little more technical for David. But you continued to invest capital in stores that you're building yourselves, and I'm sure the economics of that are attractive. But I'm wondering whether there is an opportunity to do sale leasebacks, rates are low. And then if you were to do that, first, I don't know, maybe you could tell us how much -- how many stores you own at this point and whether you could generate incremental capital that could be invested or given back to shareholders?

---

【回答: David Tehle (Executives)】
Yes. And of course, last year we did do sale-leaseback and we used those proceeds to buy back stock. So I don't -- it's something we'll definitely take a look at. It's always on -- we don't have any plans right now to do it. It's always on the radar screen and certainly, it's something that we'll take a hard look at. And then the -- how many owned stores we have? Yes, we have between 500 and 600 owned stores right now.

---

【回答: Mary Winn Pilkington (Executives)】
Yes, about 5%.

---

【質問: Matthew Boss (Analysts)】
Can you help break down the components of your 3% to 3.5% same-store sales guide? Particularly, I know you guys benefit on the real estate side from the new store waterfall. It sounds like you have a lot of traffic-driving initiatives, and then maybe just touch on the expectation for nonfood, given the recent acceleration.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
I think Todd wants to take that one.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
Yes, when you take a look at it, what we -- we definitely, from our new store maturation, we see 1.5 to 2 percentage points of comp. Of course, category management plays a big piece in our comp as well. So between category management and execution at the store level, we really make up the balance piece of that. But affordability continues to be a key focus of ours to continue to drive the sales, as well as our focus on private brands. And then, lastly, you heard, we are doing a lot of remodels. We did a lot last year and we're -- we continue to do those in 2015. And updating that base out there of existing stores really makes a difference as we start to look at these remodels and adding to the comp. So when you put it all together, we feel pretty good about that 3% to 3.5% comp range.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
And I would piggyback on that, Matt, and Todd did a great job of talking about it, but his work on the affordability issue, the fact that over 75% of our SKUs in sales now are targeted between $1 and $5, that has a lot of broad appeal across a lot of income stratas. And we are continuing to work on that very hard and see upside on that initiative in '15 and beyond, to be honest about it.

---

【質問: Matthew Boss (Analysts)】
Great. And then on the stores front, Rick, can you just elaborate on the return profile and the payback period on new stores? And any changes you guys have seen in productivity levels at some of your more recent openings?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, I will. Our stores still open up at about 85% of our average store volume. 99% of our stores continue to be four-wall EBITDA positive, and the payback is roughly 1 year, 1.5 years, in that window.

---

【質問: Daniel Wewer (Analysts)】
Well, we hate to see you young guys retire from the company.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Actually, I was hoping for someone to say I'd been carrying David for 11 years.

---

【質問: Daniel Wewer (Analysts)】
I just wanted to ask on the stepped-up expansion rate in 2016, if you could talk about the type of real estate projects, particularly in terms of geography that you'll be pursuing that you would have perhaps passed on a year ago. And thinking specifically when you think about suburban, urban and rural markets, if we're going to see it change in the pace that you opened in those 3 type of geographies.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, I think Todd has a thought on that, Dan.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
Yes, Dan. As Rick said earlier, it is going to be broad-based across everywhere we are actually already operating stores in. We continue to look at all areas that we operate in. California continues to be an opportunity for us. We know that someday there will be over 1,100, 1,200 stores in California. So that continues to be an opportunity. But when you look at it in 2016, our balance between metro and rural is going to be about where it's been over the course of the last few years. And then as we go into outer years, we'll continue to leverage our learnings that we've got moving through on our metro stores and build and open up more of those as we move into '17, '18 and '19.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
If I could piggyback back then on, Dan, as we move further and further deeper into the 13,000, we're going to introduce more metro stores. And the team is looking at lots of different alternatives here in terms of the size of the box. We've actually been -- I think we've really done a great job on the mix that's in the stores. I do think that we have figured something out that we're going to test in '15 that could really guide us, really help generate incremental return in metro.

---

【質問: Daniel Wewer (Analysts)】
When you say metro stories, I'm assuming you're including suburban with urban. I was curious how would you just characterize Dollar General's success in suburban markets, which might have higher income levels than the company has targeted historically?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, I -- go ahead, Todd.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
I'm sorry, did you...

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
No. You go ahead, Todd.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
Yes, so when you look at it, our suburban stores, we're happy with the performance of those stores as -- but as Rick indicated, we're testing some things, both in suburban and metro, that we really feel can benefit us as we move through '15 and beyond, both from a labor perspective and a merchandising perspective with our technology that we've got moving in merch, to ensure we have the right mix of products as well as the right gross margin that is generated from that. So we feel pretty good about where we are, but there's always more learnings yet.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
I think it's fair to say that we're getting sophisticated enough now that we're able to alter the mix.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
That's right.

---

【質問: Scott Mushkin (Analysts)】
And David, everyone's saying congratulations. I've got to say maybe I'm just a little envious. I have teenage kids at home. So congrats, I guess. It'll be nice to spend a lot more time with them.

---

【回答: David Tehle (Executives)】
Well, thank you.

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
I don't know, Scott. I raised 2 kids. I don't know if being home when they're teenagers is a good thing or not.

---

【質問: Scott Mushkin (Analysts)】
So I guess, I want to get to labor cost, what you're thinking of as we look through the year. Obviously, a competitor raised their labor rates, but with labor markets getting pretty tight and how that affects your business, what you're seeing in store management turnover?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, I'll take that one. And then, Todd, if you want to lay any color on it, that would be fine. I know we're talking a lot about the minimum wage thing and what has happened with one of the larger big-box operators out there. A couple of things I'd like to lay out, Scott. Number one is we don't have a single full-time employee that's making minimum wage, not one. About 12% of our employees, all part time, are at the minimum wage rate. But the fascinating thing is the way our structure is in the store, after about 5 months, they are in a position to be promoted to what we call is a key carrier. And our average key carrier makes $9 an hour, approximately $9 an hour. So it's pretty safe to say that we -- our whole workforce is not making minimum wage and there is some sort of grand or fearful expense that's going to be there. And when I'm talking about minimum wage, I'm obviously talking about the federal minimum wage. What we are going to do though, I think it's fair to say the labor market, conceivably, is tightening up. We're going to keep our eyes. We're going to continue to monitor the landscape and we'll assess or make any adjustments that we need to make. But right now, in terms of what we're paying our people, we feel pretty comfortable that we're there. Our store manager turnover, quite frankly, is operating where it had been for a period of time. We are looking at it in terms of -- we look at it, excuse me, in terms of voluntary turnover and involuntary turnover. And obviously, there's a big difference between the 2. And when you add those 2 up, our turnover is around approximately 30%, which is a little high, quite frankly, for retail. I'd like to see that number down in the mid- to low 20s. But also I would tell you that our turnover has been improving over the course of the last 6 to 7 months, and it's continuing to move in a solid direction. So...

---

【質問: Scott Mushkin (Analysts)】
All right. That's perfect. And if I can just follow up one and maybe -- I know there's transition going on with the leadership and everything, so maybe it's just -- it's too strategic but, obviously, you went for Family Dollar. It didn't work out. When you think about acquisitions or when you think about capital deployment, is acquisitions part of what you consider? Or is it really not -- just kind of one unique situation and not something we look at?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Very fair question. And I will tell you, Scott, David and I have always looked at everything. So the answer is nothing is ever off the table. We want to look, we want to understand what we could do to maximize value for our shareholders. And if that opportunity raises itself down the road, I'm sure the management team is going to want to look at it.

---

【質問: Matt Nemer (Analysts)】
David, I'll add my congrats as well. I've actually got one question on the quarter, which is I'd love a little bit of color on the seasonal business. It looks like sales per foot were down about 1%. The 2-year stack was down about 6%. Is some of that related to the port? Or are there some other issues there?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Todd, go ahead.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
Yes, Matt, this is Todd. So when you look at our seasonal business, first, I want to say it's very healthy. Now when you back down and take a look at the components, the majority of the components are doing very well. The one structural piece that we, as well as probably other retailers, are fighting and battling every day is the toy business. The toy business is embedded in our seasonal business. And structurally, as we all know, that business had been very, very tough over the past few years with electronics and computers and video games and everything else being where -- much more prominent to kids these days than the toys. But we're very happy when we look at seasonal. The team has done a tremendous amount of work on affordability within seasonal. We have about 26%, last year, more $1 items that we had the year before. I can tell you they were squarely focused on the buy this year, which is now complete for holiday of 2015, and that number has been stepped up even more. But our sweet spot, as we said before, is really $1 to $5. But in seasonal, $1 to $3 is really where we play and we do very well in.

---

【質問: Matt Nemer (Analysts)】
Great. That's helpful. And then, secondly, I was looking to see if we can get some more color on the labor model that Todd mentioned, the new labor model. Is the primary goal to speed up checkout? Or is it more about maintaining the store? Love to get some more color on that and also whether that would be baked in the guidance if you decide to roll it out more broadly this year.

---

【回答: Todd Vasos (Executives)】
Yes, Matt, thanks for letting me answer that one. I could tell you that the labor model that we have currently existing in our stores, we look at it each and every day to make sure that, that, in fact, is the right model. Now what we've seen is that in certain geographic areas, we can spend a little bit more time inside of our stores stocking and ensuring the customer experience is at the highest level that it possibly can. So what we've done is strategically taken a group of stores on a test and tested that theory. It tested out very well. And we are in the process, as we roll through 2015, to roll that test broadly out to a large group of our stores over 2015. Once again, it's very targeted to certain stores, but it is a large group of our stores.

---

【質問: Scot Ciccarelli (Analysts)】
So during the conference call, I think it was you, Rick, that mentioned you do anticipate changes in the competitive landscape and obviously, Todd just talked about some of the changes on the labor model. Can you provide some color regarding what kind of changes you're expecting? And is this just on the pending -- any pending changes with Family Dollar, now that's going to be in new hands, or are there other elements that you were referencing?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, a fair question, Scot. I think that obviously the #1 thing on our radar screen is the change that is taking place between Dollar Tree and Family Dollar. Once again, the big-box guys are now announcing more initiatives. And what we're trying to do is just stay focused on absolutely everything that's out there. Now while we can only control what we can control, we have -- the beauty of our model is it takes a little bit from a lot of different spots rather than having to grab everything from one spot. So consequently, we stay focused on what absolutely everybody is doing. And yes, I didn't mean to send any unjust or unneeded fear or anything, but we're staying very focused on what everybody is doing. There's a lot of moving parts out there right now.

---

【質問: Scot Ciccarelli (Analysts)】
So just a general expectation that it's going to be a dynamic competitive environment?

---

【回答: Richard Dreiling (Executives)】
Yes, just the fact that there's a lot of new faces managing new assets, right?

---

【質問: Scot Ciccarelli (Analysts)】
Yes. Okay. Fair enough. And then my follow-up is any -- I guess, David, you talked a little about the EBIT margin opportunity down the road. Can you provide a little bit more color why you're expecting EBIT margins then to be flat to down this year, what -- versus what, frankly, seems to be a bit of an easy comparison following 4 straight years of kind of 10%-plus EBIT margins? Is it some of that's labor investment? Or is it just the continued mix shift on -- impact on the gross margin, et cetera?

---

【回答: David Tehle (Executives)】
Yes, the biggest piece is clearly the labor investment that we're making in our SG&A line, and that really is the bulk of the story there. Again, we expect better performance than we saw in 2013 and 2014 on the gross margin, given some of the product category headwinds we had from tobacco in those years, cycling over that. And then I mentioned we continue to like what we're seeing in shrink, getting some improvement there, and then category management and foreign sourcing helping us. But it's the investment in labor that we're making.

---

【回答: Mary Winn Pilkington (Executives)】
All right. I think that will conclude our call today. We have a new member of our IR team in Matt Hancock, and some -- I know some of you had a chance to meet Matt. If you haven't had a chance to meet him, I look forward to introducing to -- you to him. And we'll be around today for calls, so I know we will left some people in the queue, so please feel free to give me a call. Thank you. Operator, that will now conclude our call.

BP9DL90.eventHeadline: Industria de Diseno Textil SA, 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 18, 2015
BP9DL90.transcript_text1:
Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex results for fiscal 2014. I am Pablo Isla, and here with me today are Ignacio Fernández, our CFO; and Marcos López, Capital Markets Director.
The results for 2014 show that Inditex continues its global growth. We enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates stores and online and offers huge growth opportunities. 2014 has been a year of strong expansion for Inditex. We have achieved satisfactory sales growth. The year has been marked by a tight control of operating expenses and significant investments in the expansion of our business. We have finished the year with operations on 5 continents through 8 concepts, 6,683 stores globally and an online presence in the most relevant markets. We start 2015 with a unique platform that can access growth opportunities globally.  
I would like to highlight some key lines on this results. In 2014, Inditex continued expanding its operations in a very significant way. Like-for-like sales grew strongly at 5% on a demanding comparable. Space growth was 10%. Online launches were on track. We are operating an online platform in 27 markets with a wide geographical coverage and rapid growth. 
Based on the performance of our business over the year, the Board of Directors is proposing a 7.5% increase in the dividend to be paid in relation to these results. 
2014 has been marked by very strong activity on many fronts. I would like to cover a number of initiatives carried out by Inditex. Over fiscal 2014, we have reinforced significantly the differentiation of our key global flagships with very visible store openings. As an example, Zara, at 592 East Nanjing Road occupies 3,000 square meters of retail space in this unique location, and is one of our most emblematic stores worldwide. 
The opening of global flagships is set to continue over fiscal 2015 with highly prominent stores. As an example we have recently reopened Zara's store at 500 5th Avenue, New York, which has doubled it's retail space to 4,000 square meters. In April, we are opening a global flagship for Zara at 61 Oxford St. in London of 4,500 square meters. The program will continue over the year with the opening of a global flagship of more than 4,000 square meters for Zara at SoHo in New York. 
We are in a unique position as we enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates stores and online as the best way to respond to the demands of our customers. This is a result of our highly differentiated business model with a central inventory position, distribution to all our stores globally at least twice a week and orders received by our customers between 2 and 48 hours. This factor works perfectly in conjunction with our global online sales presence. We believe that Inditex is in an excellent position to take advantage of global growth opportunities where we have a strong potential to continue expanding profitably in the coming years. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio who will present some of the key aspects of our financial performance, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

Thank you. In fiscal 2014, Inditex achieved net sales of EUR 18.1 billion, EBITDA of EUR 4.1 billion, a net income of EUR 2.5 billion. Inditex has had strong operating performance. As you can see from our financial release, currency translation due to the strong euro versus several currencies has been a feature of the period.  
Starting with sales, I would like to tell you that in the test performance in the period has been satisfactory with sales growth of 8.3%. Taking down the different components of sales, like-for-like sales grew strongly at 5%. Space contribution was 7%. Change in perimeter reduced reported sales by 1%. The translation of sales in currencies different to the euro diverted  [indiscernible] percentage point from the reported figure. 
Over 2014 Inditex retail space grew 10% to 3.8 million square meters. We have seen a strong expansion of our selling area in prime locations. We have added 344,000 square meters of space to our retail base over the year. The ongoing expansion of our group has led to global sales platform with a presence in 88 markets on 5 continents, both in the Northern and Southern hemispheres. 
Regarding the gross margin, we can say that we are satisfied with evolution in 2014. Gross profit has increased 7% to EUR 10.6 billion resulting a 58.3% gross margin on sales. We have sustained our commercial policies over the period. The change in the accounting method for Tempe from proportional consolidation to the equity method according to the new IFRS rule highlighted earlier this year, have reduced Inditex gross margin by 40 basis points in 2014. This is a presentational issue with no impact on net income.
Operating expenses are totally under control. We have grown 7.7% supporting the strong like-for-like [indiscernible] performance and the significant addition of new retail space. This line includes all the start-up costs for new space and the rollout of online sales. Operating working capital remains negative as a result of the business model. The working capital evolution is in line with the performance of the business. 
In 2014, funds from operations reached EUR 3.4 billion, 14% higher. Ordinary capital expenditure was EUR 1.4 billion. Dividends paid last year were EUR 1.5 billion, 10% higher. Inditex continues to show a strong financial position. Net cash and short-term financial investments were EUR 4 billion.
I will now hand it over to Marcos who will elaborate on the performance of Inditex concepts.

---

In terms of space addition and online launches, we are on track. Continuing with our global expansion, we have opened stores in 54 markets over the period. Global online launches have continued at a very rapid pace. Regarding the performance by concept in 2014, Zara continues to represent approximately 2/3 of group sales, the younger concepts around 1/3. 
I would like to highlight the strong operating performance of the group over 2014. Let me point out that in this period all Inditex's concepts have achieved positive like-for-like sales growth and EBIT margins on sales of 50% or higher. The younger concepts, grouped together, have also performed very well. I would like to highlight that Oysho, Zara Home, Massimo Dutti and Stradivarius have performed very strongly. And finally, I would like to mention that Uterqüe has achieved very strong like-for-like sales growth in the period. 
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

Thank you, Marcos. In the coming years, we will continue to invest in the expansion of our business across a number of markets, all of which offer attractive long-term returns through our sales platform that fully integrates stores and online. Inditex is present on 5 continents and in all the key markets, demonstrating the group's global reach. We manage a diversified sales platform in 88 markets. The current base offers huge growth potential for the coming years. 
In Europe, we continue to see huge growth opportunities in both Western and Eastern Europe. It is an area of growth for all our formats and we have an online sales presence in 21 markets. We see great potential to continue expanding profitably in Europe. 
In Asia, our priority is to leverage the strong presence we have established over recent years. Asia accounts today for 20% of Inditex sales. Our expansion has been remarkable due to the excellent reception of our business proposition focused on the latest fashions and the fact that many of the markets are experiencing transformation. We currently enjoy a very strong position in all the key markets of the region. We are following a multi-concept expansion strategy in Asia and we have an online presence in China, Japan and South Korea. 
We see a strong long-term potential for Inditex in Asian markets. We expect very important growth in China through the combination of our 500 strong store network and online sales. We also see strong growth opportunities in the Americas with a number of attractive growth markets. We are following a multi-concept and an online sales strategy in the Americas. We now have an online presence in the United States, Canada and Mexico. We see strong growth ahead of us in the United States. We are growing through a strong combination of very prominent flagship stores and online.
As we have mentioned to you, we will be opening our global flagship for Zara in SoHo, New York over the year. Other key cities will see important openings in 2015, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Diego, Las Vegas, Houston, Dallas, Boston, New Jersey and Seattle. These openings will be combined with the strong growth we are experiencing in our online sales in the U.S.
We have continued expanding Zara in Australia and South Africa over 2014, confirming the global reach of our business model. Zara Home is now present in Australia. We will continue to add very significant new stores in both markets over the current year.
Inditex online operations have seen a very rapid growth in recent years. Our business model allows a swift expansion of our online sales globally. Zara has built an online sales presence in 21 European markets, the United States, China, the Russian Federation, Japan, South Korea, Mexico and Canada, the world's main economies. The concepts also have an established online sales presence in Europe. Additionally, some of the concepts are present in the United States. We will continue to rollout online sales progressively in all the markets in which we are present with stores. A step in this direction will be the launch of online sales in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in the autumn-winter season.
2015 will be another year of strong expansion for Inditex. We expect space growth in line with our long-term targets. We plan to open 420 to 480 stores and to absorb 80 to 100 small units into neighboring stores. In recent years, we have seen very intense investment in logistics, central departments and the acquisition of some unique premises. For the coming years, we continue to see strong growth opportunities with capital expenditure growing below space growth. We now see a normalized level of investment with capital expenditure for 2015 around EUR 1.35 billion.
Regarding shareholder remuneration, the Board of Directors will propose at the General Shareholders Meeting a 7.5% increase in the dividend for fiscal 2014 to EUR 0.52 per share. This means the dividend per share has more than doubled since 2009. The total dividend payment will come to EUR 1.6 billion.
Finally, let me tell you that the store and online sales in local currencies have increased 13% from the first of February to the 14th of March 2015. As you all know, the spring-summer season is influenced by the performance over the Easter period due to its significant sales volumes.
And this is all from us. Now we will be pleased to answer any questions you may have.
BP9DL90.transcript_text2:
【プレゼン: Pablo De Tejera (Executives)】
Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex results for fiscal 2014. I am Pablo Isla, and here with me today are Ignacio Fernández, our CFO; and Marcos López, Capital Markets Director.
The results for 2014 show that Inditex continues its global growth. We enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates stores and online and offers huge growth opportunities. 2014 has been a year of strong expansion for Inditex. We have achieved satisfactory sales growth. The year has been marked by a tight control of operating expenses and significant investments in the expansion of our business. We have finished the year with operations on 5 continents through 8 concepts, 6,683 stores globally and an online presence in the most relevant markets. We start 2015 with a unique platform that can access growth opportunities globally.  
I would like to highlight some key lines on this results. In 2014, Inditex continued expanding its operations in a very significant way. Like-for-like sales grew strongly at 5% on a demanding comparable. Space growth was 10%. Online launches were on track. We are operating an online platform in 27 markets with a wide geographical coverage and rapid growth. 
Based on the performance of our business over the year, the Board of Directors is proposing a 7.5% increase in the dividend to be paid in relation to these results. 
2014 has been marked by very strong activity on many fronts. I would like to cover a number of initiatives carried out by Inditex. Over fiscal 2014, we have reinforced significantly the differentiation of our key global flagships with very visible store openings. As an example, Zara, at 592 East Nanjing Road occupies 3,000 square meters of retail space in this unique location, and is one of our most emblematic stores worldwide. 
The opening of global flagships is set to continue over fiscal 2015 with highly prominent stores. As an example we have recently reopened Zara's store at 500 5th Avenue, New York, which has doubled it's retail space to 4,000 square meters. In April, we are opening a global flagship for Zara at 61 Oxford St. in London of 4,500 square meters. The program will continue over the year with the opening of a global flagship of more than 4,000 square meters for Zara at SoHo in New York. 
We are in a unique position as we enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates stores and online as the best way to respond to the demands of our customers. This is a result of our highly differentiated business model with a central inventory position, distribution to all our stores globally at least twice a week and orders received by our customers between 2 and 48 hours. This factor works perfectly in conjunction with our global online sales presence. We believe that Inditex is in an excellent position to take advantage of global growth opportunities where we have a strong potential to continue expanding profitably in the coming years. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio who will present some of the key aspects of our financial performance, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

【プレゼン: Ignacio Izuzquiza Fernández (Executives)】
Thank you. In fiscal 2014, Inditex achieved net sales of EUR 18.1 billion, EBITDA of EUR 4.1 billion, a net income of EUR 2.5 billion. Inditex has had strong operating performance. As you can see from our financial release, currency translation due to the strong euro versus several currencies has been a feature of the period.  
Starting with sales, I would like to tell you that in the test performance in the period has been satisfactory with sales growth of 8.3%. Taking down the different components of sales, like-for-like sales grew strongly at 5%. Space contribution was 7%. Change in perimeter reduced reported sales by 1%. The translation of sales in currencies different to the euro diverted  [indiscernible] percentage point from the reported figure. 
Over 2014 Inditex retail space grew 10% to 3.8 million square meters. We have seen a strong expansion of our selling area in prime locations. We have added 344,000 square meters of space to our retail base over the year. The ongoing expansion of our group has led to global sales platform with a presence in 88 markets on 5 continents, both in the Northern and Southern hemispheres. 
Regarding the gross margin, we can say that we are satisfied with evolution in 2014. Gross profit has increased 7% to EUR 10.6 billion resulting a 58.3% gross margin on sales. We have sustained our commercial policies over the period. The change in the accounting method for Tempe from proportional consolidation to the equity method according to the new IFRS rule highlighted earlier this year, have reduced Inditex gross margin by 40 basis points in 2014. This is a presentational issue with no impact on net income.
Operating expenses are totally under control. We have grown 7.7% supporting the strong like-for-like [indiscernible] performance and the significant addition of new retail space. This line includes all the start-up costs for new space and the rollout of online sales. Operating working capital remains negative as a result of the business model. The working capital evolution is in line with the performance of the business. 
In 2014, funds from operations reached EUR 3.4 billion, 14% higher. Ordinary capital expenditure was EUR 1.4 billion. Dividends paid last year were EUR 1.5 billion, 10% higher. Inditex continues to show a strong financial position. Net cash and short-term financial investments were EUR 4 billion.
I will now hand it over to Marcos who will elaborate on the performance of Inditex concepts.

---

【プレゼン: Marcos García (Executives)】
In terms of space addition and online launches, we are on track. Continuing with our global expansion, we have opened stores in 54 markets over the period. Global online launches have continued at a very rapid pace. Regarding the performance by concept in 2014, Zara continues to represent approximately 2/3 of group sales, the younger concepts around 1/3. 
I would like to highlight the strong operating performance of the group over 2014. Let me point out that in this period all Inditex's concepts have achieved positive like-for-like sales growth and EBIT margins on sales of 50% or higher. The younger concepts, grouped together, have also performed very well. I would like to highlight that Oysho, Zara Home, Massimo Dutti and Stradivarius have performed very strongly. And finally, I would like to mention that Uterqüe has achieved very strong like-for-like sales growth in the period. 
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

【プレゼン: Pablo De Tejera (Executives)】
Thank you, Marcos. In the coming years, we will continue to invest in the expansion of our business across a number of markets, all of which offer attractive long-term returns through our sales platform that fully integrates stores and online. Inditex is present on 5 continents and in all the key markets, demonstrating the group's global reach. We manage a diversified sales platform in 88 markets. The current base offers huge growth potential for the coming years. 
In Europe, we continue to see huge growth opportunities in both Western and Eastern Europe. It is an area of growth for all our formats and we have an online sales presence in 21 markets. We see great potential to continue expanding profitably in Europe. 
In Asia, our priority is to leverage the strong presence we have established over recent years. Asia accounts today for 20% of Inditex sales. Our expansion has been remarkable due to the excellent reception of our business proposition focused on the latest fashions and the fact that many of the markets are experiencing transformation. We currently enjoy a very strong position in all the key markets of the region. We are following a multi-concept expansion strategy in Asia and we have an online presence in China, Japan and South Korea. 
We see a strong long-term potential for Inditex in Asian markets. We expect very important growth in China through the combination of our 500 strong store network and online sales. We also see strong growth opportunities in the Americas with a number of attractive growth markets. We are following a multi-concept and an online sales strategy in the Americas. We now have an online presence in the United States, Canada and Mexico. We see strong growth ahead of us in the United States. We are growing through a strong combination of very prominent flagship stores and online.
As we have mentioned to you, we will be opening our global flagship for Zara in SoHo, New York over the year. Other key cities will see important openings in 2015, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Diego, Las Vegas, Houston, Dallas, Boston, New Jersey and Seattle. These openings will be combined with the strong growth we are experiencing in our online sales in the U.S.
We have continued expanding Zara in Australia and South Africa over 2014, confirming the global reach of our business model. Zara Home is now present in Australia. We will continue to add very significant new stores in both markets over the current year.
Inditex online operations have seen a very rapid growth in recent years. Our business model allows a swift expansion of our online sales globally. Zara has built an online sales presence in 21 European markets, the United States, China, the Russian Federation, Japan, South Korea, Mexico and Canada, the world's main economies. The concepts also have an established online sales presence in Europe. Additionally, some of the concepts are present in the United States. We will continue to rollout online sales progressively in all the markets in which we are present with stores. A step in this direction will be the launch of online sales in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in the autumn-winter season.
2015 will be another year of strong expansion for Inditex. We expect space growth in line with our long-term targets. We plan to open 420 to 480 stores and to absorb 80 to 100 small units into neighboring stores. In recent years, we have seen very intense investment in logistics, central departments and the acquisition of some unique premises. For the coming years, we continue to see strong growth opportunities with capital expenditure growing below space growth. We now see a normalized level of investment with capital expenditure for 2015 around EUR 1.35 billion.
Regarding shareholder remuneration, the Board of Directors will propose at the General Shareholders Meeting a 7.5% increase in the dividend for fiscal 2014 to EUR 0.52 per share. This means the dividend per share has more than doubled since 2009. The total dividend payment will come to EUR 1.6 billion.
Finally, let me tell you that the store and online sales in local currencies have increased 13% from the first of February to the 14th of March 2015. As you all know, the spring-summer season is influenced by the performance over the Easter period due to its significant sales volumes.
And this is all from us. Now we will be pleased to answer any questions you may have.
BP9DL90.transcript_text3:
My question is about rents. I mean, following fairly good macro recovery in many markets, are you seeing rental inflation now accelerate? And is that something we need to take account of in the operating cost line to the year ahead? And on the side, are you paying your rents in Russia in dollars, please?

---

Well, regarding your question, I will tell you that we are not seeing any different environment that could have been the case during the last year. So you should not expect, for this year, rental expenses to go above the space growth. And having -- and regarding the second part of your question, what we can tell you is that most of our rental agreements in Russia are in local currencies, as it is the case in any other country.

---

I've got 2 quick questions. Firstly, again, actually on Russia, do you expect to continue to expand in Russia at the same pace as the last few years? It was the country with the biggest number of stores opened last year, is that going to continue? And secondly, on infrastructure, how many more years of capacity do you think you have with the current level of infrastructure that you have?

---

Well, regarding Russia, what I can tell you is that, in our business in Russia continues developing, I would say, in a very normal and positive way in local currencies. As always, when we talk about any particular market where we always have in mind the medium and the long term, not only the short term, so the idea, of course, is to continue developing our business in Russia. In terms of the number of openings in one particular year, you must have in mind that in Russia, most of the expansion has to do with shopping malls. And when we decide to go to a shopping mall, typically, we go with 7 or 8 brands. So you could have from one year to another, 30 or 40 stores of difference, but finally 3, 4 different shopping malls. But globally, as from a strategic point of view, we will continue developing our business in Russia. That, as I was saying to you just before, is a business which is having a very, I would say, healthy evolution. And regarding infrastructure, what we can say is that we are not expecting, at least in the next 3 years, big investments that have to do with infrastructure. We have gone through a very significant period in terms of investments, both in our central headquarters, the facilities and then of course, logistics. And now we have enough -- of course, every year, there are investments in logistics because you are permanently investing. But we are not expecting, at least in the next 3 years, any huge logistic investment.

---

It's Rebecca with Santander. A couple of questions, please. Firstly, in terms of your CapEx guidance, obviously, you're guiding to CapEx growth below sales growth. Do you think that would be similar to the dynamics next year and the year after until we get through to the next investment period?

---

Yes. Yes. We think this will continue being the case. We anticipated this to you more or less have -- 6 months ago, that what we were seeing for the near future was a CapEx growth to go below space growth. This is going to be the case in the year 2015 and this will continue being the case in the year 2016.

---

And then my question is on the recent like-for-like momentum. Is that totally volume or is there any pricing -- is there any ASP inflation in that like-for-like trend?

---

No. Our like-for-like is volume driven, as it has always been the case. We have, in the year 2014, we have had very positive like-for-like, 5%. We have had positive like-for-like in all the geographies, in all the different concepts. So -- and like-for-like is volume driven as it is always the case.

---

Okay. And sorry, just one final one. Can you give some guidance on the 2015 gross margin given what's been going on with the U.S. dollar?

---

Well, what we can say, of course, we are just at the very beginning of the year. And what we can say at current exchange rates, our forecast would be a stable gross margin. But as we always say, stable means plus or minus 50 basis points and we are just at the beginning of the year. But at this stage, we would say a stable gross margin for the year 2015.

---

Okay. With the lead time of about 3 months on your sourcing, is that right?

---

Well, I think this is something -- it has to do with -- when we talk about the gross margin, we always say that it has to do with many different elements. And what I would say is what I was saying before, that at current exchange rate and at the beginning of the year, at this stage, we would be seeing a stable gross margin for the full year.

---

A follow-up question on the gross margin guidance. I think that the impact from the U.S. dollar is quite limited nowadays. And looking back, the FX was negative over the last 2 years and impacted sales by around 5% negatively. If we assume that the FX now could impact positively sales going forward, don't you think that eventually should also be positive for gross margin? And eventually, the gross margin could expand more than the flat or more than your guidance of flat margin that you just presented? That's my question. And also, related to FX, what could be the FX -- the impact on FX on full year '15?

---

Okay. Regarding the gross margin, José, as you know the gross margin is composed of many factors, currency is one of them. And I think that at this stage, what we have said is that at current exchange rates the gross margin expectation is for a stable gross margin. This is very much our policy taking into account all the different elements.

---

And about the FX for the year, we would say the same, I mean, we are just at the beginning of the year. At current exchange rates, we will see a slightly positive impact on sales coming from ForEx, but we are just at the beginning of the year.

---

Okay. But slightly impact will be positive, right?

---

Yes. At current exchange rates, yes. But as we were saying to you, we are just at the beginning of the year.

---

I was just wondering, if you could talk a little bit about Spain, given it's your biggest geography. Can you give us a sense of what your like-for-like growth rates are there? And how the Spanish growth impacts, if anything, on you gross margin, is it positive or negative for gross margin?

---

Well, about Spain, what we can say is that our sales in the year have grown 5%, which is quite a relevant figure in Spain. Our space is flat, so we are not increasing and we are not decreasing our space in the Spanish market. So our sales in the year have grown 5%. We began to see a recovery of sales in the second half of the year 2013. And then this year, 2014, has been a very solid year in terms of sales growth. We have been very active in the Spanish market, as you know, with some very relevant openings in Madrid with Zara with Massimo Dutti, in San Sebastian also with Zara and then with all the other brands, so we have been very active. We will continue being very active with refurbishments, with openings. Globally, our space in Spain will remain stable during the year 2015. What I would say is that we are operating our business now in a very normal environment, I would say. So if we have good collections, if we have the right product, we are able to increase our sales, as it has been the case during the year 2014. And about Spain in terms of the gross margin, is very similar to all the other geographies.

---

I just wondered, Pablo, if you could just comment on your approach to pricing globally, particularly given recent currency volatility in markets like Russia and I guess, to lesser extent Japan. Are you planing to raise prices gradually over a number of seasons in those sort of markets?

---

Well, first of all, what I would tell you is that, globally, because then you are talking about very specific markets, but globally, our prices remain stable. And always, in everything which has to do with prices, we always have a medium and long-term approach because when we are in a market we are always planning to be in the market forever. So we always have in mind the medium and the long-term approach. In some cases, when there is a currency volatility and there is significant inflation, we could decide to adjust progressively our prices, never to increase dramatically our prices in one particular season. But for example, if you just talk about Russia, we have increased slightly our prices because of these 2 conditions. But always having in mind the medium and long-term approach and always having in mind that when we are in a market, we want to be in that market for many, many years. So we are not particularly upset with translating any type of currency movement to prices at any -- in any particular season. So globally, a stable pricing policy. In some cases, in some markets, there could be slight price increases, but having always in mind, the medium and the long-term approach.

---

Okay. So I can totally understand price increases in Russia. But are there any markets where we're actually getting price reductions over the course of this season?

---

I prefer not to enter into the specifics of any particular market, if it's -- it's a global stable pricing policy.

---

I was wondering if you could speak a little bit about the U.S. given that the rollout in 2015 seems to be an acceleration from what you've done over the last few years. And is that, that you've seen more information about demand given your e-commerce business or you think conditions are changing there that may get a more attractive market for entry now versus a few years ago?

---

As you were mentioning the USA is a market in which we are feeling more and more comfortable about expanding our business. 2014 has been quite relevant from that point of view and 2015 will be even more relevant with a significant number of openings and particularly with some very relevant openings or reopenings, because we were mentioning during the presentation this refurbishment and enlargement on Fifth Avenue with 42nd Street, which is an incredible -- it was a very good store and now after the enlargement and refurbishment is becoming an incredible store. Or our new store in the SoHo in the final part of the year or in the World Trade Center, or openings that we are having in many different cities. As I was saying to you, we see clearly that the U.S. is a growth market for us. We have this combination between store openings and online. Online, of course, is giving us access to all the customers in all the different cities in the country. And we clearly see for the year 2015 and for the coming years, the U.S. as a significant market for us in terms of expansion, in terms of growth, with this fully integrated approach between online and stores that we think is a very good strategy to -- for the U.S. market as for any other market. Because for us what is very relevant is this concept of being fully integrated retailers. Retailer, online and stores are completely integrated from every point of view. You can order online from the stores. You can order online and have the delivery in the store. The return of our customer is fully integrated in his mindset. So we, as a retailer, we are also fully integrated and we think that this approach is very strong in any particular market, but talking specifically about the U.S., of course, this is the case. So this -- in the year 2014, we had significant openings in the U.S. In the year 2015, it will be much more relevant and this will continue being the case in the coming years.

---

I just wanted to come back to your comments on currency. I think you said there will be a small modest, positive impact to sales at current exchange rates and also, you anticipate a stable gross margin. Could you just clarify, do you mean current exchange rates as in spot this morning or the exchange rates when you did your budgeting about 4 to 6 weeks ago, presumably?

---

We don't want to be that specific, Fraser. I think that we did at the start of the year, and I think that the guidance we are providing is reasonable, a small positive impact on sales at the current exchange rates. And obviously, the gross margin is not just currency, you have on this mix is a -- there are many, many factors. So all things considered, and at current exchange rates, what we can say now is a broadly stable gross margin for the year.

---

And just to clarify on pricing, because this obviously relates to the same question on gross margin. I think in recent years, some of the premium markets like Japan, like China, those premier have come down. Where do you see the sort of differential to the eurozone currently for markets such as the U.S. and China?

---

Well, as we have mentioned during the call, our pricing strategy tends to be very global. If you take our base prices, which are Europe x Spain, I would tell you that the differentials are not very material. Obviously, you mentioned in markets which have experienced a significant currency depreciation like Japan. But in general, I would say that the differentials are relatively limited. So we continue to foresee a stable global pricing policy.

---

Just a quick question on working capital. I was just looking at the balance sheet and you've set out, I think in your release, that negative working capital position looks stable year-on-year. But in the cash flow, you've got an outflow of about EUR 101 million. I'm just wondering, what explains the difference between those figures?

---

Well, in -- I suppose you are referring to the funds from operations, and this refers mostly to the calendar of payments. In many cases, sometimes it just the tax.

---

Good morning. The first question from the webcast platform is regarding China. Can you comment on your expectations for China over 2015 and the coming years?

---

Well, as we were saying during the presentation, at the end of last year, we were operating 500 stores in China. We have a strong presence through our stores with all the different brands. We have a strong online presence. We also began, last year, our operations through Tmall, not only for our own web page, but also through Tmall. In the year 2015, we are planning also to open a significant number of stores to continue developing our business always. Our store opening plan, as in any other market, is a combination between high street locations and shopping mall. We were mentioning in the presentation this very relevant opening in Shanghai, or the relevant opening we had done, more or less at the same time, at the end of last year in Nanjing [ph]. We'll continue with this process of opening relevant stores, opening stores in different shopping malls. We see China as a very relevant market for us today, and this will continue being the case in the coming years, because of the size of the market, because of the evolution, because of how customers appreciate fashion. So it's quite a relevant market for us for all our brands.

---

Okay. We've got a number of questions regarding online. Can you give us an update on online? And specifically, are there any metrics that you can talk about, for example, in-store returns and deliveries, et cetera?

---

Well, we as I was saying in a previous question, we are a fully integrated retailer. So for us, online and the stores are totally integrated. You were mentioning this possibility of in-store deliveries, in-store returns. I would say, close to 1/3 of total deliveries are taking place in the stores and close to 2/3 of total returns are taking place in the stores. So this is something quite positive for us, because it's very convenient for our customers. And at the same time, they are coming to our stores. So for us, what is key is this central inventory position, this possibility to develop our online business and this full integration between stores and online.

---

Okay. And the final question from the webcast platform, can you update us on where you are with your RFID project?

---

Well, we are -- we'll continue with the implementation. Now it is implemented in more than 1,000 stores globally at the end of this year. It will be implemented in more than 1,500 Zara stores in the different countries in the world. And this project, as we mentioned to you before, is very relevant in terms of store management, in terms of replenishment, in terms of inventories, in terms of customer service. Finally, because this is what we want to achieve with this project, which is very relevant in the way we operate the stores and which has been very, very positive from every point of view.

---

Okay. We have no further questions from the webcast. Thank you.

---

Well, thank you to all of you for joining us during this conference call. And of course, as always, we will be ready to continue answering your questions by phone or in further meetings.  Thank you very much for joining us today. Thank you.
